content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edge of space is a very ambitious game with current plot holes and some minor glitches. The game however its self has a unique array of weapons, functions, game mechanics overall are interesting. At first I thought this would be somewhat like terraria but I was quickly mistaken. It only looks somewhat similar. Probably a concept overlap in overal cosmetics but other than that it all functions quite seperately. It revolves around you and your character who crash lands on archoa. You need to terraform the planet to be suitable, build a base, etc. Terraforming is not available yet unless they consider base building terraforming but that's unlikely. Overall, I don't have too much to say but this game is great. I'm hooked and it's absolutely a blast with friends! They come out with new content regularly, and while some times things break, other times you get cool things as of now like a gun that glitched past the clip capacity to have 65 ammo. Neat stuff all around. If you like the idea, please support the game and buy it! I pirated it first, and was happy with it until I ran out of cyro rods. That killed it, but then I bought the real deal and ho boy! 10/10, as of right now, I suggest it! The deal maker was cyro rods dropping from jellyfish for me and the fire fox. It takes a bit of brains to figure things out on your own, but do not give up arconauts, it is a journey to see through to the end! Checklist:Story: Work in progress but check.Weapons: Check! (wish they had bigger hit boxes, though you get used to it.)Monsters: I hate you. (check)Mechanics: Colorful. Lots of stuff to do and figure out. Check.Difficulty: Hell yeah! Check!Variety: I'm not sure. Check in my book.Fun: Check!Many moar checks, including bugs. Oh well! BUY.THIS.GAME.

number of helpful: 37 of 58 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I've bought this game when it was v0.16 or something and played around many versions and at time i write this review i have like 200h played.To keep it short - i like this game pretty much and game quite improved since long ago. Shamefully, no longer supported.To tell the truth, 1.0`s feature wasnt suprise for me since i was in inner test team, yet those changes from last public build to 1.0 made game much more and quite much more entertaining. I'd even say it made game lively - tons of different events waiting for you to blow up (well, some of them do require you to bomb some places).So, what's this game about? - it's about exploration of planet, on which you had emergency landing when ArkCo`s shop crashed (watch the intro cinematics for more story) - thus you're alone (or not - if multiplayer with friends) and now you need to explore this world, getting resources and making better  equipment in process (typical for all such games). Further you go down - better resources, more dungerous enemies, new places to visit. For most actions you get XP to spend in knowledge window to get access to better gear and new facilities.EoS is about exploring ONE planet (different each time you make new world, following some generation rules obviously), furthermore - exploring it VERTICALLY - there are 3 biomes, which is placed vertically, even thought you will explore it in rather horisontal line, then moving down to next one. Also, note there isnt any solid terrain - rather flying chunks of it (codex it for why), thus you will not be forced to dig through solid terrain to get lower and lower.Many ppl complaining about game being too hardcore at start since weapon you begin with sucks at dmg (lol, ppl didnt even bother opening crafting window to see 1 scematics of better gun being avaible). But dont get too relaxed - most of things on this planet seems to be made to be human-killers and death can me quick and/or painful :3Ii expect ppl crying in few days about dying and respawning at start as annoying feature - even thought u can make and bind urself to better cryopods (respawn facility) to get respawn-at-dying-place points on time bases - cryorods.Btw - game has no tutorial, outside window with knowledge - CODEX - about thing you find/unlocked and flying laser shark, which will teach you some basics. Why? - well, for world's optimisation and....more hilariously, some ppl failed to finish tutorial or even simply passed by w/o learning and then stormed forum/reviews with questions tutorial had answer on :3Really, so far it's not very hard to understand a game.Those confused by low % of positive rewievs - most of negatives are made by those, who didnt bother to lurking around about game or didnt play enough (under 10hours - not even worth looking at), as well as people wanting Starbound clone.For more detailed comparison of EoS/Starbound/Terraria/etc visit http://steamcommunity.com/app/238240/discussions/0/540735426074163826/Pros:- interactions with developers - they do respond within a day (depending on timeline of yours) and they're friendly. Seriously, they even used to run server to play with players and they do take in account suggestions of players about what to implement;- helpful people;- Quite big sandbox-generated world - can travel to new places, see alot monsters and kill them. 3 biomes with different flora, fauna - so you will not see all the same things for whole game.- build your base, place facilities and decorate at your taste (alot stuff will be coming, thought even now you can spend few hours decorating);- rpg-oriented - alot stuff to research, player-style-oriented armor sets and kits;- quite nice amount of armors (3 trees: fighter, explorer, builder - all with unique and useful bonuses), weapons (phase - unlimited ammo and weak strikes, projectiles - limited powerful crafted ammo, energy - not present yet) and facilities to place;- SCI-FI setting;- some humorous moments;- Pretty nice graphics;Cons:- only English as supported language atm;- no way to pause game (thought placing command node and teleporting to command center placed in your haven saves the day);- a bit hard to set multiplayer server - there is a complete How-To guide on forum thought;- not exatly your average YOBA in terms of game's info - well, Codex, npcs and your brain should be enough to figure out the game (at least many questions are answered on forum since long ago)neutral:- farming - as in any rpg of such type, you gonna need to get resources for ur stuff, thpught getting most of resources isnt hard during traveling - just keep your eyes open. If playing solo - one might consider getting builder sets for quicker digging;- 2d game - yep, no realistic 3D graphics (like in 60-usd games);- not newbie-friendly in some terms (tutorial thing explained above), since not everything is explained, chewed for you and put in your mouth with spoon. If you run into trouble - i'm currently making game's guide:


Edge of Space almost full guide 
A Guide for Edge of Space
By: Ersatz Soul

			It's my first guide, so don`t be to harsh on me Since alot players are asking questions, in this guide i'll try to cover both basics and advanced things.		


 feel free to open it. If reading forum and guide still left you with question - feel free to ask me.- more multiplayer-oriented, than singleplayer game (noone stops from playing alone thought. Truth to be told, i donno about other simular games and their MP/SP orientation)state of game:- 3 biomes present and filled (with mobs, plants, events and stuff).- dungeons - instances to find some specific resources and bosses.- animal mounts and vehicles;- multiplayer (thought require to have someone hosting server);- guns (3 trees) and melee, armors (3 different trees w different type of bonuses), upgrades, facilities and stuff in quite nice amounts;- NPCs - somewhat funny bunch;- terrafroming is present))- achievements.- trading cards :3

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Game design is one of those things that, when done really well, goes almost unnoticed. Sadly, this is the one area where Edge of Space really fails to deliver. The art isn't bad, the worlds are imaginative, and some aspects of gameplay are actually very fun! Tearing through rock with a high-powered mining lazer feels great. Unfortunately, these high points are all brought down by clumsily implemented features that are frustrating and poorly explained. A lot of things nagged at me during the 12-or-so hours I spent trying to enjoy Edge of Space, but I'll focus on the worst: dungeons.At a certain point in the game, progression through the tech-tree is halted by materials that can only be obtained from a dungeon. No problem! Except the dungeons are awful. The freedom of your jetpack and mining laser are stripped from you, and you're forced to clumsily hop along through some kind of half-baked platformer full of dark, confusing, repetitive rooms. Exploring the rest of the dungeon after going down a dead-end branch involves slowly backtracking through rooms that are even harder to navigate in reverse. It's so tedious that it's easier to just die so that you can start again from the top. The drop-rate for those materials you need is abysmal to boot. Just terrible all-around.

number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												I actually enjoyed this game when it was in Early Access. I felt it had a lot of potential. To be honest, this and Darkout (another failed "sandbox-style" game) are the games that got me interested in the genre.But now, the game has been released from Early Access incomplete - there is no story to speak of, some NPC quests are still broken, some recipes are still broken, overall balance is lacking, some deep biomes/strata are broken/bugged/non-functional, and the game is poorly optimized. It should have never left Early Access.Add on to that, there has been no news on the game in six months (as of this posting), said news being a vague-yet-ominous post about a future announcement yet to materialize, the official game page has turned into a GoDaddy parking page, and the developer has reportedly closed doors.I wanted to believe in this game, for Laser-Guided Flying Space Sharks with Human Teeth if nothing else, but in this state, unfinished and apparently abandoned, I cannot recommend it to anybody.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								The game has a lot of potential, it's future looks brighter, but it makes no difference to the current state of the game. I'll put it simply; the game is complicated, too complicated. Refining materials is a key element to the game, and if you refine the same ore at different times chances are you'll get 2 random named metals that both cannot be used at once. The whole combat system is broken, along with it's promises of great intergalactic travel or something like that. Being this  complicated, you would assume a bussling wiki? Yeah, no. It's a regular wiki with stubs for LITERALLY every topic. Want to know a full list of tools? Yah, no-one has submitted an entry. The game doesn't have a functioning wiki, which is vital to a complex game that explains jack♥♥♥♥♥♥to you. This isn't even in beta. Even if these "Features" do exist (And I am pretty sure they do) almost no-one will have the attention span to slowly dig tonnes of crap, build high level armor and get down to get to these places. It's boring and repetative.I'm going to be honest. I bought this game thinking it was starbound. The only reason why I've "gotten into it" is because I wasted my money and can't get it back. Words are thrown around about this game, "Terraria Clone", and the like, but the one word I don't want thrown around is the word "complete". Check the global achievments. The only one is for starting the game, and only 13 percent have even touched the game. It needs a re-vamp, because I like it; enough to be sad if it does this badly.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a review in it's current state.I understand this game is still in beta, but in it's current state I'm not a fan. I definitely see the potential of this game and can forsee it being a really fun and addictive game like Terraria. Right now it's just frustrating. Especially since this game has been out in beta for over a year and the feel hasn't changed. It's sad when 3 of my friends and I can't stand to play this more than an hour every 3-4 months we try it.Many items that you find early in game have absolutely 0 use or in the item details it shows "Will be updated in the future" or some nonsense. The inventory feels clunky and can be buggy when swapping things in and out of your actionbars.For those of you who played Terraria, if you enjoyed the helper dude being there to somewhat guide you in the right direction you're going to have a harder time. The beginning gives you a brief sense of direction but then it's gone. To understand what a lot of things do, you must either spend lots of time trying to figure it out on your own or look it up on the wiki.While I feel games do need to have a little but of challenge in them, I'm not sure the start of this game goes in the right direction with that. Your mining tool is painfully slow. Your starting weapon is painfully weak. Materials needed to upgrade anything are way high. You also have lives in this game. So as you're digging down trying to find some sort of material you need to make an item you have no clue what it does, you come across some crabs that take 15 shots to kill with your weak gun and they kill you. You've spent 20 minutes digging, lost a life, and still have 0 of the material you need.The soundtrack is nice. Which is one thing I expected after playing Terraria and Starbound. Visuals look good for the most part. The gameplay just has a long way to go until I feel it will be fun.If you want a new Terraria style game, go pick up starbound instead. You'll be completely satisfied! Maybe in another year I can say the same about this.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Bought this game since it first appeared in Early Acess. Played it on and off until they announced an official release date, so let's get to the details and where this game fell apart.  First, for a space exploration/craft game it's mostly about just digging down....down down and only down. The crafting menu is categorized but it's still very messy and not pretty. Explanations on how switches work with power are also few and far between so you're going to have to do your own troubleshooting for a while. There is a variety of weapons, i won't deny that, but in terms of USEFUL weapons there are only a few types which work well. So you can basically ignore all the melee and energy fueled weapons, stick to the projectile and plasma weapons. But the worst part of this game is the enemies...their hitboxes are really funky, and to make matters worse the hurt boxes on your weapons are terrible as well. So mixing hard to hit enemies with weapons that are hard to aim...great. And the movement of the enemies is particularly annoying and random. Otherwise I applaud its effort to be different but this game feels poorly done to me.

Early Access Review
								Love this art style for sure and how helpful and friendly the dev team is. I play this game solo and really don't have any plans to play MP. I do enjoy the idea that all the fighting (for now) is with guns rather than melee. It is hard to get used to because enemies are smaller and fast but you get better over time. The game itself has just had a UI overhaul and progression is being changed up right now. I have no fear that this game will turn out to be bad in any way. The team listens to us and makes great decisions on their own as well. I have been part of some rough early access games (Warz :( , The Stomping Land :((  and Starbound :-\ ) so I have had my share of ups and downs. Edge of Space has kept me even, while I want the game to be done I am not demanding them. I know they are working on everything and it will be great no matter what. I originally came to this game because Starbound was updated and it killed a connection to a mod that made the game fun. (survivalist mod) Obviously starbound is so easy, no challenge at all. This game is actually much harder and makes you feel the need to be careful and play safe at times. Give Edge of Space a try some time or just keep it in mind and watch for updates!

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I was skeptical about this game when I first looked into it, the reviews on steam seems to have a really hit and miss feel to the game.  Since the game was on sale I decided to take a chance with it since I'm really drawn to the artstyle and general concept of the game itself.  I'm actually surprised that I liked the game as much as I do since I played Starbound before and it didn't really impress me as much as EoS does.A few things I do have to mention though is that, yes the tutorial isn't that informative but since a lot of people have played games such as Starbound or Terraria and Eos is in the same genre, a lot of the functions and basics are the same as well.Another thing is the lack of any active server searching function within the client, as far as I know of right now, servers are spread through word of mouth or in forum posts, but most of the big servers have been shut down already so there isn't a huge population in multiplayer that anyone can just jump in (Again, I may be wrong since I've only been playing the game for a little bit)Last thing I really wanna recommend to anyone thinking about playing the game is to really stick with it during the beginning, because things are slow and gathering seems like a drag, but once you start getting into the game more, you'll find that Eos has a lot of depth, potential, and it's own personality that separates this game from the other games in the same genre.  Seriously though, you can build a giant mech suit, what more do you need to convince you to buy this game?

number of helpful: 27 of 45 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit for 1.0 release : Been super hyped for this and now that it's actually out, it didn't disappoint.Tldr; Buy the game. Best case scenario you love it and have a new game to play. Worst case scenario, you find out it's not for you and you can just get a refund.Pros : Toooooooooons of contentA much needed optimization (went from 25-30 to 60fps)Easy to set up multiplayer as long as you know what you're doing3 seperate tech trees for armor and 3 seperate tech trees for guns as well as a tech tree for melee.Every tech tree has 15 layers/ranksArmor looks unique and prettyIntroduction of nests that can be taken over (nice challenge at the start of the game)3 bosses already in the game with more planned for the futureSound effects sound great, especially for the weaponsOverhaul of world generation. No longer are titanium, ice, and other ores rare in the first phase of the game. Game promotes a natural progresion in that exploring, digging, and fighting will all give you exp you can put towards tech I really really like this soundtrack (thanks, Lori)Different types of weapons feel different. Phase are weak but infinite weapons, projectile are strong but very limited, and energy are strong but require you to decide between using them or using your jetpack since they both use the same energy.Wide range of enemies and great for people who like making very technical bases (with logic gates implemented and an easy to use power system)Funny loading screens to help pass the tedious but necessary parts of every gameCons :Weapons are a little hard to get used to and are sometimes hit and miss. Like with any game release, it has its fair share of bugsAfter the tutorial with Fineous, it's kinda hard to know what to do nextOver abuncdence of snails and frogs can get annoying.Game doesn't feel as grindy as other people make it out to be. I don't find it to be too gindy since there's always a lot of things to do.Finished playing Terraria with a friend and needed a similar game to play. With Gaben's infinite knowledge, steam recommended this game. After looking around and reading reviews for a few days I can honestly say I do not regret buying this a bit. Game felt grindy but with the new system being implemented, that's going to change completely. The devs are active and actually pay attention to people's positive AND negative reviews and react positively to both (Unlike starbound...). The reviews on the developers played a huge part in my purchase and I'll be buying a copy for my friend in the near future (aka the steam sale). Couldn't recommend enough.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												For version 1.0.3Though the developers have released this from Early Access, it really should not have been.  First off, the bugs:  missing image assets  broken dialog trees/subquests  spelling mistakes  crafting window which gets laggier and laggier each time it's opened.  constant shaking of the screen when left unattended for long enough (in my case, once to answer a phone call and another to deal with a someone at the door).Beyond the bugs, the content of the game itself is surprisingly sparse.  You just constantly descend without much incentive to explore other than to discover upgrade stations.  You can also find NPCs and get their subquests, but even if those subquests aren't broken there's no real payoff for completing them.At its current level, the amount of active development and polish needed before this would be worthwhile is probably measured in months, not days or weeks.  I'd check back in six months to a year to see if things have gotten better or if the move out of Early Access is an indication that the dev team is abandoning the game and so might as well call it done.

Early Access Review
								This game should be a repleacement for Terraria or atleast a comparable thing. Unfortunetaly it is still in phase of development. After completing few startup things (gathering resources, protecting robots) it is coming to a point where You are bored because You can't find anything new (~15 hours) or it gives You a head punch with difficulty level that is too hight (in the game events like 15 mobs spawning and shooting at You light bulbs that is extreamly hard to avoid). I do not recommend this game because sometimes recipes are not finished and in some points it is not intuitive (that is very important thing). Good thing would be adding some kind of direct portals (that You could craft on place with quite huge ammount of resources) to epic boss battles which would give You either uncommon/rare loot or resources that would be only available to drop out of this boss.Things that could be usefull:1. More boss fight (and except needed gear, also tactic required) + rare epic loot 1 in 100 or 1000 to drop2. More special monsters that grant a nice reward3. Combo shoots that gives a player sense of power (for example charging power for killing monsters and than when You want You can unleash it upon all foes dealing massive damage)My opinion:For now it is not as good as expected, however it offers creation of own server that You could play co-op/multiplayer. This game could use some features that will make it better and 12 Euro is a bit too epensive (but it's standard for most of steam games).

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Edge of Space pits you against the environment as you progress downward as opposed to side by side.   You gradualy start to encounter bigger badder challanges that not only require you to be well prepaired equiptment wise, but it also requires you to bring more advanced tools.   The versatility in Edge of Space's tools seperates it from alot of other sandbox games because you can choose to have a longer, less powerful range, or a shorter more powerful version of your tools.   This gives you options to work with.The armor sets also differnt from other games in the aspect that they are not necissarly combat focused.   Instead of Ranger, Mage, Melee, you get  Builder, Explorer, Fighter.  Each armor catering to a particular task rather then a weapon role.  All items are created from crafting data of a specific sub catagory in crafting, so you can specialize and focus on one area at a time rather then pooling all of your science (aka accumulative xp pool ) into everything at once.Edge of Space also offers a challange factor with it's dungeons.  It disables things like jet packs and grappling hooks and building so that you can not cheese the boses for easy wins.   This should give you an idea of how the game plays out and how it differs from other games of it's kind.*Feb 25, 2015* Development Stage: Early AccessEarly Access Compitence Rateing:  9/10  -  Things were bumpy at first for what ever reasons, but things turned around quickly.   The developers never gave up despite the road bumps and updates are comeing in frequantly.   Edge of Space is a very good example of Early Access done right.Exploration:  9/10 -  The environment can be dangerous, there's danger around every corner and you need to prepair accordingly.    There are events and outposts that keep you busy and though it is currently in an infant state of things, I can see how the world will gradualy become more and more full as time advances.Crafting: 8/10 -  Crafting is based on xp and tends to get a bit grindy, but it's quite rewarding once you unlock new things.Game Controls:   8/10  -  Some obvious bugs are still around, but it will not hinder the game experince too much.   Jetpacks can also go wildly out of control and some of the grapple mechanics can send your character bouncing about.Game Play: 8/10  -  I suspect the game will greatly improve with time, but at the moment there is a limited amount of content to keep you busy, so the game becomes a bit grindy.   Again, I suspect this will change greatly in the near future.Music:  9/10  -  The music is very fitting for the game and quite immersive.Graphics: 8/10 -  It's gritty and retro, but also very fitting for the game style.  Some of the texture look weird, but it's a fair representation of what it is conveying.Newbie Friendly:  7/10 - Newbies will catch on eventualy, but the learning curve is a bit harsh.  But in a good way.   It is suggested to have some platformer experince before attempting Edge of Space.  Newer generation gamers may have trouble where as older generation gamers will have little trouble with landing platforms and timeing jumps.Community and Moderators: 9/10 -  Very few fights, healthy interactions.   Strong communication, very good staff members.  Moderation is fair and efficent and well handled.Developers:  10/10 -  Very approachable developers, they are always happy to answer questions.   They have sense of humor and are reasonable people.   Very good company to invest your faith and funds into.TL:DR Version:Is it worth it:  YES!

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												This game has come a long way since when it started in Early Access.  It is now the first 1.0 'Official Release'as of last week.  I'm a thumbs up but if you read my full review you'll see below what can be impoved on as well.I've stuck with this game and I still enjoy it.  It is a crafting, exploring game in 2D... but it's in space!  And if you like space games that are open world and exploritory, I think you'll find this one not to like.  The are lots of materials to search for, interesting knowledge tree to work towards for crafting new gadgets and gizmos, and plenty of creepy monsters and weird vegetation to learn about.  So if you like figuring out the unknown, you'll like this.  It's kinda like Terraria, Metroid, and Star Trek blended together, with a dash of Avatar but something kinda unique too.The Edge of Space development team says they will keep improving this game post release and I hope they do.3 things which need some immediate attention by the development team include:-  The game engine processes data and movement too slowly compared to other games in this genre.  The result is that movement is slow and battle can be clunky for game play.  I don't think this is my processors' or video card's fault as I play similiar games with even better graphics and gameplay, without so much latency.  Maybe the coding could be tighter / more real time.  Seems like a lot of processor overhead going on.- The opening movie is pretty untelling still.  It's better now that it's 1.0 but this is supposed to be the intro to the adventure.  The user doesn't get a good sense of what the background story is and where they fit in.  And what's with the other 3 organizations with different symbols?  Are they competitors or allies?  Are they the Ark Corp council?  Are they the ones who blew up our ship or was it an alien war?  It's hard to tell and it shouldn't be.-  The addition of Fineous the Shark has helped teach new players (and older ones) what the controls and game mechanics are.  It could be a little more obvious though.  Probably the best way is to make sure the Codex has more content and the user knows right away that this is their one stop shop for learning about their new world, and how and what an agent of Ark Corp is supposed to do and try to acheive.  Some more work on the goals of the game are needed.  The Codex should be like our 'Hitchhikers Guild to the Galaxy'; everything you need to know when you thunk on a new planet in a Cryopod without any friends or contact with where you blasted off from, after a long cryo-frozen nap. I like the sense of humour though so far; keep that going.That's my thoughts on this game so far.  I recommend, as long as you don't expect perfection just yet but I think it's worth supporting and playing.  It's fun and interesting to explore.This Review was written Sept. 20, 2015.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Normally I don't do early access reviews. Partly because early access is really about development, not playing (and reviewing) a finished product. Partly because everything is in too much flux for the review to be valid for long.Mostly because I'm too lazy to write reviews for finished games, let alone one still in alpha/beta.But I'll make an exception here, because even in it's current incomplete state, it is already one of my favorite games. It's also a fine example of what early access should be: An engaged development team that listens to feedback, works with the community, and simply wants to deliver a great experience to the people who buy their product. From an investment standpoint (which is how early access should be approached IMHO), this is exactly the type of product I'd want to back. The fact they're making a game I want to play makes it even better.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edge Of Space is a really well made side-scroller/sandbox game, it is still an early access game but in the future I think it will be extremely sucsessful since it is only beta. EoS has a really good character customization layout, and for a beta game, it has a lot of variaty and choice, it even has 'Deal With It' sunglasses!! EoS is a Single-Player and Multi-Player game, which is very impressive since it is only beta. It does make sense how EoS is such a well-made game, the developers of EoS have also made some really sucsessful Side-Scroller/Sandbox games e.g. terraria, an extremely sucsessful game and has many fans, and is what brought me to that kind of genre of game, so if the devs have made an extremely sucsessful game like Terraria, then EoS has quite a high chance of being really sucsessful game, and it even has the chance to become even more sucsessful than Terraria itself! When you start the game there is a tutorial in your spaceship which gives you objectives to show you how the game works, and gives you items which you need when you go to the surface of the planet you are on, so far I have seen three lifeforms, which i will not spoil to everyone, you should buy the game to see everything for yourself. The crafting interface is really cool as you can select  what you want to make, then instead of going into your Inventory you can click on select on the material you need, then it shows you how much you have in your inventory and how much you need. Overall i think that when EoS is at its Prime, It could me the most sucsessful game of that genre.9.999999999999999999999999999999999999999 / 10

Early Access Review

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update  7/15/14:  Do keep in mind this game is far from done and my review below didn't have enough time in to see how far along it was.  The timer has a few days till the next update so I'll update this then but I have exhausted about all i can do in its current state in a few days time.  I do think it had more that is currently being rewritten that may be blocking me but don't expect the complete experience of a game like terraria yet but what is here is great and I'm happy to of supported this game early.  I could build more, explore for more upgrade capsules and such (and I may) but recipes are limited, just a warning.Only 6 hours in so far but I like what I've seen.  This and starbound are apparently the 2 biggest games like this getting made right now (darkout deserves mention here since it could easily be the best if it gets more love) and with all the negative stuff I have read about starbound and the dev's attitude in general, edge was the one I chose.  Its fresh and new to me so I can't really critique it properly until I get to endgame to see how wiring and engineering possabilities stack up to terraria and have a better feel of the progression and what exactly is available  The fact that i have schamatics for various relays, switches and 'and gate' 'or gate' and 'not gate' makes me very happy even though I don't know if its possible to use them yet.  One thing I can say is that it will get enough time out of me to, at least, pay for the game in my eyes.  This won't be one of those many games on my list with 1.5 hours played and never touched again.  I'm more of a mechanics style gamer style game but I can already tell it has a ton of customization to those that like to decorate with TV's and such for whatever reason in the places they build.  I do appriciate the more advanced stats this has like various resistances and damage types.  Time will tell how it stacks up with terraria but I can't see any reason not to grab this if you want a new terraria experience to relax with at the end of the day.  It also has timers to show when updates are coming so thats nice and its kind of cool being in on the development cycle since I didn't play terraria till it was finished.  This way I get to see new stuff added and get ot be excited about it as it grows and expands.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #54 - Edge of SpaceYou'll get an immediate sense of the quirky writing in Edge of Space as you start by having a conversation with a talking shark.  There isn't that much of a story to tell, just that your spaceship crashed and now you are stranded on a planet.  The writing is definitely tongue-in-cheek.I liked how the game began, and appreciated that it wasn't too difficult to begin with.  Although I do wish they had explained some things a little better.  The game includes a "tutorial video" that I felt was kind of a shortcut, as opposed to just better integrating a tutorial into the game.  Still, the first set of quests you get involve gathering various components to then craft into items, which is a pretty major part of the gameplay.I wish the controls were better.  I found mining to be frustrating at times.  You use a mining pick that you aim with your mouse.  But the aim is weird at times.  I kept wanting to just point my mouse cursor at a block to mine.  But the aim is actually based on the position of your cursor relative to a point on your body in order to determine direction.  This means sometimes, even when your mouse cursor is on a block, the aim is actually causing the laser to hit a different block.  It's a minor annoyance but mining is such a major part of the gameplay that it definitely adds up.If you've played Terraria, then you'll pretty much know exactly what to expect here.  It's pretty hard not to consider this game a knock off.  There are some minor differences with crafting, like the way you can use different items to fill a recipe.  But as a whole the gameplay feels extremely familiar.   I don't hold it against Edge of Space for being a knock off, but when you're borrowing from another game, you should at least make some notable improvements.  And it really doesn't feel that way.  And when you add the fact that Terraria is cheaper ($14.99 vs. $9.99 regular prices), I really can't recommend this game unless you've just played Terraria to death and want to scratch that itch with a different game.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								What we have here is Edge of Space. Edge of space is a really interesting game, it plays differently from Terraria and starbound, it's truly a breath of fresh air for the genre. The weapon focus is more on guns at the moment, although they told me they are to add melee weapons in at a future time. As for graphics, the graphics are amazing and have a interesting feel, actually kinda throws me back to the days of the SNES, kinda breaking away from that pixel feel but also sticking to it. As for the music the music makes me feel a lot of things it's ambient and interesting it's kinda sad but in a good way. Point is, It's a fun game really, the level design is interesting and there are many canverns and areas to explore. The game is challenging as a rhino trying to climb a tree made of tomato skin, it takes some getting used to. It's a little slow at first but once you figure it out, it's awesome. On that note be sure to check out the tutorial and actually PAY ATTENTION to the words it says, there are quite a few giggles in the script too. Just pay attention and get immersed in the atomsphere and you will fall in love with this game as I did. This by the way, is coming from a terraria/starbound veteren. So purchase it and give the devs all your money as they're a fantastic bunch. 10/10 'nuff said. Also did I mention LAZER SHARKS.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Edge of Space recently came out of Early Aceess, can i just start off by saying that this is a brilliant start. In an industry where developers leave their game to die with no content and sparawling fans: "cough, cough" DayZ.Edge of space is a 2D, Openworld Adventure game. The main story goes like this, You were in cryogenic sleep when your ship broke down, so you wake up and you go exploring the planet beneith you for recourses, not too shabby for a starting story. The story continues with a character named Rufus who is an interesting character to say the least. I wont spoil any more but i doubt you were looking at this game for its story. You want to know about the gameplay, the exploration. Well im glad to say that it's awsome. The game has many simularities to Terraria and Starbound but it improves on these things and adds more to them. For example in Terraria you have your ranks of gear going from a wooden sword to a Gold sword going to a Lights Bane. In Edge of Space, you have sooo many more options mainly because you have to earn xp to unlock new items which is awsome because you dont grind xp by killing mobs (well you can but there is a more enjoyable way to do it) you get xp for mining ore and it basically rewards you for exploring. You will also encounter these things called "nests" which you can explore and destroy for even more xp, which is cool. You also have your character skill trees, but when i say skill trees i dont mean like the stealth, the tank ect. I mean you specialise in what your doing. For example i could get builders armour, if i was interested in building stuff in the game, this would neglect the mob damage and illiminate annoyances that might stop you from building. There is a large range of things to makr that you actually want to get unlike other games where they have you craft random crap just so you can continue with the story, Edge of space doesnt do that, instead they let you build mechs, pets, new weapons and badass jetpacks. These arnt just useless vanity items they do infact effect the way you play and make it more enjoyable. So far im loving this game too pieces, being a big fan of Terraria and Starbound helped i guess, but i'd honestly reccomend it to anyone who loves open world exploration games as there is stuff to find and tonnes of things to make, there is no doubt a wealth of content here.....which is really great! :)Want a review that you can listen and see? Check mine out on the Youtube's:

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hello readers!Let's get the obvious out the of the way: it's in Beta. There will be changes. There are glitches. Boo-hoo. Pros: It's engaging, especially compared to the garden variety of miners and crafters out there. There is a multifaceted approach to crafting that requires both raw materials and the know-how of a specific skill to be able to craft. Science Points (SP) are awarded for everything - killing baddies to laser-punching dirt - and are used for increasing skill levels in broad categories such as Base Construction (BUILD BIGGER CHESTS!) to Utilities (MAKE STRONGER LAZERBEAM!) to Consumables (WHO NEEDS CRYORODS ANYWAYS?). Once your skill level is increased you can then craft a better item for yourself! Enough on crafting.. Enemies! They're gorgeous! They're varied! They kick my♥♥♥♥♥=( They have weaknesses that make it an engaging combat game beyond point-and-click. Angles of attack, parabolic arcs, and reload times all need to be taken into consideration when fighting the local floral and fauna. Build stronger weapons! Fight bigger baddies! Get more SP! Build Data from SP into building better weapons! Rinse - repeat - pwn. Dungeons!  Just when you think you've found it all - suddenly you're platforming through a mega-dungeon fighting off mechanical brains with well-timed plasma rifle shots! Loot Loot Loot Loot. More dungeons!  Did you know penguins like pre-marital sex and Daft Punk? Play this game to find out why. They're promiscious. And deadly. More Loot! Why do I need all these brain stems? SCIENCE!Cons: It's in Beta. Lighting sometimes ♥♥♥♥♥ itself - sometimes there's no shadows at all! Hitboxes have been off before - but appear to have been patched. Nothing gamebreaking that I've run into with my 38 hours. 1/2 the world isn't filled in yet - but I'm sure it will be amazing when it is! There's more than enough to explore as is. The only gripe I have is lack of map - but it is a planned implementation, and I'm sure will be here soon. It's a large and confusing world - even with teleportation available you still get your♥♥♥♥♥lost. OVERALL GRADE:WOULD BUY AGAIN / 10 I give it a solid 8.5 - with the possibility to be a 9 or even 10 when all the bugs are worked out and content is added. The time I have put into  it should say enough. As a fan of Minecraft and Terraria - both Vanilla - the Edge of Space more than meets my expectations and is my current crack.

content:

Early Access Review
								It's the love child of Terraria and Contra. If you dig the suvival crafting genre you owe it to yourself to try this game out. It's by no means perfect with its occasional bugs and hiccups; but if you can get past its flaws it's a wonderful experience.Edge of Space has a killer soundtrack (reminiscent of Mass Effect), it has RPG elements in it that make it unique in the genre, and it's only gonna improve more.So, as it stands, I'd give the game a 6.7 out of 10. Not because it's bad, but because it's more of a sugar rush experience due to the game not having all of its intended content.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												well ive spent about 20 hours on this game and i can say that at this point the game is just not worth playing anymore. Exploring: its pretty standard, you go out find monsteres and stuff and you need to kill them to get their materials. most are nutral, some aren't. they have little zones with events like "kill the zombies", "kill the crabs, "Save an NPC" which are fun but super short, like done in 1 min and thats it" Building: building is pretty similar to other games of its like. you dont need as many as other games from what i can tell. getting new building recipes is pretty unique. you get XP for everything you do, and you trade in that xp for new teirs of items. Fighting: the fighting was pretty standard, thir weapons and teir systems are so annoying that finding the right weapons was just a chore. it doesn't say what the possible damage of the weapons are you just have to build them and hope it was worth the materials. mining: its pretty standared, nothing special. im sure it might get better later on, but ill never find out. but within the first few levels of you mining laser, it was pretty standard. Organization: their teir system wasn't done well AT ALL. i only got about half way through it and i found myself getting frustrated when trying to find stuff. like they have mark1weapons and forward, and if you need a mark1weapon you can't just search "mark1weapon, you need to click on each weapon and see what kind it is, got really annoying. there are some items that are broken in this game that you can't get, but im sure they will fix it in the future but for now it makes it impossible to get any of those items. Dungeons: these just suck... like hard, they tried to make them a cool platform area, but they aren't they just suck and are annoying as all hell, and when you die you have to start from the beginning and fight your way back to where you were at. and if you wanted to get all the material you need from these dungeons you have to spend hours and hours in them. its just not fun. then there is another dungeon where its a boss one and its ♥♥♥♥ing impossible, i barely did any damage and died almost imediatly, and icouldn't build anything else untill i got those materials from thsi dungeon. (there might have been stuff that i could have built but there was no ♥♥♥♥nig way to figure out what i needed to maybe beat him, the organizaion of items in this game are ♥♥♥♥ing BAD. there might have been items to help me, but damned if i could find them.)all in all this game still has a long way to go and if you don't mind dealing with a game that has alot of work ahead of it, then have fun, but i for one stopped having funa round the 10hour mark and was just hoping it would get less frustrating, and it didn't 20 hours in and im done, im just interested in anything else this game has to offer, it seems like the further i go the more problems there are. they need to stop adding things to this game and fix the problems at hand.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												The game is out of Early Access now and I've played what I consider to be the majority of the content in the game, so I'm updating my review.This game's pretty good and I do recommend it for a good 20 hours of playtime.Pros:Scifi setting is niceGoofy humour is good and prevalent throughout the game if you're into that kind of thingGame runs smooth for me and I've encountered few bugs since coming out of early accessA lot of different blocks and placeables for building basesA lot of different items and armoursDungeons are a lot of funMusic is great and matches the moodNPCs that give questsEasy to fast travel between basesCons:Nothing to really do in the 3rd biome but grind for materials to build end game gear.  Also, there doesn't appear to be a dungeon in the 3rd biomeLight radius is small (spamming torches helps but that's just annoying)Weapons never really get powerful, even the Death Dealer takes multiple hits on spike balls (personal con, I like to feel powerful when I get to the end of a game)Still a lot of stuff that feels unfinished (many items share sprites, no dungeon in 3rd biome)I didn't try multiplayer but it sounds like it takes quite a bit of work to set up a server and to get people to joinThey are still working on the game, but at a much slower pace.  I hope they make another game because I have enjoyed Edge of Space for what it is and I would like to see something new using what they have learned developing this game.OLD REVIEW:I would recommend the game at the stage it is currently at if they sold it as a finished game.  So, the fact that they are still working on it and improving it all the time makes it an easy recommendation.  The devs are very active in the forums and constantly updating the game.  One of the devs even broadcasts on twitch sometimes while wearing a shark suit.  This game has come a long way from its original early access release and is going to go a lot farther.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Those who are willing to put in the time to explore the world of Edge of space will find a colossal amount of content just waiting to be discovered and enjoyed. The sheer variety of weapons, deployables, pets, mounts, materials, dungeons, bosses etc is impressive, and although there are some obvious similarities to Terraria for instance, it is in fact a very different game. I would definitely recommend trying to find someone else who you can play with though, as it does enhance the experience a lot.There is a sort of tutorial in the form of a friendly laser shark who asks you to do a few short quests to get you used to the basic mechanics of the game, but the rest is mostly left up to you to figure out, (there are instructions on how to do everything if you dig in the menu) and so a degree of effort is required in order to get into the real meat of the content. Once you do however, you'll realise just how much there is to do and discover.Edge of space is very colourful and is graphically the equivalent of eating too many packets of Skittles in one sitting, the pallette is well chosen and easy on the eye, the art style is great, and everything stands out. Some players have complained about the lighting system but personally I haven't had any problems with it. The music is great, very relaxing and suits the mood well. The best thing however is the splendidly warped sense of humour that the developers obviously have and that comes across not only in the design of the world but in many of the descriptions and explanations that are there to be read if you take the time (and I recommend that you do)Gameplay is a lot of fun and some of the weapons in particular are extremely satisfying to use. I know I have only just started to scratch the surface but already I am enjoying flying around on a net full of jellyfish with a small glowing fox creature following me around and helping to light my journey into the planet's extensive cave systems.In summary, if you like randomly generated 2D exploration games with crazy amounts of content and are willing to put in the time and effort required to get through the initial learning stages, then you will get very good value from Edge of space, even more if you can find someone else to team up with.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Firstly, the combat is annoying and clunky, especially when all the enemies are darting around erratically making it infuriating to try and hit them; and when you do eventually land a shot, the enemy (in the first zone, less than 20 minutes in) is totally immune to your weapon, and firing back homing explosives which are very had to evade or shoot down. The AI is clairvoyant, always knowing where to aim at any moment, and the explosive weapon of one of the first three enemies you will face can break large holes into your base, allowing the rest to hit you directly, killing a player obscenely quickly. Secondly, the crafting is on a tech tree, requiring spelunking with useless tier-1 equipment to try to unlock tier-2 and so on, sadly, the depth you can reach is restricted, and a player will often never find anything before death forces them to their respawn point. The crafting is clunky and difficult, the UI is a battle to navigate with almost no quick access to the comically named "hotbar", and the tutorial is laughably incomplete. I bought this game believing I was buying into alpha software, and it felt like that, in mid-beta. The gameplay feels confused, torn between rogue-lite and Terraria-esque sidescrolling sandbox. Enemy variety is good, and the art style is unique and appealing, but the gameplay needs severe work. Avoid buying this title for full price, if you must buy it at all.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dear readers,I highly recommend this game, for a range of reasons. Perhaps most importantly, it is actually fun to play. I was initially dubious, since I am new to this genre of game, but, at the behest of a friend, I decided to give it a chance. I am very glad that I did, because flying (even for short distances) with a jet pack is all that I hoped it would be. I am still waiting for my real-life jet pack, universe! As I have never played this type of game before, it took me longer than the average person (I assume) to get through the tutorial. This was not, however, because the tutorial was not well-structured. In fact, it taught me all the basics I needed to know for this game without much superfluous fluff. I just had trouble with, for instance, remembering that I could jump down platforms. In addition, it is clear from the regular patches and updates that the developers are highly invested in making the game-play experience as bug-free and enjoyable as possible. This is the first early access game that I've purchased, and thanks to my positive experience with Edge of Space, I will be taking my chances on other early access games in the future. Best,CV

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
just a slice of my thoughts on the game by no means encompassing the wholeLast play through 31st August (about two weeks before release)::the good::This game is a hell of a lot of fun.  I have spent my time building a main base and burrowing fully enclosed tunnels outwards in every direction to mine the resources whilst being able to protect myself after sun down.  The monsters are punishingly difficult to control and kill hence my paranoia.  I found the difficulty initially frustrating but having conquered my local landscape I feel proud.  Any attempts to venture outside my zone of control are met with caution but as my confidence grows I am becoming more able to endure the relentless onslaught.::the bad::The science research tree is full of gaps.  For example, you will research tech level one in 'companions' and be able to craft your own floating torch but unlocking tech level two will garner you nothing.  Why not merge tech trees from different categories?  The intention may be to keep a certain clarity by separating 'companions' from 'weapons' from 'base building' but I am only just starting to understand that fact by writing down my thoughts.  At the time of playthrough the science tree just felt unfinished.  That is probably also symptomatic of early accesss games.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												REVISED 11/4/2015Being a follower via Early Access; I must say that this game has come a long way in its development, and I am quite happy with the launch result. The game runs smooth, the 2D graphics are amazing; I definitely love how the developers broke away from the typical pixel art you see in most games of the genre. What definitely makes me appreciate this game, is not only the quality of the visuals and the sound; but what makes it different from other games like Starbound or Terraria. That being said, it has its drawbacks; which are mainly peeves on mine as mentioned in the cons section.Pros:+ Exceptional 2D artwork and visuals, definitely shines brighter than others of its genre.+ Nice and fitting contemporary Sci-fi theme.+ Biome diversity and abundance of interesting places to explore.+ The PIOS system which allows you to wire power to objects.+ Technology tree and research aspects are present.+ Nice crafting system. Uncertain:= The game feels grindy, but at the same time it prolongs the game.Cons:- The NPC's you get are really lame. You have a flying shark that sounds like a 5 year old, and a bunch of annoying furry "aliens". Really devs, couldn't you be more creative and make up some interesting sentient alien species?- Sometimes, there is an excessive amount of creature spawns. - Some creatures have a very obnoxious knockback.- There needs to be more biomes/content.Overall: If you like these kind of open-world, randomly generated 2D platform games; this is definitely for you.

content:
Posted: February 3
												I've had this game in my library for a while.  I bought it back when I was looking for a Terraria-esque game, and either Starbound wasn't out yet, or I hadn't discovered it.It seemed VERY promising at first.  So, I decided to put it on hold and come back once a few updates had been released for it.  Unfortunately, by the time I did come back...the developers had pretty much abandoned the game.Now, that's not the only problem - the other problem is that you gather resources too slowly; now, you could make that argument about Terraria or Starbound, but there's a difference: in those game, it's it was slow at first because you needed to update your tools; and over time, you upgraded your tools, reducing the time it takes to gather resources.  Not to mention that they gave you other stuff to do in the meantime, like quests, boss battles, or exploring dungeons.  Here, it's because the things you need to upgrade are too hard to find.  It takes WAY too long to make something like a house - in Terraria, you can have a simple house up by nightfall; in Starbound, it's a bit longer if you decide to build a base on a planet instead of your ship, but it's still completable in a reasonable amount of time; in this game? ...You'll be lucky if you're even done with a quarter of the house by that time.Even then, the other problem is that...well, once you get past the tutorial, it's empty.  There's nothing obvious for you to do.  This is because of the lack of an NPC to give you hints like in Terraria or a quest system like in Stardew Valley.  At that point, it feels like a 2D Version of No Man's Sky, minus the ability to go to other planets (to be fair though, at least this game doesn't cost nearly as much as NMS).It's a pity that this game is now abandonware, since it does have some good ideas - I like the power system idea, since it makes you plan out your base; also, the research system is a good idea in theory (although in execution, it fails).If the developers ever decide to pick this game back up and start updating it again, I might give it a second shot, but at the moment, I cannot recommend this game.If you're contemplating buying this game, I would suggest passing on it and instead picking up Terraria, which does the idea of a 2d Sandbox game a lot better (not to mention it's cheaper); but if the sci-fi element is a must for you, go for Starbound instead, since while the worlds in that game aren't as big as the worlds in this game, the rest of the content more than makes up for that.

Enemy Detecting: I cant tell an enemy from a friend, the next thing I know a tiny little bug incapacitated me. The game is spacey so why not add a techno enemy detector or something spacey? It would be nice to have done in those 28 days before the MEGA UPDATE!C. Objective: OK so in Terraria (Not related just thought this was a lot like it) you knew if your friends told you or not that you had to slay something and survive through the world. Well this game is very spacey and from what I have played this game needs an objective bad. VERY bad.Now here is a list of what I officially think of this very game! Trust me this should cover why I enjoy this game so much.Well I have to say the game has very good potential. And it has Terraria data so that is kind of exciting, if they do read this I hope they know that I am routing for them and hoping they prosper and flourish in their glory, they have made a master piece's outlining, now can they finish the painting and how that is my main question in this all. But it does not matter I enjoy the game and I think they will go good with it.FINAL RANKSACTION:5/10DESIGN: 7/10CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION: 7/10OPTIONAL OPTIONS:10/10 (OPEN WORLD OF OPTIONS!)IN GAME TECH:6/10PUT TOGETHER: 10/10 (LIKE BUILDING BLOCKS)OVERALL FUN: 6/10LAG: 10/10 (ANTI LAG POLICE)MASTER RANK: Spacey Space Space Of SPACE!YAY OR NAY?: YAY! :D

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Yeah, when this game was in EA it was a little rough around the edges, but it was still a game, which I can say is more than most can say at this point, but it's out and 1.0. Does it still have a few rough spots? Sure, but what game doesn't on initial release, but they are working hard on it, to fix what is going on, and are very connected with the community giving us regular updates on whats up.The game is built around the idea of exploration, terraforming and expansion. Each of which is handled very well.The experience system that has been added in replacing the old way of researching is MUCH better and a welcome addition, as is all the UI cleanup that has been done.One thing I love about this game is there is nothing you pick up that is completely worthless (except building structure tiles if you don't plan to build with them). You can use Dirt, Stone, Biomass, jelly, shark stuff, to make guns, armor, jetpacks, tools and ammo.The Game is deep, and has more content in it than I will ever have time to discover, but for those of you whom have enjoyed Terraria, Starbound and Crea this is a welcome addition to the collection.Like I said, it's not a perfect game, but it still a heck of a lot of fun, I'd give it a 8/10.(Also be very warry of the negative reviews, most were done while it was in EA and a lot has changed since then, or many have been posted since it went live, but they have 0.0 hours of play time since it has.)

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												I rarely review games, but this one is exceptional. Never mind the old negative reviews, as they were made way back when the game is still in Early Access, with lots of bugs. Now there are still bugs out there, but it has improved greatly.UP points:- Vast world (The first biome can easily as big as, if not bigger than, a Large map in Terraria);- Various quests, both main and side;- Interesting mechanism, both leveling and crafting;- Good sound effects;- Neat 2D graphic;DOWN points:- Bugs. Bugs! BUGS! There are a lot of bug fixes needed.- The menu is not actually scaled with windows' dimensions (i.e. you cannot create new character in 800x600, in-game UI is partly of screen, etc.);- The whole world is loaded in Unity so it will greatly drop you FPS on low-end PC;- Character control is poorly built: the character's arm is like a stick attached to the body, it cannot bend so it is really awkward in close-ranged action;- THERE IS NO HORIZONTAL INERTIA! There is vertical onertia, which mean it take time for you to speed up and slow down vertically. Horizontal: Nope. If you jetpack around and suddenly stop midair, you will drop straight down regardless of the initial speed.The bugs are not game-breaking and are being quickly fixed by the developers, so the UP points outweigh the DOWN points. Worth every cents I paid for it.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												If you are the type of person who is ok with having to remember on your own every detail of every inch of your world as you explore it, or are one of those people who can go exploring, end up in a running barrle, and die and know exactly how to get back to where you got by sheer accident than mayby you will like this game, for the rest of us I would say don't bother.  there is no in game world map, just a mini map.  it is entirely possible to fall through a series of areas and get completely lost.  there is no way to see where you were to get back there, you have to memorize everything, and for people like me that play once in a while you have no idea where everything was.  the nature of this games series of floating islands is what really inflames the problem.  unlike in games like terraria, a great deal of your time will be exploring by traveling through empty sky to see what is out there.  if you miscalculate your fall angle for the return trip you will miss what you found completely.  it is similar to trying to recreate a randm painting as a connect the dots puzzle when you can only see the dots your pencil tip is next to.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros - Good game so far. Playable. Hours of game play. Survival. Dont have to remember Crafting. Music. Can make anything with anything. You have the right to record EdgeOfSpace I believe. Has Mutiplayer. Tutorial on basics at the beginning. Achievements(Not a good thing to the game, just something I like about games).Cons - Needs bug fixes, and more ores to find early on. Crabs are too OP at the beginning. Run out of energy too fast. YOu dont regain Energy as fast as you loose it. Everything wants to kill you. No tutorial on how to make Energy work with the doors or CommandCenter(which i believe will be added?). No trading Cards(Not a downside, just something most steam games have, which I believe this game will have shortly later).Personal Review - Ive only had this game for 1-2 days, but I can tell you, this game is a great game and has a lot of potential for a early access game. Look forward to the updates and how it will improve to be a better game than what it is now. I strongly recomend this game if you are looking for a game like Terraria and/or Starbound to play with your friends. The energy/electricty system is a little hard to understand first, but I hope it will get better with the updates. With mutiplayer you can get things done a whole lot faster, as ive played with my three other friends. If you want a survival game I recomend this game. The music is great, and has a spaceish feel to it. Mutiplayer is easy to use, just open your ports, and get the IP, boom youre in. Playabe, and has hours of game play just to get the basic things. I Love this game so far, and I am looking forward to the updates to make this game even better! I am planning to make a gameplay series of this game, show the updates, and how to do things in the game. Keep up the good work Devs!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Let's start by saying I've been playing this game since it first came out on Steam.  I also voted (before that) to have it "greenlit"...  Greenlighting a game in Steam means that out of several recommendations that Steam gives you for upcoming games they'd be willing to add to their service, you chose the ones you like best.  Not all games actually make it!It didn't take much to impress me, this game had it all.  That's not to say it needs to improve highly, but the devs once promised there is a lot of updating planned for it. I really love this game so far, it has major potential.Having played Terraria for some time, I knew this game would be a great addition to my Steam library.  It has a long way to go, even after it was released to the public, there is a lot of content that needs to be added, and lots of bugs that need squishing.  Nevertheless, I am looking forward to see that happen.Still the best "Terraria In Space" anyone could find!

Posted: December 19, 2015
												This game seemed to have a lot of potential especially if it continued to develope.  I will say that the Devs are very active and not just "Holiday season" active to make it seem like they are still putting time into the game. This team keeps pumping out updates almost 1 to 2 a month and providing feedback for future updates. The game is a little hard to follow and a very pricy for it's type. If you like this type of game though and can catch it on a really good sale, pick it up, you may find something you like about  it. I don't feel that I can recommend it though, for the price to value ratio just isn't there. If you like Terraria, and are expecting this to be as good or a lot like it, you would be in error. Other than being the same type of game (2D crafting exploration game) it lacks a lot of polish, and flavor. It is still early access though so it could becore a great game, but I don't know yet. If it ever does, I will have to update my review.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I have a split review about this game, (9/19/15 edit NO LONGER SPLIT) so below you will find my pros about EoS. Pros:Amazing graphics, sure there is better, but the graphics amplify the futuristic feel of the game rather then the classic 8-bit.Kind playerbase, I have been to many a server on EoS and only 1-2 of them have had a non-userfriendly community to come along with them, but those that do i mostly delete from my server list.Understanding Devs, unlike most early acces games, EoS has devs who always respond to complaints and try to fix them. Most of what usaully turns me away from early acces games is the devs forget about the players after a bit and turn the game into a money grab for them, but thankfully Eos's devs show no sign of doing so. (thanks guys)Addictive gameplay, EoS has a feel that you have to keep on going to the next thing, boss after boss, domain after domain. The fact that you have categories instead of a specific item being needed for every recipe. In my opinion, this really helps because you can swap clay for dirt for mud for rock etc. This helps because you dont have to grind your way through the world looking for specific resources.It has a story, unlike most games (except starbound) this game follows a story that explains why you are randomly stuck on a planet with a cryopod as a respawn point.Cons: As of 9/19/15 i cannot think of any consThe advertising video is a complete lie: 9/19/15 edit: not anymore!!! the trailer pretty much sums up the gameplay (congratulations to the devs for finnaly completing it)The sections of the research list (my hotkey is L) of Experimental armor, Assualt armor, and Recon armor: 9/19/15 edit: no longer relevant =xAlso you cant get structure blocks for a base until a few hours in: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED: can get this almost immediately after creating the worldAlmost forgot to mention the tiny damage of the starter gun: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED ;D starter gun is now has fair damage and guns are easier to craft Good Job Devs

Product received for free
												Scam Alert! What a mess this was. They came out with a fun concept of a vertical based survival mining game and really goofed it up. Then when the chips were down and the sychopant chorus sang but it is early access it will be great when its done! They Notched it and released the buggy rough hewn work as a finished product and scuttled off with the dollary doo's. Yet another reason to never trust early access. A bit about the actual game is that you have to wait for machines to churn out recources you provide to progress. Then you have to complete dungeons using resources you harvested to access. Its a monotenous poorly scripted bullet hell that turns arbitrary resource gathering into a byzantine mess of mechinization and waiting around till you can get 45 nanocarbon fiber units or whatever you need to not die instantly in the next zone down. Remember: If the game is bad and unfinished after years of non progress like DayZ its never going to be done. If you buy a game like that and its got obvious bad spots where its poorly made has bad itemization or other red flags. Return it immediately!Don't buy these games as jokes, you only support more of this. Finally just wait for the version counter to tick over to 1.0 before you buy!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												PROS:Progression-I appreciate the progression in this game, it's not something where you get to end-game gear in one day. I still haven't got to the end-game yet, in fact, I barely even started. According to my character, I have learned less than 10% of everything you can learn in the game. Progression Part 2-This may seem grindy, but Edge of Space made this slow progression curve actually fun. They broke up the progression in a way where there's branches you pick, like armor crafting, weapon crafting, base construction and even pet creation, and there's 15 tiers of progression in each branch, each successing tier costing more knowledge points. Everything gives you knowledge points to spend to progress further, and the deeper you dig into the planet, the more points you earn. NPC's and Crafting Stations-There's NPC's that hand out quests, which keep you busy, some requiring harder to achieve materials than others. And on top of these NPC's, there's a large amount of crafting stations, requiring you to have some kind of base. There's also command centers, which provide power to nearby devices which require power. It's a neat system I don't see in too many games.CONS:(Let's be honest here, no game is perfect. So, let's get to the chase, and say the things I've noticed and dislike about this game. Also, keep in mind that everything I have said is my opinion)Textures-Quite a few items in the game share the same texture, like Soft Chitin and Penguin Explosives. These 2 items are very different, but they look exactly the same, and it's a little annoying. This is one example of items sharing the same texture, and there are a few more instances.Multiplayer-Multiplayer is a bit janky. When me and my friend played on a server I hosted, we noticed you can have only 1 of each Quest NPC in the world, and command centers (They provide power), cannot be placed anywhere near each other. So, what I'm saying is you and your friend have to share a base, or your friend has to live far away, and one of you has to walk all the way to the other player's base to talk to the NPC's. Also, the quests are independent, but at least the dungeons you can go to are publicly accesible which slighly makes up for this. But all in all, I was far ahead of my friend, and had all the quest NPC's, which ruined his experience a little bit, because we were independently progressing.All in all, this game has more pros than cons in my opinion, and makes for a great game. If you don't feel comfortable paying $14.99, then wait for a sale. I got this game for only $4.99 around Christmas, and trust me, if you think this game isn't worth $15, then it most certainly is worth $5, because this game has potential for hours of enjoyment!-KLuebbert

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I waited a long time to review this game, mainly because I don't like or want to contribute to negative reviews. I acquired this game in pre-Alpha back in 2013 and it was a rather RAW version of the game back then. The forums were kicking on the main webpage and wheels were turning with update ideas and the direction of the game. Fast forward 2-3 years and there is a lot of development, a lot of change, and a game that has been finished. There were many character wipes and world wipes along the way = That was to be expected. I bought it on pre-order before early access, and played for about 6-8 months through early access, so a few save wipes isn't a huge deal. However, I think another user said it best " I think the negative reviews are born mostly out of frustration with how long the game took to get from early access to release." Here we are three years later with a game that is no longer in Early Access but still has clunky controls and somewhat of a grind feel. However - it has come a long way, and if you came  here NOT expecting to grind in order to craft and survive, I don't know what you were expecting.I played some of the most recent updates and will update my review from not recommended to recommended, but with a disclaimer attached: This game still doesn't feel 100% to me. But, Terraria never did either - far from it - and everyone loves to compare this title to Terraria. Terraria was lacking in story line, direction, but had an abundance of content and playability with constant updates. This game is proceeding along a similar path, but a  year or so ago they introduced a Tutorial stage at the beginning of the game. Instead of the tutorial level - the game now appears to have something else, that exists more as a dialogue feature that I won't spoil.I"ll keep checking in on the updates as they come along.

Early Access Review
								*Early Access Review* *Not final review*This game is a 2D mining sandbox game, but it's not a generic clone of Terraria, but it does feel like a clone. First off, combat only consists of guns right now, this is quite annoying, but the amount of guns is pretty good. Crafting is very complex, you can substitute some materials for others, but this also makes the crafting system feel slow and clunky, which I hope this is fixed later on. The developers update the game VERY often, and make changes based on community feedback, like an early access game should. I recommend this game based on sheer content alone, but buyers beware, it's early access, there ARE bugs.
