content:
Posted: January 14
												Most of the reviews point out the same thing, the game is abandoned by the devs. So why do I recommend the game?I had fun.The graphics are pretty good, the weapons and armor were fun to play around with and to fit different play styles the PIOS was ambitious and confusing at first, but does work. That said it, among many other things, still need work. The game never left beta and only did because the company folded. Bugs/crashing: I didn't come across any bugs. Not to say they don't exist or might be in the late game content though. Not one crash. Sure 15 hours isn't a ton of playtime, but that is still 15 hours without a single crash. (window 7 64, AMD, ATI hardware)Abandonment: Don't pay full price if you are curious about the game, wait for a sale or bundle etc. I have to say that for me, it was worth the money spent for the time spent and amount of enjoyment I received. That said though, I don't really want to support a publisher who leaves unfinished games to just cash in on. A price reduction is certainly in order.TL:DR - sound gfx and gameplay was fun but game was abandoned so any bugs/problems will never get fixed. Get on sale or skip. Or get Terraria.  Pleading to publisher or Valve: Open the game to the steam workshop and allow mods.Think of other good games like Bloodlines, it released with game breaking bugs that required community patches to fix. If the ambitious players could make mods that would allow for us to finish the game and add more content. Sucks that it is left to the players, but at least it would be something because the basis for a great game was left on the table here.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
-Review subject to change as the game does-Pre review TL;DR:It feels like an early access game still, with aspects not fleshed out or completely/nearly goneIt STILL needs to be polished moreit STILL needs more contentAnd to top it all off, devs went dead silent and moderators were layed off despite the fact they told us "Regular post-launch updates will bring fresh new content"Pros:+Exp and upgrade system is great+The overall concepts are really nice+The backrounds on the biomes and the lighting change in each biome looks good+Tons of potentialCons:-Melee weapons are useless-You only need 2 or 3 weapons of the 20 or so ingame, the boomerang, the volter, and maybe a boson blaster-The landscape (Foreground) is a mish-mash of colors-The structures offer little to no reward and can be very out of place-Everything that isn't shield regen improving fighter armor is basically useless (From personal experience)-Out of vehicle you always remain sluggish and cumbersome flying around, jetpack tiers don't increase any speed horizontally or vertically (iirc)-Combat is sluggish feeling because of jetpacks being so slowy-Exploration is slow and unrewarding, each biome is a reskin-Last two biomes are completely unfinished-Multiplayer is port based and buggy (Infinite loading screens, lag, ect.)-No Terraforming or survival aspects-You see the Terraria "Inspired" Worm on the videos on store page? Not in the game, and to my knowledge never was-Abandoned with unfinished content-My review is still subject to change for better or worse if the game finally updates more-

												I bought this game a long time ago on that other thing... what was it... desura! pre-order kind of thing that gave me access to the demo. when it came to steam, I remembered that I bought it and started looking to see if I could get a code to import my desura copy to steam or if I had to strap myself down with another content management thing. I could! wonderful.The game plays well enough, its a bit goofy really. Thing is, its a bit under the radar as far as games I keep my eyes on. updates are always going on, and over time they really do make a difference, but somehow I always forget I have it. Then one day, I spot it and realize "oh hey, thats a thing I have. lets see whats up. oh these are neat changes." Ill play it a bit, and then get distracted again. Its a decent game though. It's been streamlined and improved quite a lot since I got it all that time ago.There are a lot of negative reveiws for edge of space though, looking through them I see that it's down to the devs comparing it to terraria. Personally, that was a mistake on their part. When you take game giants and start throwing comparisons around, inevitably people will become incredibly salty about it because "WHAT!? THIS GAME IS LIKE THE GAME I LIKE!? LETS JUST SEE ABOUT THAT!!! WHATS THIS? THIS GAME IS DIFFERENT THAN THE GAME I LIKE!? *insert verbal abuse and hate aimed at others who do enjoy it and it's developers here*." Edge of Space is NOT terraria, it is it's own game. Take my word for it, give it a try and you'll see.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												So, ill start with addressing the mixed views.. most of the bad comments you see about this game are from back when the game was in pre-alpha.. since then this amazing team has made this game beautiful and have really come a long way.. I should know I played this back before it was even on steam, but thats my opinion.  AND dont let my time played on steam fool you, trust me I have hours soaked into this game.Now for the pros and cons. -PROS--tons of weapons-tons of armor-lots of really cool mounts, such as SPACE RAPTORS, gaint crabs, mechs and gunships, even ones that help you build and mine!-lots of really cool decor and important building items-has a really cool power system in which you can root a power supply to your lights, doors, and even crafting stations.-a great number of really cool enemies to fight from flying jellyfish to polarbears with artillery cannons on their backs.-has dungeons with some rather awesome boss fights-3 types of armor, fighter, builder and explorer, each pretty self explanatory.-constant updates which always fix problems and bring in awesome new toys.-as is,  the game has a ton of fun content that will keep you busy for hours.I could keep going but I think you get the point.-CONS--You dont own this game-has a few bugs, nothing really GAME breaking, except for the UI problems, opening menus and such lag the menus out, this while really game breaking is being broken down on as we speak, so in a week or two you can most likely ignore this.-needs a bit more upbeat music, mostly for events etc.Well honestly thats all I can think of.. if you are a fan of games like terraria or starbound, or just a fan of 2d games where you can build, then give this game a go its great!  With the speed of updates and endless content they can put out for it im sure this game will keep going strong for a long time, once they fix that UI lag... good bye social life.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you played all you could of Terraria and Starbound and absolutely love the sandbox genre of games then you will love Edge of Space. This game combine many of the elements of Terraria with an Edge of Space trim to it. The gameplay itself is similar to Terraria, but with a Starbound spacey theme. The game is unique in its own way. Game music is good, better than starbound but not as cool as Terraria. The game is more complex then Terraria and Starbound which can deter players who play it for the first time. The tutorial explains the basic controls and concepts of the game, but in my opinion, more could have been done to explain the game mechanics for crafting. You have to read your codex entries after the tutorial to figure out what you need to do. Once you do that the game becomes very fun to play. Explore, craft, fight... All is open to your disposal. This game is still in beta, the developers are constantly patching the game and adding new content. The game only gets better from here.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												This one is pretty hard for me to judge objectively, as it was given by a now-gone Significant Other.As such, I've desperately tried to like the game and pushed myself to give it more chances.Now, with that in mind - The game has potential. There's some really great ideas in there as well as a unique art style (Though given the size of the sprites, I can't imagine there's much modding going on with people skilled enough to pull it off).The problem is, as always, execution. Edge of Space feels very empty, despite its vast size, and there's not much to really  do other than "Dig deeper, grind for better gear". The controls feels pretty floaty, and the gathering mechanics tend to get very weird when you want to mine a block right in front of you. Their attempts at humor are dry and fall flat on its face, as I've come to expect of indie games lately. Also, on top of frequent bugs and crashes, the game also needs some SERIOUS rebalancing around the crafting system and output. Often times you will have to grind your butt off to get a better gun, only to find that the one after that is almost trivial to acquire. Enemy frequency and damage scale up disproportionally to your ability to defend yourself.So what DO I like about the game? The crafting system is quite brilliant - Much like the (newly released at the moment of writing) Fallout 4, you mostly rely on braking down items into basic components, in this case minerals. For instance, you can build a nice looking base with just some basic metal and dirt, no joke.Building is also a charm, as you can place blocks all over the screen without a fake limit. It's also quite refreshing to get a hi-tech tool from the get-go. I s2fg, if I have to deal with another spacey game that gives me a pickaxe, I'm rioting.When the game works, it can feel very satisfying.In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game, since it still feels heavy WIP, even if it improved GREATLY since launch (It was simply awful then). The content is limited, and it's pretty clear that the game is very much unfinished at this point. I've found a way to enjoy it, but without the intial reason, I would have abandoned the game for good.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												I simply cannot recommend the game in this state.I was trying to wait out for updates, I was trying to wait for the developers to come back from their "logistics stuff" that they've been doing for months (it doesn't take that long for someone or even multiple people to move), and the developers have seemingly fallen off the face of the planet (maybe into the Edge of Space!? lol, couldn't resist, sorry).Starbound did a similar thing where Chucklefish relocated their entire company, but yet here's the thing: Chucklefish at least continued to maintain their website, and actually continued communications with the playerbase. Since Handyman Studios posted that update in April (It is October as I write this), there hasn't been any communication whatsoever, except for 1 tweet that advertised the game being on sale somewhere.So, since this appears to be abandonware, I believe I can attach my own review of this game.Do I recommend it as it is now? NO.Do I think it could be a good game? YES, but only if the developers actually come back.Do I hope they would come back and make it better? YES!The game has a nice premise going for it, but there are simply too many things wrong with it to make it an actual good purchase. If you really want a tech demo to mess around with, maybe for inspiration or ideas, go ahead. I'd wait until it's on sale, though.So, Pros/Cons:Pros: -A nice recipe unlock system-Good graphics for a sidescrolling indie game-Lots of inventive ideas (pets, character upgrades, etc)-A unique take on the sandbox exploration game (you progress by going down)-You start with a jetpackCons:-Control/UI Bugs (your character will shoot their weapon or use their tool while dragging items around in the UI)-Unfinished game and obvious missing content (the last two biomes are not finished, some tech unlocks are empty)-Blah combat (you always feel weak as bleeep because your guns all suck, and it takes 10+ shots to kill anything)-Melee combat is useless-Cheap enemies that can fly through solid walls to attack you-Dungeons are buggy, some of those bugs were fixed in the last update, but some remain from what I've been told-No Real Map System (this is the huge deal-breaker for me -- you only have a "current" minimap of what you can currently see and that's it)-Somewhat clunky UI system (inventory management, everything freshly obtained gets dumped into the hotbar etc)-UI LAG. Yes, the UI lags when trying to move items around.Recap: A game that has/had a lot of potential but sadly fell way short. I tried hard to like this game, because when I first started playing it, I was like "I hope they finish this game or make it better!" But sadly.. it doesn't look like that will ever come to pass. If you're a game developer and you're looking for some inspiration, I'd suggest picking this game up on sale, maybe someone else can develop something else that is similar but way better?

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has come a long way. I bought in on a whim in my early terraira burn-out phase. Wasn't much then, but the developers have been working hard to improve the game and it shows. Countless patches later this game could launch today and it would get solid reviews. I recommend this one to anyone with a love for rouge likes and has a taste for the sci-fi our fathers used to enjoy. Outside of that, this is at it's core a mining/crafting game. Nothing special to remark outside of differences from other games in genre. Overall not bad compared to other offerings either when it comes to controls, content and depth. Sure, it's not on the same scale as Starbound, and nothing is as polished as terraira, but this game has character and immersion. The rough edges of this work in progress are limited to a lack  of good interface and general tutorials that leave much to be desired. I haven't truly logged enough hours to speak about end game, but I want you to know that I havent regret my purchase since day one (well over a year before this review). Check it out, I think you'll probably end up feeling the same.(Additional Edit: 4/26/15)I just wanted to update my review based on the current state of the game. I noticed recently that this game was at a "Mixed" review status. Please, if you are like me and weary of seeing such things before you purchase, give each and every negative review a read to make sure. This game is a work in progress. It should go without saying, but this is going to have bugs. It's going to have wipes. They are going to release patches that break, change, or completely destroy previous things. Accept it or dont buy early access titles. For what its worth; I still give this game the "safe to buy in" approval. It's a little clunky here and there, but they have really done SO much to improve the game. Its got everything one would expect from a game of this genre. If you're a fan of SciFi and Crafting/Rouge-likes, you would be doing yourself a disservice to not take the dive on this one. Its a solid game already and the Developers are VERY attentive and constantly updating. Don't let the mixed review status turn you off. From what I have read, there is alot of nit picking over what is a really early access title that, even after two years, is STILL being worked on constantly. Jump in, help out with the progress of this game, and enjoy the glorious Science!

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't get me wrong the game is solid already,  but even at this point early access,  the base game just doesn't feel very involving.  You start out in a game with a spawn point and are given lots of blueprints to activate then craft.  Where I get pretty annoyed and usually give up is the whole downward scrolling aspect of the game.  To reach the first 'layer' of a surface, you need to drop down,  which requires building stairs back up to the initial block of dirt you spawn in to presumably build your starting base.   Getting back to the whole verticle scrolling aspect of the game.  Going up and and down all the time requires building lots of stairs and frequent use of your jetpack.  The problem is, it recharges extremely slowly,  resulting in a lot of time just waiting to use it.   Lighting is also trickier than in other survival games:  there's a few flareguns and torches to be placed,  but they all require using the crafting menu,  which is tedious. For example, to craft an item you need to select the materials you want to use first,  sometimes there's a huge list of materials you need and if you are missing one, you'll have to re-select all of them again if you want to try and craft again.   A lot of the time you'll find yourself in the dark trying to climb out of a pit of some sort, and hope you don't accidently fall further downwards to certain doom.Speaking of tedious,  everything just feels tedious to me about the game.  Mining is about as exciting as watching blocks smoke from heat before turning into collectable ores.  Crafting requires dragging a blueprint to your inventory slots, selecting the slot,  holding left click to activate the blueprint,  then right clicking the inventory slot to remove the blueprint.  This is just a typical example of how something is done in this game and honestly I don't feel like any of it is as intuitive as it should be.   Combat is also pretty sleepy.  You shoot enemies,  and they die.  There's no real weight to the combat and it's just not very gratifying.  Overall tho, the game does feel solid as I say.  Personally I just fall asleep trying to figure something out,  but that's just me.  Many will find the game appealing because there is much to do and there's a lot of content,  so if the aforementioned things don't bug you, feel free to dive in.

												Ive been playing this game for the last couple of days and i have to say that it is a phenomanally gameplay rich game filled with fun and engaging contenet.  Alot of people on here are claiming it is a Starbound ripoff but at least this game is finished and runs smoothly on my pc (with the minor hiccup here and there) but all in alli have had no game breaking bugs or crashes in my play time. As i mention there is alot of content to play with, one example is the ability to travel to dungeons changing the gameplay from a Terraria style build and crafting game into somthing a kin to Super Metroid or Castlevania Symphony of the Night. The gun play is satisfying and a multitude of guns gives a lot of choice to the player as to what they want to use.  Do you use the laser shotgun to blast your foes to pieces with a point blank blast to the frontal lobe? or do you take the Volter and electricute two enemies at the same time disintegrating there bodies!  when it comes down to it i would definetly recomend this game!!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												After extensive playing of Edge of Space since the release I decided to rewrite my review.Pros:Sci-fi setting with a good intro video explaining why you are on a planet that’s hostile and heck bent on killing you.I love the sci-fi graphics, and the look of the broken planet landscape.Excellent array of items to craft, in fact, the list is HUGE, including three different sets of armor (each with their own upgrade tree), all kinds of different weapon types, and a lot of other things that give my love of farming resources, and collecting new, interesting bits and pieces, a lot of reasons to feel content.A very large selection of base building decorations, workstations, defenses, etc. And yes, the advanced items require extensive farming and playing the game to gather enough resources to make, which some might feel is grindy, but I feel motivates me to keep exploring and mining for “a few more minutes” and then turns out to be two-three hours of game time I didn’t even know slipped by when I glance at the clock.I’ve heard a lot of negatives about the user interface, but personally I see nothing wrong with it, and you can see it demonstrated in action via screen-shots, youtube videos, and streams, so it’s not like the developers are trying to hide something… If it doesn’t interfere with my game-play and fun, I don’t see how it’s a problem.Lots of biomes, and mobbies, and some good humorous moments.Tons of new areas to explore, and lots to keep you busy.Developers that are getting the kinks worked out as fast as possible, and they are very active and responsive in the forums begging those with issues to send them logs so they can fix any issues for everybody else.I’ve put a ton of time in and I am thoroughly enjoying myself, because I find the game both extensive and challenging.I myself haven’t crashed even once, and though I experience lag here and there it only happens for me after playing for several hours straight. My computer is an Asus Rog Gaming Laptop, win 10, and I have an nvidia card.The mini patches since 1.0 hit have improved the game a lot, in my opinion.Active Devs that really want this game to succeed and are willing to do whatever it takes — though they get knocked around a lot by players that seem unwilling to give them time to hear and fix any issues that might be present…Cons:The Lead Dev has said the game was designed more for multiplayer, so mobs tend to spawn in waves that can overwhelm a single playing character… After reading that bit of info, I was sad, because I look at these games as something I wish to spend a lot of time with soloing. Like in Terraria when I played with a friend he wanted to kill this boss, and that boss, and I wanted to just find resources. I never played with anyone again, though once I got to Moon Lord I lost interest, because I realized that fight wasn’t balanced for single player at all (my opinion).EOS needs some patches to iron out the kinks, and I bet my life SO WILL Terraria Otherworld when it’s released. Even Terraria has had at least a half dozen mini patches since 1.3 hit, and I don’t see anyone knocking Terraria for it… And Starbound will continue to see many updates and patches before and after its 1.0 version hits… Whenever that might happen — sooner than later, me hopes!Players rush to leave negative feedback, rather than logging the problem and helping the Devs get a handle on it. They have asked and asked for player input via logs, but some grumpy, unhelpful players would rather sink their chance at sales than help get the game working perfectly for everyone.The game is extensive and resource gathering takes a long, long time. And some ingredients are very hard to find and farm — like Penguin parts and even Headhunter parts, and though I love to farm resources, even I wish these dropped more often…Sometimes things feel unfair, unbalanced, such as weapon upgrades that don’t do much to make you feel like the mobbies are being hurt… I swear there was a penguin laughing at me at a Penguin Rave — it was hysterical, this little penguin dancing at a Rave as I’m shooting him, pew pew for half a minute…It seems New Players find the beginning confusing, and perhaps because the game is so extensive more time should have been put into a longer, more engaging tutorial, with an option to skip it for more advanced players…Final thoughts:Personally I’m enjoying my time in the game, and though I have a large library, it keeps pulling me back with that one more node feeling, and I wake up excited to play and find new areas and new upgrades, etc. Some might not like gathering, farming games, and if the game is balanced around MP, I think MP should have been a bigger priority, as I believe a lot of complaints have stemmed from the MP community, AND I feel us solo players might not find the game as satisfying in the later stages, if the game really cannot be completed single player (which I’ve no idea if it can or cannot, but I’m hoping!!!)

Even Terraria has had at least a half dozen mini patches since 1.3 hit, and I don’t see anyone knocking Terraria for it… And Starbound will continue to see many updates and patches before and after its 1.0 version hits… Whenever that might happen — sooner than later, me hopes!Players rush to leave negative feedback, rather than logging the problem and helping the Devs get a handle on it. They have asked and asked for player input via logs, but some grumpy, unhelpful players would rather sink their chance at sales than help get the game working perfectly for everyone.The game is extensive and resource gathering takes a long, long time. And some ingredients are very hard to find and farm — like Penguin parts and even Headhunter parts, and though I love to farm resources, even I wish these dropped more often…Sometimes things feel unfair, unbalanced, such as weapon upgrades that don’t do much to make you feel like the mobbies are being hurt… I swear there was a penguin laughing at me at a Penguin Rave — it was hysterical, this little penguin dancing at a Rave as I’m shooting him, pew pew for half a minute…It seems New Players find the beginning confusing, and perhaps because the game is so extensive more time should have been put into a longer, more engaging tutorial, with an option to skip it for more advanced players…Final thoughts:Personally I’m enjoying my time in the game, and though I have a large library, it keeps pulling me back with that one more node feeling, and I wake up excited to play and find new areas and new upgrades, etc. Some might not like gathering, farming games, and if the game is balanced around MP, I think MP should have been a bigger priority, as I believe a lot of complaints have stemmed from the MP community, AND I feel us solo players might not find the game as satisfying in the later stages, if the game really cannot be completed single player (which I’ve no idea if it can or cannot, but I’m hoping!!!)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Quick Review:Edge of space is quite a relaxing game. It obviously lacks of fun and ecxiting things to do but it has its simple charm of just simplistic things to do, I'm sure you'll have a good time if you don't compare to terraria and starbound. (unless you hate these 2D kind of games... why would you even consider buying this if thats the case....)Long Review:Lets start with describing what its missing and what needs to change. CONS:First of all, as everyone would say about this game, is that its various inventory and crafting "pop ups" are complete rubbish. They need to change all of these because has it is for now, you have to press around 7 different keys to open 7 different things that literaly take up ALL you screen. And btw it also doesn't pause the game so you'll be sure to be killed if you don't pay attention. So all this inventory bussiness needs to be sorted out. You'll also have a hard time getting used to this weird new crafting mechanic they use. Even though it isn't the worst, it sure is quite different... I personally don't mind it because it forces you to go out of your base and mine and kill stuff for experience. You then spend this experience on different types of weapons or armor. Tbh the armor and weapons they have at the moment are quite boring. There is nothing special about them so you'll end up just picking what does more damage and what benifits you the most. They will need to make each weapon type more special and more ecxiting. Finally the envirnment is also quite dull. A lot of what this game lacks of is just fun and cool stuff to do, to craft and to explore. There are some locations to fight and conquer, but there's nothing "special" about them... So now that we've discussed the cons here are some of the PRONS:This game has this ability to really start you offvery easily with barely any enemies to attack you at the beggining but has you go further down, the enemies only get stronger and thougher with chaging backgrounds as well. Not many games allow you to start off like this like this game does, and it really helps just to work out what you are supposed to be doing (cause thats quite hard at the begining).For the reason above, this means that this is quite a relaxing game. It has a wonderfull soundtrack to it which really had an impact on me the first time. I really managed to fully relax and enjoy the game with this wonderfull soundtrack. I also think the mining in this game is great. You are able to last as long as you want (usually) just peacefully minning away without some great powerful monster sneaking up on you. (lol I'm getting tired of writting so I'm ending here)I think that since this game is now out of early access, it isn't getting as many updates anymore so I wouldn't get it if you will be expecting more of this game for the future (although I could be wrong). I would say to buy this if you are looking for something out of the oridnary and isn't trying to follow the same foot steps that terraria has left so give it a try (when it isn't as expensive as it is wight now because it definitely isn't worth that much money, basically get it on a sale if you are bored, k bye im done here...)

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Currently, the game is in VERY Early Access, without a significant amount of content or progression.  However, what is here is all good.  Edge of Space, unlike other games of this genre, is much more combat focused - collecting "tech" upgrades and data from the creatures you murder unlocks the next tier of craftables, which is a pretty nice change of pace from the genre staple "dig downward to win" scheme.How it works as of this patch, however... kind of grindy.  It's definitely in need of tuning (and the devs have mentioned it's going to get said tuning) but the system itself is a nice change of pace.What the game sorely lacks now is content - the core systems appear to work well, so it really just needs to be loaded with items, enemies, ores, and mores.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								November 28th, 2014Picked this up during a sale. I own Terraria and Starbound but the latter left me burned with it's launch and follow through by the developers, but this isn't about that.I'd been interested in Edge of Space for some time and had it on my Wishlist for a couple months before finally picking it up. A quick look through the history of the games shows I missed some of the blunder years the game held and am playing it after a UI and tier revamp so I can't comment on anything prior to the date above.The game looks good, though I wish there were more customization items for characters, the style they've presented works well and I had no probably playing my marathon session of the game these past 2-3 days (17 hours) and the music is pretty darn good as well. Normally I listen to my own music collection during these types of games but I left the background BGM on and didn't grow to hate it. The controls are smooth as well and how you can move is really limited to your gear and how well you can control your jet pack, using weapons can be tricky sometimes however. The game has a few different weapon types in its starter tier from the basic automatic rifle, sniper rifle, and mortar launcher. I've found myself using the sniper rifle and mortar exclusively. You have unlimited ammo but there is a reload timer but that's not why I don't use the automatic, the main reason is damage and difficulty hitting enemies. I played exclusively in a local hosted server with friends and there were times were you can't hit an enemy due to their size, movement, and shots just passing through (most likely due to the server lagging) so we found more success with the area damage of the mortar and taking the risk with the sniper rifle.Crafting is pretty extensive as well. There are three armor types and many branches of crafting to "skill up" by using Science XP gained from mining, crafting, and hunting monsters (which is the best gainer later on) and unlike Terraria and Starbound the dungeons aren't found in the world but you rather transport to them after gaining enough coordinates to get to them. Once you enter the dungeon the rules change, you can't use your mining laser or jet pack. Having these taken away really changes how you go against an enemy as you now have to time your jumping and can't block or tunnel away from an enemy (or through a stage) and personally I feel is nice change. Unfortunately I haven't seen the dungeon boss yet as during the dungeon we had problems with the game failing to load or players games blanking to grey in the dungeon.Overall however, I am really pleased with the purchase and look forward to future updates with the game. It does have a learning curve and some of the UI elements are weird (I've hit escape hoping to clear a open menu more times than I can count, it doesn't work) but overall at it's current stage it's fun and playable.

Posted: March 13, 2015
												Review Updated as of 4/3/2016How far my hopes have fallen.This games started out with such great potential. Nice graphics, good crafting and world building mechanics. Even the inclusion of EXP and special in-world events! There were even going to be NPCs. Notice how I say 'were' in that last sentance.The Developers seem to have left this game behind. In December, they assured us that the next update would come out after they got back from Christmas break, but days turned to weeks, and eventually into months. No update, no word from the Developers, no hope for this game.The end product is a lot of good ideas that never got to see their full potential. The framework of a great game is there, but now it's never going to be completed.I had high hopes for this game, and I have no idea with the Devs vanished so suddenly. But despite my dashed hopes, I cannot recoment this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Edge of Space" is a construction/adventure game in the vein of Terraria, only in space!  It's a very simple premise, but somehow, as of this writing, the game doesn't quite deliver on either its potential or the intellectual legacy of Terraria, which great effort is put into establishing.The first thing to realize about this game is that there are some really cool ideas!  You've got a laser drill, and you start with projectile weapons!.  The graphics are a miss for me (I'll get into why later), but are certainly more detailed than Terraria's, and may not be as offensive to another gamer's eye.(The following edited as of 21 May 2015...)The game has vastly improved since my playthrough last year!  The general user experience is far less irritating than it was, and actually warrants my giving this game a chance now.What WorksThe game's crafting system is awesome.  Pretty much, the game is already similar to the "Terraria Leveled" mod in some ways mechanically, but the research lines are well-defined, and the experience amounts required to unlock a tier feel correct.  What's more the amount of things you can craft without a crafting station is great for upgrading your field arsenal (from what I've seen so far.)They fixed the guns to always hit.  This was the dealbreaker for me before.  Thank you.  Note to other game developers: in an action game, RNG-based miss mechanics are very very bad.  What's more the base tier of stuff after completing the tutorial is actually useful, which is nice!Speaking of the tutorial, it appears simplified from the version I played earlier, and is effective at basically teaching the game.  Less was indeed more!You can rebind keys.  This helps to mitigate some of the confusing keybindings in this game, and let you play Your Way™.What Doesn't WorkFirst, you still spawn on a sky island instead of the planet's surface.  I think this is a mistake, even with jetpacks being available immediately, because jumping into a void beneath your little sky island is too much of an early risk, that I don't think a new player wants to take - at this point, we're still getting a feel for the game and the world.Second - re-evaluate your default key bindings.  V for crafting and C for character are really counterintuitive to me.  While providing rebindable keys is nice, nailing a good preset will help this game immensely.  It was irritating to have to click the menu button every time I wanted to craft something, until I found the hotkey.Speaking of crafting, the way you spend XP feels incredibly clunky, and the increment/decrement textfield used to implement it clashes with everything else.  Since the upgrades are straight lines, not trees, why not just allow me to click an upgrade or a button on the upgrade in order to "buy" it with the XP?The visual style to me is hit or miss, but this gets into personal preference; if Terraria is a Saturday-morning cartoon, then this is Archer on Adult Swim, which is what I think they're going for.  This point may or may not be a sticking point for you; this "Doesn't Work" bit is purely subjective.  Some sprite mods or the ability to create sprite/tile image mods might be a good idea, though.The (New) TL;DROnce, I did not recommend this game; it wasn't ready for the public.  Luckily a few patches seem to have come and gone to help resolve that situation.  The developers need to study up on good User Experience (UX) quite a bit more, and take it as a lesson learned going forward - UX seems to be one of their weaknesses that they have to fight against.  However, the interesting ideas in this game seem significantly closer to fruition.I recommend watching this title more closely...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								Edge of Space (EoS) has just entered Early Access and is now up for grabs.EoS is in the explore and self-direct style of gameplay that was pioneered by Minecraft and Terraria. So if you're familiar with and enjoyed those games, this will be familiar to you but space flavored.If you've never played such a game, then let me boil it down for you. EoS is an action oriented exploration game where the world is created procedurally (randomly) and you possess no state goals aside from survival. You'll take your trust space pick and mine out a little bit of safety while hoarding resources to use later. Use on what? To craft bigger and more elaborate spacesuits, jetpacks, weaponry and gadgets.Except, it is beta, so how far that road goes is sort of limited. If you're the type who enjoys seeing games get bigger and more fleshed out then take a chance now and support the devs. Otherwise wait for the full buffet to come out later.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
Early Access Review
								Badass space version of Terraria. Graphics better but are more like SNES or Sega Genesis, so it still has that retro feel. Currently amazing even though it's in beta as I write this. Probably worth getting it at the "Dirt Cheap" special edition price, for an extra 5-10 dollars or so, but not sure yet. I am indeed enjoying it however. Ranged mining is quite useful too, crafting is simplistic, but it's a good challenge to get the materials. Night has been recently added to the game. The night could use a little work IMO. ( Without light you can see the background, which clearly has some form of light, [e.g. Stars] and your character perfectly fine above ground but when you look at the terrain, it's pitch black. Plasma torches are not hard to make, however you get one per craft. I'm probably overcomplicating; after all it's a video game. ) Once servers are running I'd like to have someone to play this gem of a game with. I recomend this if you enjoyed Terraria and/or would like more of a challenge and/or are into complex playing and/or retro looking games.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far this game is pretty fun and playable. If you're a big fan of Terraria-like games, this is definitely something to check out. It's a good deal more difficult and it takes a lot more getting used to than other games of its type that I've played. The UI, windows, and keybar are kind of a pain to deal with, but I'm sure that'll be fixed at some point. It's probably the most detailed of these pixel-y, crafty games out there, but I feel like the game should be a bit more "zoomed in" so it's easier to see all of those glorious pixel details, especially of your character. All in all, I feel that this could easily be a hit for.. Whatever the hell genre these games are, but, of course, after it gets worked on some more. For the moment, I'd say that if you don't have Starbound, you should check that out first. But if you already own it, then definitely give this a shot.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you yearn for that authentic "early access" experience, look no further! Do not be fooled by the fact that the game has been released almost 2 years ago, nor by the fact that those 2 years were filled with hyperactive developement - it still feels like a proof of concept. Every time I return to it after a long hiatus (caused, usually by frustration at being unable to progress because, to give a few examples, the devs couldn't decide where some resource or other should spawn and deciced not to put it into the game at all, or there is a typo in a crafting recipe) my saves won't work, half the in-game systems have been changed and the others are broken (dev-speak for those is "not balanced yet").I want to love this game, I've spent a lot of time playing it, but untill the devs decide what they want to actually do with it it's very hard to recommend.EDIT: I'd like to clarify, now that my hissy fit is over, that if there ever was a game that shows promise, then EoS is that game. It's just that, well, I want my saved games to work - at least for my character, if not for the world itself.

number of helpful: 12 of 24 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I bought this from kickstarter long time ago, during its ALPHA stages it was great and showed a lot of promise.They removed most of the enmies for a long time which was kinda frustrating as the game felt like it only had 3 enemis to kill. They made the world smaller and only go donwards direction which makes it really hard to travel as you cant predict if your jatpack can take it or you die falling. The quest are a good addition but mostly impossible as with the weapons you can get early they do 1 damage so destroying a craps nest takes so long you cant destroy it before time runs out. Same thing with defend defence platform, once you take the quest 8 enemies will spawn inside the defence platform and destroy it less than 10 seconds hitting it 15 dam per tick inside the platform.Also its kinda weird that enmies that hit it are seen in the game wilderness as non damaging mobs and yes they will even hurt you even thou they should not.The new research system takes far too long to get anything build. Even the basics. As you need to grind load of enemies to get 15-25 points in certain research gategories at random in order to advance it further which requires 1000 or more per level and enemies wont drop reserach date always when killed.Currently for some reason you cant even build the next weapon in line as its material tables are bugged and it wont allow you to put any of the right materials in to build it.Also the current weapon system is kinda sad as you can only upgrade your weapon and not really build more weapons jsut the one you have.Enemies can spawn anewhere, even inside you and they sure like to spawn inside your base all the time. You need to constantly clear it out.Enemies also tend to have so much hp that with your 1 dam pea shooter you need about 30 shots to kill one enemy and yo ueven have to reaload it slowly. Thou the weapons are made randomly if you are lucky you might get weapon with 2 dam.The lighting day and night system is getting an upgrade soon which is a great thing but at its current state it is horid. Black boxes that dont even fade in but appear instantly when night comes. Luckily this shoul be fixed soon but its been this bad for a long time.There are many normal alpha game buggs that dont bother me like animatiosn are the wrong way, characters spazzing out when looking up ( this will be fixed soon too =) ), etc cant craft things, de-sync at servers, etc.The developers are very active and have improved this game alot thou sometimes things have gone the other way too but currently I dont recomend this. This will prolly be good at some point but not yet. Consider buying terraria, 7 days to die, minecraft or maybe crea while you wait for this to pop up good.I will edit this review as the game updates, hopefully it get better. I really hope so.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll start by saying that this game is fairly fun, but only if you like Terraria and Starbound type gameplay.  The game starts you off in the wilderness wearing some basic light armour, a jetpack, and a rifle in-hand.  Using your laser pick you can mine out the natural resources of the world, and using your rifle you can blast the natural fauna of the world.At first you only know a handful of recipes, so as you go you will build data disks to unlock more recipes and more data in order to advance even further.  Unlike in say Terraria, you don't know every recipe off the bat, and unlike in say Starbound, you don't have to deconstruct or kill a boss to learn new recipes.The game seems simple and easy, until you get hit by a random event, in which case you might end up losing all of your clones in a matter of minutes as an unrelenting anomally continually destroys you as soon as you spawn.  For this reason, it's very much recommended to upgrade your gear as soon as you can.  Good luck!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								A very enjoyable game even though it is still under its earliest of development stages.I currently have played the Tutorial and replayed the Tutorial, during three different stages of the BETA.I have also played the first accessible world Acheao and had much fun even though the BETA often changes things that can both make and break the game!Uniquely, everything has remained stable, everything playable, and the only problem is the bugs that are few in number and worked out with every update of the BETA.And every update has added either new items, craftables, creatures, events, or even progression forms.I'm enjoying the BETA. I will enjoy the game when it leaves BETA too. It is a lot like Starbound, but set in a different dimension with slightly differents rules, laws, and phsyics. Oh, btw, if anything, you can customize your character to be a human, space kitten, cyborg, android, as well as being tenchologically altered, influenced by a slime symbiote, and more, so it all ends up really cool with character customization! Starbound has its races, EdgeOSpace has its many bizarre character feature combinations, inventing your own race and what not is easy (its only aesthetic though)!I'll mention new things in my reccomendation as they come up... for now expect the occasional character wipe and the rarer world wipe as they alter and add things to the game.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												This is one of those "Had amazing potential, shot itself in the foot, then to try fixing things, shot itself in the other foot" type of games.In the Early Access, it needed a bit of polishing, and some tightening, but overall wasn't too bad. And then they took out the tutorial, but fixed the UI a bit. And then that sort of thing became a trend. Take out an important bit, fix a semi-important bit, so overall, it got slightly worse.And now you  have a game that is, while playable, has a poor UI, no tutorial or useful start to speak of, and the worst thing; it feels like all the fun this game could have been was very specifically surgically removed.Maybe it was. After all, they had to remove something to put in the Robot Shark NPC at the last minute.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Been playing for a few hours now, and it's really awesome the sheer amount of content that has been packed into an alpha game. There's a huge amount of depth to this game already. However, this does come with some drawbacks. Not everything is mapped out for you, and while this may not seem like a big deal, with so many branching options on how you want to progress in the game it can become overwelming fast. Some sort of talent tree system, or unified menu for research and it's current level would be a huge help. A wiki for this game is something that the community is more responsible for, but as it gains momentum this type of resource will come naturally. Updates for this game are seriously quick and seems to flow constantly. Be ready for new content or fixes often, and tweaks to things you already know. Yes, I highly recommend the game for those who like sandbox games, and especially those who have a friend to play it with. Just remember that starting out is tough, and the end rewards are worth it. This is no terraria or minecraft or any other crafting game you've played. This is Edge of Space

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Edge of Space has come a long way since I first started playing. Movement feels a lot better; I have fun just jetpacking around and taking jumping-trickshots at the wildlife. The last minute addition of an entirely new category of weapons (melee) is fantastic, and I really like using them. There is a ton more content in every respect; creatures, events, billboard tasks, crafting, base decorations, and resources.A lot of people have mentioned that it's a bit tough getting into the game at the start, and I would have to agree with that. Fineous's dialogue options help, but it can be really difficult deciding where to spend those first precious Science points.My best tip: upgrade your jetpack (fighter, explorer, or builder) and make a better primary weapon (phase or melee) first! Having an upgraded jetpack makes a huge difference to mobility, and the starter weapon really seems to only be there to get you used to crafting -- by making you craft a better one.All in all, I'm having a lot of fun. Thanks for the game and congratulations on release!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Professional Preview (Italian): http://www.everyeye.it/pc/articoli/edge-of-space_provato_24950Abstract translated in English:Edge of Space is a promising heir to the 2D sanbox legacy initiated by Terraria, which introduces deep changes in one of the fundamentals of the genre: the crafting system. Having to invest your hard earned experience points in developing every single Research branch to discover their advanced recipes is both an incentive to explore the world in solo play and specialize your character in multiplayer games. There are bugs here and there, but the developers are actively supporting the game through continous patch deploying. We can't wait to see what new features will be introduced in the next updates: we'd like to see a compass that aims to your last bound cryopod or a geological probe to see what resources can be found in the area.Commento in Italiano:Edge of Space è un promettente erede della tradizione sandbox bidimensionale iniziata da Terraria, che introduce novità incisive in una delle meccaniche principali del genere, il crafting. La necessità di sviluppare i singoli campi di ricerca, investendo i punti esperienza ottenuti interagendo con l’ambiente, per scoprire le ricette più avanzate, aggiunge un incentivo a procedere nelle partite in solitaria e, allo stesso tempo, permette una maggiore personalizzazione dell’esperienza di gioco in multiplayer. I bug non mancano, ma le continue patch pubblicate dallo sviluppatore mitigano in parte la situazione, oltre a introdurre nuovi elementi di gameplay. Non ci resta che vedere quali altre feature verranno introdotte nei prossimi aggiornamenti: magari una bussola che punti verso la propria criocapsula o una sonda geologica per mappare le risorse presenti nell’area circostante.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I bought the game when it was on Greenlight a while back, and while it has somewhat improved since then, there's still some lingering issues with the game.The gameplay itself is fairly solid. If you're familiar with other side-scrolling survival games like Terraria or StarBound, you'll be right at home. The progression system to be able to craft better items for your base and gear gives you goals to work toward. Crafting that one weapon that plows through enemies you were having trouble with is always satisfying, and having missions to clear out an enemy nest is a good change of pace from resource gathering.The biggest issue I've had with the game is the UI. Tooltips for players new to this particular game would be helpful. There are times when the screen becomes cluttered by the menus and crafting screens, and the screens themselves will become somewhat unresponsive at times after long periods of play.Regardless of the game's issues, which I hope can be fixed in future patches, this is still a fairly fun game, and it's good for a change from the other survival side-scrollers. Give it a look if you can.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've put about 13 hours into it at this point, and I'd say that it's definitely worth it at the current sale price.  It's obviously a work in progress so there are things that are in flux and there are tweak issues (finding particular types of elements), and what feels like a memory leak (not confirmed yet...the last hour was getting laggy and warping, but the twelve previous hours ran perfectly).I admit I was slightly cautious about picking the game up for months because the art seemed a bit "fuzzy" (not as crisp as some of the other similar games), but didn't seem that way when playing...maybe it was an impression I got from early gameplay videos.Gameplay is close enough to Terraria that you won't be totally lost; though there are a lot more items to craft and there's more of everything.  The variety of weapons and the distinction of the armor, etc, are a plus.The world is alien and more broken up than Terraria...morea bunch of floating islands, some of which are quite large.  I haven't played it enough to distinguish layers and there is some environmental damage mechanic which resulted in the odd death when going to far down but is still a bit mysterious in its workings.Monsters and combat are more complex and interesting.  One thing I find interesting is that somethings are neutral under certain conditions and then hostile in others (sleep mode?).  You will often be in a situation where you have to decide how you will engage because indiscriminate shooting may aggro otherwise neutral beasts or plants that will jump in your combat and make your day really bad.There is a bit of silliness, but so far the majority of the game plays pretty straight...just had the occasional polar bear with jet boots thing but otherwise seems staple scifi.So yes, I would recommend if you like this type of sandbox game and are willing to do your own research rather than have everything spoonfed in one guide.<Note:  Reservations below are describing the current gameplay experience I am having.  They are just things to note and may be addressed tommorow for all I know.  On the whole, I am enjoying the game and look forward to seeing it get the polish that will really make it shine.>My main reservation is that, especially in such a "complex" type game with many concepts and crafting being such a main component, that documentation is sparse.  Of course documentation is one of the last things put in a game but even the community is really light in consolidated guides (at least in English...there are other language guides that may be more fleshed out).  This isn't a reason to not pick up the game but it will get a lot easier to play when you don't need to troll forums for basic game info (ie: what are dungeons, what do you need to go there) or how do you upgrade weapons.Other more minor reservations include "Hmmm, I build this item and put it in my base...just what does it do again?  Perhaps pop up tooltips for placed crafting stations or maybe an intergrated icon to jog the memory.Ladders, or other ways to go UP besides jump packs.Some sort of ablative heat shield/air bag for when you jump into an abyss that is many screens deep.In the crafting menu, have another grouping "misc" for all items that don't fit under weapons or base items or any of the other crafting subgroupings, so that when you want to craft something you don't need to scroll through the "all" category to find it.An interface to show you what items you can make in list form all on the screen at once (and the ability to hide items that are outdated).  Sort of a tech tree at a glance.The ability to choose how long info stays on screen before disappearing, and the ability to configure what is displayed.  IE:  I don't need to know xp as it accrues, but I would like to know when I ding a level in crafting what new recipies I had without looking through the browser.I assume XP bar fills and you get no more?  If so, maybe some sort of on-screen alert so you know to burn that XP instead of wasting time doing things with a full bar.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I've played the game off-and-on for the last couple of years, and it is a fun game.  It's Terraria or Starbound, but with better graphics.  However, the content of the game, while not terrible, is still lacking a bit, and there's still a lot of work that needs to be done.  The recent 1.0 Release I feel was a bit premature, as they actually removed some content from the game with the intent of it being added-in later (hopefully not as DLC).I tenatively rate this with a thumbs-up, but I might change this depending on how it progresses.  I've heard some rumors that some of the planned content for the game will instead be released as DLC, but until that's confirmed I won't downvote it, as I have gotten my money's worth out of the game.The easy description of this game?  Starbound with better graphics but with less content.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is completely awesome. Starbound was great for a while, but it will never have the "chase the dragon" addiction this game offers with it's leveling system. If you played Ultima Online, compare it to that with more control. You spend your mined resources on data for certain skills which allow you to build nicer items in that particular field. It seems very class oriented. There's like 13 skills right now as well as 6 stats. 3 armor skills and 3 weapon skills, giving you a fair amount of customization. Your skills allow you to do things like build different vehicles, different accessory buffs, an interesting spin on animal taming where you clone different animals that each have their own separate function, specialize in gathering+passive buffs, similar to UO Alchemy an entire skill dedicated to consumables, and even a cosmetic skill to make your forts look nicer. If these developers know what's good for them, they will continue to add more skills without changing the actual skill system.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								With so many "mine, craft better pick, and mine some more" cames out there you might expect that they are all the same, however Edge of space offers more of a survival gameplay that makes the game very interesting.  The crafting system alows you to craft an item without having the exact resource, for example.  instead of neading sand it might say Raw/mineral  which means you can use any dirt/metal/ or stone for this part of the recipe.  The vertical map design makes the gameplay more interesting as well.  The world is made up of floating islands of varying sizes and the dificulty and enviornmental hazards increase the lower you go.  I truly have high hopes for this game and I recommend you try it as well.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												CAUTIOUS RECOMMENDATION:As of now this game has a solid start. The premise is good and the skill tree is interesting, easy, and fun to make your way through. The game itself is still a bit buggy, with framerate on a singleplayer world as if you were lagging on a multiplayer one. The UI also leaves you wanting something a bit better and easier to use. However, the developers are still putting time into fixing up the game so I am hopeful that issues such as the framerate and UI are addressed. There is also a drastic increase of difficulty as you move deeper into the world, as the enemies become much faster and stronger than you really have any feasible hope to overcome...which means lots and lots of deaths, a minor issue. It just begins to feel grindy and repetitive after the silly penguins and/or bears kill you out of nowhere for the 100th time while you are minding your on business.

												Unity strikes again - well, it's not Unity's fault, but bad developers love to use Unity to inflict bad, unfinished products on Steam. This is basically almost a sci-fi ripoff of Terraria, it's a 2D platformer, lots of promise, no real reward.   They put some effort in, but ultimately a game should be fun.   And really, we've advanced beyond the limitation of PCs only capable of rendering graphics in 2D.  There's no reason at all to go for this.   Uninteresting, clunky interface, bland gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								There are many reviews that go ionto specifics about the pros and cons of this game, so mine is going to be short and sweet:As it stands, it is not worht the $12.99 I paid. I really want to like it, but it is clumsy, aimless, and unnecessarily challenging. A poor user interface only makes it more glaringly obvious that similar games are better. The art style for the characters is a nice touch, but the textures for the more common things like dirt and mud are ugly at best. The music needs work and there are some game-ending glitches. Wait to purchase this one until it has some polish. I wish I could say "more polish" but it feels like they haven't even started yet. I'll be going back to Starbound for the time being.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game shouldn't even be in early access. I just played multiplayer with a friend and with-in 5 minutes the game crashed. The in game window that notified me that the game crashed wouldn't even close. The Ok button doesn't even work. So you are forced to terminate the program to close it. I mean come on the Ok button doesn't even work. Other thing to know. Game is very unclear on what to do and how to do it. Many many many bugs.  They are constantly deleting the worlds you create so don't plan on getting very far before its deleted. So you are forced to start from the beginning again. You may say "well the games still in early access." Yes it is but that's no excuse. I mean the OK button doesn't even work. That's not early access that's just poor programing. They didn't even check to see if what they programed worked. They just enter code and assume it works with out checking it. That's why there are so many bug. This game has potential but the makers really need to wake up. It almost seems like they have given up on their own game. Save yourself some money and don't buy this. You will regret it. There are many way better sandbox games available that will not disappoint you like this one disappointed me. So sad to see a game that could be great frustrate me so much I don't feel like playing it anymore.Don't let the trailer fool you!!

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Edge of Space game team presents nicely polished product. Proven concept of Terraria taken to space works very nicely. Constant flow of updates ensures new content as well as bug fixes and patches that are already polishing the game despite its early access. Content is already rich in current build, more biomes are coming and planned. I personally hope for linux support which is currently not planned but there is only minor thing as it was not promised in the first place. Sound part is nothing to be ashamed of. Catchy song in main menu proves this 100%. Graphic is nice and art fits the theme very well. Interesting design of enemies should be mentioned. Where else are you going to meet bear with rocket launcher on its back or legions of crabs swarming you all directions.Early access is a big thing recently and it's up to us, gamers, to drive it in the right direction by supporting the developers who deserve it and excluding those who don't. Very responsive community management of EoS to all concerns shows how developer-community relationship should look like. This is certainly one of the best parts of the experience. Handyman Studios shows how early access should be done. By very active approach they are building nice community and nice reputation.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDITED AS OF VERSION 0.3765, 3/31/2015I was going to leave my old review below to compare, but Steam has a character limit so I didn't. Consider this first paragraph a big ♥♥♥♥-you to whoever implemented a character limit ON REVIEWS.Now, the actual thing.First I want to acknowledge issues I had previously that have been fixed, the foremost of which is the ability to craft better weaponry. The devs clearly listened to their player community on this one, replacing the old system with a way of generating research data and using THAT progress to create better guns (and better everything else as well!) The ridiculous placeholder drops on the second biome flora have been replaced with the real deal, and though I suspect it took me about as long to get there as the last time (seeing as I have neither x,y coordinates nor a map nor my old world to reference for comparison) I found the trip less crappy for having a weapon that can KILL THINGS. This is a major improvement over the last attempt.Some of the new tools available include better saws and picks. THANK YOU, DEVS. THANK YOU SO MUCH! Being able to mine -quickly- makes generating both resources and science xp (used for science) much, much faster and more reasonable to accomplish. I am also fairly certain that either the costs of chests (in terms of aluminum) have gone down or the availability of aluminum has increased: either way, THANK YOU AGAIN. Early game resource management sucked the last time, much less so now.Combat got more fun. This is partly due to the fact that I CAN KILL THINGS NOW because my gun NO LONGER HAS TRAINING WHEELS. Seriously, I cannot say enough how this particular change makes the game better (and I also cannot say enough how confused I am that the old loot % system was used AT ALL before, eminently terrible as it is: good change is good). The enemies feel overall a bit less the same, and I genuinely live in terror of those little blue bugs in the second biome. Guh.Now for the less cool stuff.Screen shake. Cool effect, but this (like controller rumble) should always have an off switch. Making it non-optional is excessively lame to your players.Weaponry NEEDS a key that reloads it that is NOT shared with another function. Maybe the R button? Just a thought.Disabling jetpacks in headhunter temples. This is kind of awful, honestly. I have the entire rest of the game to get used to using my jetpack to maneuver, only to have to change my reflexes in the more challenging parts? Where I would dodge basically without thinking before, here I am forced to remember a change in play that IS NEVER PREFACED while in the middle of genuinely tougher combat. Let the player use the tools you've given them in game. Let them think laterally. Don't feel like you need to take away one of the most fun parts of your game to add "challenge": execution challenge isn't satisfying. Depth challenge is satisfying. At the very least give some warning about the change beforehand.Weapon customization needs to happen. When reload times are long, a mod to make them shorter is muy bueno. When ammo counts are small, a mod to make them bigger is muy bueno. Not having this sort of thing to replace the old random weapon stats system? No bueno.Tl;dr, The changes I've seen are massive, and merit me changing from a not recommended to a recommended. Way to go, game devs! You guys genuinely fixed things that were broken, and what I'm seeing now is much, much more enjoyable than when I bought it. High hopes, guys.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Edge of Space takes dedication to be appreciated. I recomment this game because I've grown to enjoy it after about 2 months of intensive in-game experimentation, but it was a winding road with a dull beginning.The biggest flaw with EoS is its glaringly lacking help menus. This is a significant flaw because the opportunities offered by the game far outweigh the amount of helpful information about the different tools and installations you can craft. This can lead to extended periods of aimless mining and construction that can feel pointless and frustratingly anti-climactic (I've been surprised quite often at how little I could accomplish during long hours of continuous play because of a lack of clear objectives).That being said, I've grown to enjoy Edge of Space very much. Here's a bit of context: you are dropped on a foreign planet after a spaceship crash and evacuation. Your codex (the help menus) is obviously incomplete and written very much like the entries in The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy: unfocused and essentially devoid of any useful information beyond vague hints at a distant purpose. As the player, it is your job to extrapolate meaning -and ultimately results- from what little help and guidance you are offered by your interplanetary employer.Edge of Space plays very much like the old NES and SNES Metroid games, with the added elements of terraforming and crafting. The bottom line is that once you've "figured out" the basics, the game works. Very well.So, provided you're willing to tolerate fuzzy objectives and the occasional quirks, you should enjoy Edge of Space for what it is: a wacky, competely over-the-top sandbox with a lot of potential and a ton of fun! And laser sharks!FREE TIP: Keep digging deeper. And when you think you've gone deep enough, keep going. Edge of Space offers a BIG world!

								Attention! Do not buy this game YET!The game is playable but unfinished. The game starts with this vague tutorial. Ofcouse, tutorials are there to help you in-game but this tutorial is kind of weird. A tutorial should show what is really good in a game. But instead of giving that to you, they give you this level of an depressive room I guess.The game plays laggy and unsmooth. It feels just like a flash game. Seriously. In the trailer you see smooth NPC's/Players, but when I bought the game and started it, it wasn't that at all. I bought the game to quick. I'm a really big fan of Terarria and when I saw this, I was completely sold. But I felt betrayed when I played the tutorial. Yes, it is an Early Access Game. But do not buy this because you thought the trailer looked ''cool'' or whatever . (Me) But I do see alot of potential in this game and I hope that the developers make a great game of it. And that is because I DO RECOMMEND this game. Developers , please make a good game of this.- Booker

number of helpful: 16 of 34 people (47%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has suffered mass criticism from players, critics and just gernerally people don't like it. I DO NOT see why people hate it...This game is great...Better than Terraria? Nope but still better than other side-scrollers and also you cannot compare it to Teraria as they are pratically two different games.First off, you create a charater, mine an awesome-looking female with a mask which screams ♥♥♥♥ off to any crab,jellyfish or any 'badguy' that thinks they can take a piece of me. Then we have the tutorial. I have read reviews where they say that the tutorial didn't help or it didn't give enough depth...well I'm sorry but you must be playing a different game. The tutorial has a video in the bottom right corner of the screen which demostrates how to do stuff and what you needed to do in order to advance through the tutorial. Yes I admit that at times the video played a bit fast so I couldn't keep up with the voice BUT there was text above the video so I didn't even have to worry about it.Once the tutorial finishes you are thrown straight into the world with little knowledge of what to do next. My thoughts were to build a base...Captain Obvious here...Digging is simple, just like other games, and it wasn't long before I had a decent amount of materials in order to make a base. Now I had two options, Build it in the sky surrounded by jellyfish or on the ground overrun with plants and creepy crawleys. My choice...the sky. Now I'm not going to run it for you...Try the game you will like it. The ideas that are in this game are truely awesome...There are different guns and ones I would of never thought of such as the Ark Light which shoots torches for quick and easy light...'Oh boy I wish that was in Terraria' was said a few times.Good side-scroller...CheckGood ideas...CheckFlaws...a few but none ruined the experienceGame of the year...Maybe not but still goodTerraria or Edge of Space...Terraria but I'm am still a devoted fan This game will grow...New patches often...New features...Yes I've played only an hour or so but my first hour was a good experience so here's to the next 2218947947918 hours of my life :D

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												8/10-don't trust the current steam rating, the majority of the negative reviews are 1-2 years old, this game deserves at least a 80% rating. (imho)-fresh outta EA, this games has a few little bugs here and there, which is only natural. but there's certainly nothing game breaking.-unlike other devs, you can be sure that these guys will fix bugs within a reasonable time and answer 99% of your questions in the forum.-similar to terraria and minecraft, this game won't hold your hand: there are some npcs and a in game guide (codex) that give you some hints, but quite a few things you'll have to figure out by yourself, so at least bring a IQ of 80 with you.-taking terraria as a reference value, EoS does some things better (again, imho):--> better ambiente: mainly due to the excellent in game music, EoS feels beautifully melancholic and mature without being depressing, it makes you thoughtful. coming back to terraria, you'll figure yourself on a happy LSD trip.--> better in game music (see above).--> placing tiles works smooth and easy from the beginning.--> beautiful art style, and it gets even more beautiful the deeper you go, especially the individual zone backgrounds!--> devs are 10/10 straight.--> progression is more versatile: get exp, spend in many different tech trees, find hidden stat upgrades in the world, random stats and bonuses for weapons.--> you can fly from the getgo with a jetpack, yay! (watch your fuel though!)Keep in mind: Overall, Terraria in it's current state is better, naturally. Terraria started this whole 2d sandbox genre: Due to a astronomically higher budget and a longer development time, you can't really beat it. If you played Terraria ad nauseam though, if you want to play something similar yet in many ways different, get EoS.

Early Access Review
								I'm giving this game a recomend.Keep an eye on this game. I enjoy it, and I believe it will be a really good game when it's finished.I don't usually write reviews for early access games, but I'm giving this a positive because it has so many unjust downvotes from people who didn't give the game a chance. I believe the review system as-is doesn't quite work for early access games and needs a redesign that would be more fair to the product and it's changes over time (or lack there-of) and the reviewers who give their opinion.The biggest positives of this game:If it has a bug, the devs will fix it as quickly as possible.They update the game regularly.The devs really listen to the feedback, and replies from the community managers and devs themselves are often.I enjoy the game and the gameplay. This one is last because it's an early access game that is unfinished and somewhat unpolished, but I'm positive this game will keep getting better and better (as it already has been), and it will actually reach a 1.0 version and players will be happy with it.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												This game is ready for primetime and worth the cost, with active developers who have made a fun project.If you like Terraria, you might like this - it's not as crazy-full of content, but it doesn't have the benefit of time and money that Terraria has had.  It's fun and different enough from Terraria that it presents some unique value.There are a couple cons: balancing and game progression.  You get relatively little guidance in the overall 'purpose' of the game - what you're trying to accomplish, all the features, crafting progression, etc.  This can be annoying, especially absent a robust wiki which Terraria possesses.  Moreover, the damage done by enemies is all over the scale, and it's hard to predict how a particular tier of armor will prepare you for the next group of baddies.  Right now it feels like enemies can swarm very quickly and do crazy amounts of damage quickly.
