content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since I first started playing EOS I have noticed a ton of improvement.  The game gets regular updates and the devs are very involved with the community here on Steam.  One thing I really enjoy about EOS is the multi-leveled crafting.  Each resource is needed from the start to the end, so I don't feel as though I'm waisting my time gathering dirt, mud and rock on the way to the more valuable resourses.  You unlock new crafting opportunities by earning XP.  With this XP  you can "buy" data.  The data (once you get enough) gives access to better equipment.  I really like this system, I'm hoping that this is the one the devs settle on.  There are a few frustrating things about the game, such as the amount of time required to gather resourses for the equipment you need to progress.  Also, much like Terraria, the player is super vulnerable at the start of the game (this can lead to much frustration for players not accustomed to this type of game). The issue I struggle with the most is the lack of direction in the game.  The crafting is so much fun, but I have no idea what certain resourses are for or how some of the better equipment is crafted.  If you get too lopsided with buying data from one or two catergories you will be totally lost.  Make sure you unlock the data evenly to avoid any problems.In conclusion, I totally recomend EOS.  I remember being frustrated as hell when playing Terraria after it first came out, but as time went along and I slowly learned new things the game became really fun.  I am 100% convinced that EOS is offering the same type of experience, who knows, maybee it will be even better than Terraria when all is said and done.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated review from my last one.In my previous review I stated how bad this game was and how it seemed to be going nowhere. It felt amateurish and pointless. The tutorial was vague and taught very little.That was at the beginning of the year and I recently reinstalled the game to see what was new and if things have improved. I'd like to talk about these changes after some brief gameplay:The first impression that I got was that the tutorial is way better. They aren't always necessary for this kind of game, but before I was baffled on how to build things, now I know. Immediately you are given a gun, fairly weak, but it does the trick, whereas before there seemed no way to kill enemies other than using the mining laser on them or the plasma saw or whatever it was.So what do I think now? Alot better, my hat is off to you guys for improving upon a royal mess. Not perfect, but still not released. At this rate of improvement I am confident, however, that things will get ironed out.Some minor problems:For some reason the install for a game of this type and look is enormous. 1.5 gb download and 3gb disc space. Where it all goes, I'm unsure, but as the art seems to be bitmap and bitmap has large file sizes, I'm inclined to think that it is that.Screen tearing is quite bad.Bloody snails pushing me around. Probably by design but annoying.The worlds seem extremely small. Could perhaps do with you being able to go to other planets or at least make the worlds alot bigger.Overall, my opinion has swayed. I see potential in this game and I am impressed with the improvements. Keep up the good work.

Early Access Review
								Mixed is not true... Simple and plain. If you have been with these developers as long as I have been so far, you would know that the developers are going to make this game better then Terraria has been. Dont get me wrong by any means, Terraria is a AMAZING GAME. But this one shows so many new great changes in the games function. Edge of Space comes with great function and it also has gotten a great face lift from its game friend Terraria. Yes. I only have 1.1 hours on the game. Dont let that fool you; I have many hours on Terraria and have been comparing changes between them. The game still shows much progress and they have not even hit 1.0v. The tutorial is one of the best early access tutorials I have seen yet with very few bugs if any now.  Don’t let the mixed reviews throw you off too much. Early access game with this much function is nothing to be mixed about. This game will be a good one.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overall I would definitely recommend this game, as of the writing of the review the game is still in Early access so i can only imagine it growing into a HUGE game, if your not to sure as to whether you should buy this yet then definitly keep it on your wishlist or follow it,I have just bought this for myself today, played a total of about 2 hours on it so far and still just learning the basics, in my opinion it does have a steep learning curve, its a game that you have to plan what your doing ahead of where you currently are, the restrictions on the crafting can seem abit unfair at times (its just making you explore more and be more active in the world your on), unlike some similar games it does have a backstory meaning it can be good for beginners and advanced players alike. Also for those wondering if they can run it, I have a pretty basic set-up that ive ran it on; 2.0ghz quadcore processor with AMD Radeon 8400 on board graphics and 6gb of ram, i can get a solid 30FPS most of the time (trees falling causes a small amount of lag,)

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												So first off, let's just say I don't particularly like this game. And when I say that I don't like this game, I mean that I really don't like this game.I got this game on release day, installed it on release day, played around 2 hours on release day. It was a weird experience to say the least. I think that pretty much everyone who picked up this game on release day was expecting something that was literarily just "terraria in space". This game is anything but that. From a terraria perspective, the characters are a weird size, seeming just too big. The game is similar to starbound with the way you mine and build things, but starbound just feels more complete. The game has a weird graphics style that just doesn't quite complete. It seems a bit rough around the edges. I am not saying that no one could love it, just that I can't. If you own Terraria and want a similar experience, then get Starbound. "But I already have Starbound" you say? Wait for an update to Terraria and then you will be right.If you own Startbound and want a similar experience, then get Terraria. "But I already have Terraria" you say? Wait for an update to Starbound and then you will be right.I cannot recommend this game for the simple reason of there are already games out there that do everything this game does but better; want a great 2D building/exploring/sandbox experience? Get Terraria. Want a great 2D space building/exploring/sandbox experience that isn't quite complete, but still great?. Get Starbound. Want some weird space thing? Get Defy Gravity.P.S. Just as a warning for this game, there are save wipesP.P.S. I have also played this game since release day, enough to find form valid arguments about this game.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the December 2014 version of the game.  As it currently stands, it holds alot of promise, but suffers from usability problems.  For example. there is nothing you can do with your old gear - when you make new equipment, you can't salvage or sell your old items that are no longer useful, you have to delete them (or store them if you're a pack rat).  Also, the UI is still pretty rough - some recipe names don't match up to what they create.  This is a problem when you are trying to figure out where the 'crafting bench 1' recipe is, because its actually the 'computerized work bench' recipe.Overall its decently fun, but the clunkiness of the UI drove me to give up on figuring out what I needed to do next.

content:

Early Access Review
								Fun if you like buggy Beta games. For a 3 month period or so, i couldn't even load the game without it CTD! The dev's fixed that, but it's still a long march to the finish it seems. Oh hey guys, Terreria content! C'mon, get some original ideas for Christ's sake! Pixelated avatars and a big skull boss do not make me want to re-install. Cool original content, maybe, but not re-hashed ideas borrowed from another game, pshhh! ******MMORPG.com - Best Indie RPG at PAX East 2014****** <--- this bothers me, because it's NOT an RPG, and it's being rated by an MMORPG report, which furthers my distain. Firstly, it's a sandbox crafting game, with zero RPG elements. Sorry, but being in control of an avatar does not constitute, otherwise EVERY game would be an RPG. And just because you can augment items does NOT mean it's an RPG, nor is that even an element. That being said, NOT AN RPG, and it's certainly not the best, and I'm sure there were dozens at PAXE2014 lol. In order for it to be a Role Playing Game, there needs to be an implemented stroy line with varried choices offered to allow alternate paths of progression.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Disappointing. I wouldn't recommend to friends.The release version of the game feels more like a version that should be releasing on to Steam Early Access for the first time, to go through those last few months of finishing, polishing and feedback before actual release. It still feels in a rather "beta" state, which is disappointing for a game that's already been in Early Access for two years.For instance rockets are represented in the player's inventory UI as an ammo type, but there is actually no weapon that requires it, nor any recipe to make it. An unfinished stub of a feature like this shouldn't be left in the release version, it's misleading and cringingly "beta".I wanted to like it, I like the genre and loved Terraria. I wouldn't have stuck with playing this for so long if I didn't, and I like some of what it does differently. I could list other problems I perceive with it, but instead I'll just say that overall It's a disappointment, and probably needs another year in the oven.Edit: It's been over a year since I posted my review, and a year since the last minor patch. It doesn't seem like we can expect any major patches, and I don't think the game will ever reach a state that I could consider finished, so my recommendation is unlikely to change.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: This review is only for the game as of 8/2/2014The big drawback for this game is the user interface (which is so bad that I gave up after less than an hour, hence the lack of play time). At its current condition, the UI is far too complex and spread out to be used effectively. There's something like 5-10 different 'windows' that you can bring up, each with their own UI's and submenus, all of which the player must navigate in order to effectively play the game. Did I mention that the windows can only be brought up by hotkey, and have no onscreen hint as to which hotkey brings up what?Compare this to similiar games such as Starbound,  Terraria and Minecraft, which are far more streamlined in terms of UI. Starbound is the most complex out of the three, but even that has only a couple of "main" user windows - the inventory/equipping/status menu, and the crafting menu. Minecraft has a similar setup, with a combined inventory/equipping window and a crafting window, plus some other assorted windows depending on gameplay style. Terraria has only one "window", which is the inventory/crafting/equipping/status overlay that is accessed via the escape key.The graphics are ok, and the gameplay is nice, but unless the user interface gets a rework, I wouldn't recommend playing this game - you'll be stuck navigating windows, menus, and submenus half the time.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off, this game is amazing even though I haven't played it recently so I don't understand why there are bad reviews. I hardly ever write a review but I felt this game is worth my time reviewing. With all the new updates, I am actually going to set out some free time to play it again. In fact, I enjoyed this game even before all the big updates and patches were made (wipes included).  It is similar to Terraria in the aspect of genre but uniquely different in terms of content. Edge of Space speaks for itself what it's about (almost). You are an alien thrown into an unknown "world". Whether it was a planet or on an asteroid, even I'm not quite sure. Everyone complains it's hard to grasp but there is a tutorial at the beginning which I happened to accidentally skipped. Even so, I didn't find the game entirely hard to follow if you know the basics: collect materials, build a house/base, kill monsters, etc. Not to mention all the cool pets and mounts you can create. Come on...a laser to collect materials and space guns?! Jet packs to fly! It really sticks to the sci-fi feel. Oh, I would also like to add I love how smooth the movements are in this game.The challenge is in figuring how everything works and the satisfaction when you do. Since last time that I played, the only thing I really would complain about is how each character was bounded to certain worlds if they were made in multiplayer/single player. You can't select any character to load into a world if that character wasn't made in that particular world. Some materials that can be collected in single player were unable to be gathered in multiplayer (but before I stopped playing this issue was already fixed). There weren't as many boss fights as I would like and their drops weren't always anything special. Overall, when I stopped playing I was merely waiting for more content to be released. I've seen a lot of reviews comparing this to Terraria and Starbound. If you like those games more then play those games instead of comparing it to this one. Why? Because if this game was exactly like Terraria then...that defeats the purpose of making a uniquely different 2D Sandbox game. Also, if you hop into the game for less than an hour and deem that it's awful then you're not even giving the game a chance. I would also like to repeat that this game is in EARLY ACCESS. There will be bugs and the sort so if you don't want a game that's in DEVELOPMENT, I would advise you to wait if you have no patience for an unfinished game rather than buy it and give it a bad review because it has a lot of potential.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ The crafting is clunky and nonsensical, making machine rifles out of dirt and mud and other things. It is also clear that it's aping Starbound's layout but being even more irritating and difficult to use, needing to push the craft button multiple times in a specific place for it to even work. the worlds are impossible to navigate without dying from a massive fall, there is almost no character customization unless you count the person's face. And just their face. Just get starbound. This game is fugly and the enemies are nearly impossible to fight due to them being tiny and do half of your health bar's worth of damage on a hit, and utter lack of melee weapons. Now for me, the aesthetic is garbage except for maybe the backgrounds and sky of the game. It's like one of those minecraft knockoffs with 'HD' textures that look like garbage and not because of the fact it's a voxel-based sandbox world building game. Do not get this game if you are thinking of getting it over starbound.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer:  This is an early access title, so as always, buyer beware.  It may or may not make it to the finish line, but from what I've experienced over a few years development cycle with this game, it's team is nothing if not dedicated and focused on the goal of pushing this game to release, so I'm fairly confident it will be released, just not as hastily as other titles.  The question to be answered, is whether or not this game is worth buying right now.  While it's in the same sandbox genre as popular (and depending on who you ask, infamous) titles such as terraria, minecraft, and starbound, the graphical style sets it apart fairly decisively.  It's not super high-res, but the cartoonish yet realistically proportioned characters are a nice change from the pixelized Devs-Don't-Give-A-Damn you sometimes see.  What can I say, some people like pixels, others don't.  For my part, I do like pixels.  Anyway, see the screenshots for a good idea of the art style.  At the very least, the art style is consistent throughout the game as far as I've seen.The devs have taken an interesting direction in the way of progression, in that every action you take, whether it be killing monsters, felling alien vegetation, or just digging up some mud, nets you experience that can be spent toward research in the area of your interest.  It's an interesting component that I suppose promotes cooperation and teaming up with other players who can fill the gaps in your research to help fully kit out your base.  Materials aren't enough to build all that you need, you actually need the experience and research level to create equipment and objects, unlike terraria and starbound where you only need touch a component to know how to put it together.The alien environments don't take the typical planetoidal approach to world generation, and instead you find your avatar cast adrift on a sea of floating islands, which you can hop from one to the next with a handy jetpack, which you get from playing through the tutorial at the very beginning of the game.  It's necessary to build a suit of armor with exposure protection in order to delve deeper into the world's depths, so progression is a multi-pronged challenge as you have to gather experience and then spend it correctly in order to build a base and equip yourself for the dangers you'll find in the lower levels of the planet.There's not much else for me to say about this title, but if you're still on the fence after hearing all of this, know that the game is still in development, and in order to expedite the process your characters and worlds may be wiped.  So bear that in mind if it's a factor in your decision.For my part, I bought it at 20 dollars a while back, and like where the game is going.  I trust this dev team enough to get the job done eventually, and really look forward to when it's finished.  If you have the money to spare and want to put it to a project, and this one sounds good based on all you've heard, great.  Honestly, this either is your cup of tea or isn't, and that's okay.  I will say that it's my cup of tea, and an interesting and very different entrant to the 2d sandbox genre.  I don't regret buying the game.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Shogun wanted to love this game but my friends had to make new Characters just to get past the starting doors because it just picks if your charater is gonna be able to countinue on or be trapped forever in the starting room, but moving past all that we never gave up and made it to the end and this is what happend.The very start we all picked different things to level up so we could all contribute in a team effort to go faster together.We all built a base and struggled very hard to get our base working correctly with the power needed for each thing you place just so your stations will work so you can craft your things.We tried out mounts and found them to be the worst thing in the game to invest your resources in for every reason you can think of, you cant take them into worthless dungeons, they die forever, they cost a ton and get killed super fast and are too slow to avoid damage as well as too big to get around like you thought they would be used for but no jetpacks are the best for getting around and always will be.Dungeons are the most worthless waste of life in the game right next to Mounts, the gear you get from them is outdated the minute you can gather enough parts to make the dungeon key to enter it and the dungeons are so bugged you can't complete them most the time and the bosses are harder then the gear you have at the time to fight them to win, also most of your things dont work in the dungeon like jetpacks,mounts,doors, even entering the dungeon will some times crash your game and the doors teleport you to random locations some times making you unable to back track or even go forward or even leave the place alive so everything about it is a waste of life.and at the end of the game you find yourself grinding parts and EXP to make your medic gear as well as waiting for your carbon fibers to be made because the dang machines just decide to eat your refined metals and not make any because the game is broken and super coolent is broken in the same way as well.So in the end your friends all end up thinking the same thing as well as yourself...Explorer armor is the best along with builder just so you can progress the game and its all about trying to get as far down as you can as fast as you can and all the side stuff to explore is broken because the far right of the map crashes your game and its just boring,filled with buggs that have never been fixed and have been around since the start of this game and they seem to be ignoring the community that has been reporting these buggs, im pretty sure a team of 3 people is working on the game and the rest are streamers and sellsmen that dont work at all and just screw around on tumblr talking about their feels.  Sorry for bad English~Shogun

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												I have over 100 hours into this game and I've been here since Alpha.  I've played through about 3 revisions of the game, so about 40 hours or so per playthrough.  The game went thru some major changes since Alpha, and even though it's not 100% finished, and hasn't gotten any updates as of lately, it was an extremely fun game to play.  The fact it's unfinished really doesn't change much, as there's no main storyline, it's more of an exploration, creation, and upgrade game.The Penguin music alone is worth the money I paid for this game while it's on sale.  There's 3 completed biomes of enemies, thousands of items, I think like 45+ full sets of armor, 3 seperate lines with different attribute upgrades and abilities, and a bunch of alien techs to find that upgrade your passives.In short I'm completely happy with my purchase.  I hope they add more content in the future but I well got my moneys worth.  This game in alpha felt more complete then most of the crap I buy nowadays anyways.  It plays ALOT like Terraria.     I have no idea why so many haters due to one biome being unfinished, but I'd totally recommend this game, especially if you like Terraria.  Don't listen to the haters.

There's 3 completed biomes of enemies, thousands of items, I think like 45+ full sets of armor, 3 seperate lines with different attribute upgrades and abilities, and a bunch of alien techs to find that upgrade your passives.In short I'm completely happy with my purchase.  I hope they add more content in the future but I well got my moneys worth.  This game in alpha felt more complete then most of the crap I buy nowadays anyways.  It plays ALOT like Terraria.     I have no idea why so many haters due to one biome being unfinished, but I'd totally recommend this game, especially if you like Terraria.  Don't listen to the haters.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I went into Edge of Space, hoping for something of a cross between Terraria and Starbound. Unfortunately, it did not deliver.Firstly, there are several menus. too many menus, assigned to keys that you could possibly change, but why? why are there so many?Navigating story text is also a pain, and the tutorial is horrible. it conveys the controls, but the way it does it is more of a chore it has to do, ticking off parts of the game on a checklist. You don't feel like you've learned anything.Then there is death. this is perhaps my biggest axe to grind. it turns death into some complex process involving crafting a chamber, and using rods, and I just give up at that point.I spawned in, tried to slowly edge down from the top of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ asteroid field it dump-ed me into really? couldn't have started with rolling hills? something normal??) and died. I had no idea what to do or how to do it.Edge of Space is a game full of potential. however, it is far, far too complicated. it has a LOT of work to do to get the gameplay user-friendly, and the death mechanic needs some serious reworking.It feels like this game is trying to be terraria 2.0, while also trying to be starbound, but not grasping what makes starbound fun. It takes the sci-fi all right, but it takes the grungy abandoned-spaceship theme. Not the adventuring and simplistic controls.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												The positives: Uh...... it has a terraria reference?The neutral stuff: Kinda grindy and mining is slow. The stuff that are pretty big flaws but could have been okay:  A "research" system. In other words, not just one, but TWO methods of forcing you to work your butt off to get a incredible reward!..... Just kidding, you 'll also get stuck behind so many progression walls there are enough for several mazes of utter misery with the slow mining and finding out SURPRISE!you now need a new workstation. Alright, i'll go dig out ANOTHER massive crater to get some XP so I can research that. (An hour later) Alright let's see what I need for this thing. Looks like some uranium and a ton of aluminum (That's not actually a recipe but an example of the sorts of recipes there are) Time to go get some aluminum!.... Got that, what about uranium? Oh... I can't mine it. So what do I need to make a laser to (hopefully) mine it? Looks like more giant crater making for me. Hooray. Three cheers for whoever decided holding down on your mouse and moving it for hours was a neccecary game mechanic.What killed the game: There's no satisfaction to ANYTHING. Completing quests? Grindy and unrewarding. Exploring? Fun until you realize all the terrain is the same. Progression? There's progression? Where? Where'd you find precious progression? WHERE?!?! Combat? Yes there is! It's combatting the woefully weak jellyfish who die after about 20 seconds of holding the mouse button down! There isn't even different fighting styles. Sure you can pick between "pew pew" guns, "pew... BOOM" guns or "PEW............... PEW" guns but compare that to terraria where you can get a massive variety of weapons, from classic swords to lances to boomerangs to flails to variants that deal more damage, look cool, fire off an array of projectiles from various actions (hitting enemies, when swinging, whenever there's an active hitbox...) or inflicting debuffs. And that's just THE MOST BORING CATEGORY. Not to say they aren't cool, it's just they're the trump 6 out of sixes and tens. There's also guns, bows, bow/gun hybrids, spellbooks wands+rods and staffs, throwing lances, throwing knives, shuriken, yo-yos,  a portal gun, a voodoo doll, and that's just the stuff I thought of in a few minutes. Sorry about the massive rant. Overall, it's a 2.5/10 on the scale of games that aren't stupendous but aren't one of "those" games. You know them. Zelda CGI, Flight Control, Slaughtering Grounds. The type that get videos dedicated to laughing at the sheer amount of crap that they are. Anyway, hopefully this helped the devs and the people who are thinking about buying it. Here's some games that hold up to the 1$ per hour of fun rule. Terraria: a 157 hour epic, and i've only gotten to late prehardmode and skill is the limiting factor in that. Cave Story+: The original indie game with new graphics and a handful of extra content including difficulty settings, new characters and a new level cut from the original game because it was apparently too dark (clones of a friendly character who attack you) which makes no sense considering it involves drowning as well as being forced to kill a character who was fed the red flowers (you'll understand if you play it) along with a character who tried to protect his friends and killed them accidentally. Seriously. It also has multiple endings. Undertale: AWESOME game involving SPOILER SPOILER who SPOILERs SPOILER. It's kinda loses half its appeal if you already know the story. Not to say the story is great and the gameplay is bad; all of undertale is fantastic. It's just that the story and gameplay are SO interconnected that spoiling one makes the other not quite have the impact it's supposed to. Also, bring a friend and a tissue or two. Seriously. Undertale is the only game ever to make me laugh so hard or cry anything exept tears of frustration.

Early Access Review
								Sadly, I cannot recommend this game for a variety of reasons:1) the GUI is quite clunky, and not intuitive.2) the gameplay is choppy, and slow3) there are random words/text obviously placed in the game.I know this game is really early development, but come on! At least have some generic description of the items or dialogue! Not "Insert Description Here"...I think the problem with this game is that it has POTENTIAL, but unfortunately the majority of the kinks have not been ironed out, and unfortunately, could be the downfall of this game.Don't get me wrong, I love Sandbox games.I love Space.I love exploration.Unfortunately, this game is way less than mediocre, and is hurting because of it.If I could rate this out of 10 stars, it would receive a 1.7/10.Please fix the problems with this game that would make it much higher in my book!I would love to review this game again, maybe in 6 months or so, but as of now, stay away from it.

								There are some things wrong with the game right now, but they still have time to change it before the full release. I feel that the tutorial is a bit lengthy (maybe just because of the reading). There are very apparent things that are wrong with the game and their internal testing (if they even did any) should have picked up on it.Overall, the game seems pretty fun and I trust the creators to make this a really good game.

								Honestly... I just don't like this game. I love Terraria and Minecraft though. (like Terraria, I don't think it should be compared to Minecraft). The game just doesn't look good in my opinion, is very slow paced, and is just generally boring. number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's really hard to believe that this game is "finished" and shall be released September 2015, at the time of my review it's August 14, 2015.I really can't get into the look and feel of this game and its game play, it certainly is no Terraria or Starbound, and there's nothing really unique in the first 1.5 hours that makes me want to keep playing. There's just the prospect to mine blocks, or grind creatures for XP, to "unlock" things that I can then build.I think that the UI is terrible, it's visually not appealing, it gives next to no feedback, and it's unresponsive. But I think I already read that 2 years ago. Once you mass up (unlock) items to build it gets rather hard to use. The components required to build things are questionable at best. Dirt, mud, clay, rock, to build a large variety of items, huh.There are billboard missions you can take to get more rare stuff (is it the only way?) like aluminium or uranium, they are simple and seem buggy. For example, having two missions to collect 50 dirt immediately completes both if you have 49+ dirt in your inventory, and collect just one more piece of dirt.When you play the tutorials where you need to shoot humanoid training dummies, it becomes immediately apparent that the hit boxes are... let's just say, you have to hit them in a certain spot, their legs for example are completely off the hit box boundary.If you have neither played Terraria, or the Terraria 1.3 update, I'd recommend that instead, or keeping an eye on Starbound. I've put over 100 hours into Starbound around December 2013, when they first made a public Alpha release, which really puts a unique spin on the whole Terraria feel and it has an absolutely amazing soundtrack.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								So at one point in starting to play this I thought "where'd they get Starbound's source code from?" and then realised it was just a little bit more than that. I'm not sure what to think of this, but I know one thing: over the years I've been playing games and then trying to recreate them in my own way, trying to get some idea of good game mechanics. This is what would happen if I successfully did that after playing Terraria and Starbound. The reason I can't recommend this is that I can't recommend Starbound either, - and Starbound even adhered to certain game design principles Edge of Space does not. For example, DLC or content purchases - and I can't help but feel like it's Starbound remade. /impressionsSince reviews aren't just opinion meters and-Oh, they are. Well here's a breakdown anyway:ArtThe art is quite good, but I can't look past the animations, which I personally don't much like. They seem slightly unnatural somehow, as if forced or overacted. The music is okay, and at times reminds of a certain game that parallels EoS a lot.Then again, there isn't a whole lot of it yet, so I can't be sure.UsabilityOne thing I quite like is how the game is actually somewhat intuitive. I mean it has all that arbitrary stuff where you go through the tiers of equipment and unlock things that you would realistically have beforehand, but I can overlook that since it's an industry standard, no matter how dumb it is. The tutorial goes through the mechanics and controls at lightspeed. Something that's great for someone like I, who plays games like Xonotic, but would be really damn hard for anyone who isn't used to learning new controls extremely quickly. The rest of the game seems to just leave you to do what you want after the tutorial, which is good and bad, depending on how you look at it. GameplayAs usual, sandbox style progression using "tech", and unlocks of new gear.There isn't much emphasis on building, possibly because there's not really much need, and possibly because the small hotbar and needing to manually stock it with stuff all the time is a nightmare, at least coming from games like Starbound which allowed you to place things by picking them up in the inventory. A small issue I have with it, but I'm sure many people would feel the same. Systems, bugs, exploits, map generation, etc.The map is automatically smoothed by making every top corner (tiles y-1 and x±1 are air) 45°. Not a great feature, since building with this in mind can be very annoying. There are too many bugs to go into. I'm hoping this is because it's still in EA. The map generation algorithm is pretty basic. Very similar to Starbound, but less to explore for lack of content so far. out of the few worlds I've looked at, all are the same flattish top island with other small islands above and below. It's a little like an extremely dense asteroid belt. It's not incredible. Overall, this seems kind of interesting, but not so much so that a person who just bought the Weekly Bundle would give it a good review. I don't recommend the game, but I don't recommend not playing it either. It's one of those things where you just don't quite know how it'll turn out.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like Terraria, then yes this is a game to get. True, it is in the early developmental stage and there are a plethora of bugs, incomplete items, and overall balancing issues that still need to be worked out. For a game still well into its beta, i find it damn impressive that it wants me to keep playing as much as it does. Gameplay is not as smooth as i would prefer, e.g. no invinicibility frames upon taking damage, enemies ridiculously hard to hit with guns, having a ceiling on the max amount of ammo you're allowed to have for everything besides phase weapons. In all honesty, I felt that Terraria handled the ammo situation for projectile weapons very well, where you could have as much as you wanted as long as you had inventory space. Reloading of course is something they didn't incorporate but the upper limit on ammo makes projectile weapons nearly obsolete. Haven't tried energy weapons yet, hope they are better, otherwise its sticking to phase weapons forever just because of ammo constraints.Mining can be tedious, as i have not found any new ores or reasons to mine besides the fact i need resources to farm xp from the enemies flying around, and your upgraded picks dont seem to be digging that much faster. Dungeons on here are very exciting to explore, i was amazed when i first discovered the headhunters dungeon, and again when i found maps to other dungeons as you went lower. Transportation mounts, like the raptors, can't teleport with you to different command nodes, which i found to make them  not very useful since you get to them so much later in the game and need to move around between your main base and hub bases quickly. random events that happen are interesting, they are usually pretty tough, although the rewards are severly lacking. Kill x/x monsters and you get a couple blocks of some ore thats not very rare? not worth it. also can we get a map early on? exploring's a ♥♥♥♥♥ without one, even if we have to make it but make it available from a fairly early point please.I am very excited to see this game get completed, hope that this review persuades others to invest in this game and help support the developers.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I understand I only spent a few minutes in this game, but unfortunately that was all I needed.First problem I encountered that immediately threw me into a rage...audio crackling.Normally I would believe this to be some sort of sound driver issue, but as someone who regularly uses Skype, Pandora, numerous other games and software with absolutely zero problem in sound, I found this to be the foreshadowing of the only stain in my library out of (currently) 147 other items. Reinstallation of drivers and the game itself has produced no fix. Fabulous.Second issue, which I should say was already mentioned by someone else in the reviews on this item...sluggish gameplay. It feels like you're trying to swim through molasses. I was trying to gun down uh, floating jellyfish and other unpleasant critters and it felt like I was in a slow-motion Matrix scene (minus the badassery by a long shot, that is).Third issue. There were no prominent enough sound effects for mining or busting something's skull in. I expected some splattering or crumbling or something. What I got was a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor puff noise for most of it. Seriously? What kind of horse crap is this?Fourth issue. I'm very happy I was able to adapt to the game itself as quickly as I did, because the game not pausing with the tutorial UI up in my face was extremely unsettling and left me open to get owned by the nearest hungry maw. Someone with very little experience with games like this will not be so fortunate in the future.Fifth issue. This game  has some sloppy sprite work on the player avatars. Normally I would let this slide, but I know this game has been worked on for quite some time, so no, I am not going to let it go. Hell no. You can definitely tell a lot of the features you're able to add onto the avatar in creation were lazily pasted on. Thankfully, the fitting futuristic artwork helped balance it out.Sixth issue. OH HOW CUTE THE GAME ONLY HAS A RESOLUTION CHANGE OPTION AND V-SYNC FOR GRAPHIC SELECTIONS. LOL WTF IS THIS, 2004?!Edge of Space was supposed to be the answer to the demand of an outer space sandbox game like Terraria. In fact, when it was advertised, it was proclaiming to be better and a bit of a sequel to the installment. What a waste of cyberspace and time! Terraria is everything this game wanted to try to be. You know, functional and good?In fact, if you want a good sandbox game similar to Terraria that occurs in space, either sit down with Minecraft and some mods, or get a game that actually does this♥♥♥♥♥♥right; STARBOUND.Save your money, ladies and gents. This title belongs in the dev studio for quite a few years more before it should touch the stores.I can't believe my friend wasted his money to get this for me. I want to actually pay him twice the amount of what he spent on this game just to compensate for the disgrace I went through in giving this a chance.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												well i hate to say it but this is just a mess multiplayer is non-existant as it currently fails to load most of the time. charecters are restricted to per instance/world loading (you cant have charecters in multiplayer on both you and someone elses world.) the game is very laggy often crashes even in single player. the multiplayer uses a vulnerable port that often cannot be opened/hosted while an antivirus is running or a firewall is active. finaly multiplayer isnt easy to setup as you need to know how to forward ports find your ip and other technical knowledge that most players like me lack completeley.the singleplayer lacks a story and most of all is very repetative each 3 layers adds 2 new ores.... wow.... it takes hours to actualy find most of these ores in a descent quantity and often the mobs kill you before you can mine it. talking of mobs they seem to spawn everywhere especialy in the 3rd 6th and 9th islands the 6th island is inacessable to players without armor found 3 layers deeper (that you then wouldent be able to craft) the games drop rates need a massive boost as they currently are taking the p~~~. the "bosses" in the game lack any difficulty whatsoever and additionaly drop next to nothing for your time especialy the dj penguin whose armor set may need 30~40 kills to aquire and 21 hours of my gameplay was wasted making it. the game`s mobs are no better the egnoid matiriels take hours to find also the mobs that drop them dont seem to spawn as often making it very hard to get anywhere endgame the dungeons are nice but dont have any reward execpt 1 mob worth of science xp (not worth it) the ambient mobs eat viechles so it isnt worth crafting them especialy as they are single use finaly the singleplayer lacks a map and this isnt acceptable the maps is needed for the game to be minorly enjoyable as of now players just get lost in the middle of nowhere.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Wouldn't recommend you buy this at least until launch. They claim a launch patch is rolling out September 17th but it's August 22th, it's in 'beta', and the main quest is completely broken. Hard to think they'd launch when the previous version is so buggy. I can only hope it launches more complete.The game itself, or at least what I've been allowed to play (what is not bugged) is pretty barebones, featuring very simplistic "randomized" quests (with a time limit, oddly enough), and an awkward MMO-style XP system (mine blocks, get XP, get slightly further towards your ridiculously numbered goal to level.)All in all I'd recommend just waiting and reading reviews for when this game is more finished or just staying away.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game really is on another level as compared to its other successor, "Terraria".  I liked Terraria a whole lot but when I played Edge of Space, I was blown away.  The tutorial let alone was quite deep and informative but exploring was another thing because you just want to keep going and going!  I also like the researching aspect in the game as compared to Terraria because it feels like grinding on some monsters actually serves another purpose, so props to the developer on that!Although it is in Early Access mode with the casual grammatical and spelling errors, I would definitely recommend it to anyone who has time on their hands.  If you are looking to have a quiet time with a couple of friends, this game is for you!  One last point I want to make is that the game's graphics is quite amazing.  When I bought the game, I thought the graphics wouldn't be quite nice but you will be surprised when you go in!~Definite 10/10 for me.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Took a bit to get into but overall I liked it.  Definitely think a few things could change but it wasn't as bad as some of these reviews seem to be portraying it.  I didn't like the completely polarised armour for sure.  If you want a decent amount of inventory you need to give up health and damage, if you want damage you can't have inventory or health, etc.  That bugged me because I don't want to keep 3 sets of armour on me at all times just in case.  I think the worst thing though is that in the late tier you get some special weapons and tools but they can only be used while wearing a very specific armour.  So unless you want to carry that armour and the tool these great items become entirely useless.  Levelling also seems to be a huge grind.  I ended up just creating the machines that mine quickly and straight up hollowing out entire massive chunks of land to get the xp (I think it has a name in the game though, like Research or something instead of xp).  I still found it fun to progress solo, though.  One of this games big issues is the crafting system.  It would be really nice if you could initiate crafting while in a chest's inventory so that both your inventory and the chest's would be checked for crafting materials.  Its really annoying to have to constantly take small things from chests for each thing you need to make, especially since there are so many different materials in this game (which is a good thing but cumbersome in this case).Tl;dr Its a good game but it takes a bit of dedication.  And if you aren't the type to look past small issues or annoyances then this might not be great for you.

number of helpful: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I tried, i really tried to like this game. To win the battle against the horrible UI, annoying crafting system, constant dying, dull surroundings, dull music, dull combat, dull mining, dull building, dull everything. And to find the "potential" that people seem to be talking about. But it was a failure. I mean, what were the devs thinking? You know, "BETA" stage of development starts when you have an almost ready-to-go product, so you just need to eliminate bugs and test some features. Not when you have a game that's almost unplayable, AS WELL as buggy and unstable.Where do i start? The world is pretty tight, so you can only explore downwards, but since you have no way to tell what's below you, 90% of the time you'll end up falling from great height, crashing and dying on impact. Not to mention that you can't go too deep since the exposure and/or mobs will kill you there. In my book that's not "exploring", just pointless trial and error.You can build a base, but what's the point if you can't even respawn there? And it's not like in Terraria, where you always build a base near the surface - here you won't be able to get back up there unless you die again. And if you build it deeper, then every time you die, you'll have to go and find it again in the midst of a thousand identical floating islands. Oh yeah, and who would've guessed that these super-advanced spacefaring guys won't have a device to make a MAP of the area.So here's how your first couple of hours in EoS will look like: you'll be jumping around, searching for at least something different from the dirt\mud\clay surrounding you, trying to get deeper, but mostly falling and dying constantly. Even if you succeed, you'll see that nothing really changes down there, except for tougher and more aggressive mobs, and the exposure timer won't let you go deeper until you get better equipment. And unless you think that painfully slow mining and crafting some aluminium pants or whatever is fun, then that's it, that's your only option here - you won't have anything else to do. To make things worse the game gives you no clue on how things work and why would you need them. So i can build a GENERATOR and a COMMAND CENTER, cowabunga, now what? It won't even explain the basics. Like if you played Terraria, you know there's a difference between a block and a wall. But here, there are only "walls", by default functioning as blocks. You actually need to hit "TAB" button to be able to place your "wall" in the background where it belongs. Only you'll never guess it unless you stumble on it in some random guide, like i did.Yeah, whoever in the devs team is responsible for the UI deserves a bullet to the face. Why can't i place items just by dragging them from my inventory? Why do i always need to bind a hotkey to do this basic thing? Why the crafting window is so bizarre and complex? Did you see how crafting looks in Terraria? Well, look again. Probably there is some difference in the later stages of the game, but i gave up here. It's not like "playing a game" to me, more like trying to fix a car without any idea of what you're supposed to do. And with the wrench constantly slipping out of your hands and falling so you need to go pick it up again and again. Overall, this is my most frustrating early access experience since Project Zomboid, but at least i didn't spend my money there.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Basically, if someone saw the concept art for starbound and tried to make a clone of that but for the Sega Genesis...I bought this game AGES ago, but because of the negative reviews, I thought I'd wait till the 1.0 launch to give it a propper chance.  It feels very much unfinished, and there is no real goal to the game.  Progress feels very slow and grindy(e.g. an upgraded version of something takes lots of resources, but then is not noticably better)Graphics 3/10Gameplay 3/10I think many aspects of this game may have seemed like a good idea in isolation, but unfortunatly it just hasnt come together well.  I dont think this game can be improved much though, because many of the problems are fundamental game-design issues.I imagine people who would like this game would also like Starbound.  Anyone who has played Starbound will see how heavily EOS has borrowed from it.  I have problems with starbound too (slow development, bad community management, broken promises). That said Starbound is a much more polished game than EOS, and has much more game play (from what I have seen so far).even its its slow, poor development never reaching the and of beta state.I really wanted to like this game... but I just can't do it, after 2.6 hours of REALLY trying to.  The game play is responsive enough, and I have found only a few bugs.  I would suggest watching a gameplay video before buying though.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Edge of Space is a game still in development. There will, of course, still be bugs and pending/missing features. However, at this stage, it is still a pretty fun game to play. I'm still relatively early in the game, but I still got plenty of stuff to do and to look forward too.However, and I will say it again, IT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT.At this stage, not many people may like it as it is. The developers are still working on getting a lot of things in the game. They have lots of features planned to be implemented which are currently not present at the moment. The game is not done and there is still a lot to add.Another thing: Stop comparing it to Starbound. Just because it's a randomly generated, 2D scrolling, sci-fi themed, mining, crafting, and building based game; it doesn't mean it's a clone of that game. It has many different mechanics and the devs took a different approach to the genre. Don't compare the two.My final note is this: If you want a fun terraria-like space game, you can go with either Starbound, Signs of life, or this game, Edge of space. Whichever you choose, don't compare it with/to the others two. I've only played Edge of Space, and I've loved it. However, if you don't like to playing unfinished games, I recommend you not to buy it; or at least not right now. It's up to each one's preferences.8/10:Can't wait for each update.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Edge of Space is a Terraria but sci-fi effort in the same vein as the more popular Starbound, even going as far as to include Terraria crossover content, which was one of the selling points of the game for me. It is also one of the most tedious and uninteresting games I've ever played. The basic gameplay loops are completely uninspired and dull. Terraria has wonderfully satisfying Metroidvania progression that makes slowly mining the world in order to acquire better gear and be able to defeat more difficult enemies an absolute joy to play. In the strictest sense, it's a very repetitive game, but it all feels so good that it's wonderfully engrossing. Edge of Space achieves none of that. It's a grind that just feels like a grind, and even in 1.0 is still a bit toward the wonky side, particularly the jumping mechanics.I have issues with Starbound and it also misses some of what made Terraria work, but it at least feels like there's potential there, and even still in beta it is a lot more fun than this. Edge of Space needs fundamental design overhaul and the 1.0 release really is just polishing a game that never actually worked on the most basic level. One thing I can say for it is that I don't think the graphics are as bad as some other people are making them out to be. Don't get me wrong, they're certainly not great, but I don't think they're intolerable. In a very fun game, they'd probably be fine. Unfortunately this is not a game that plays well.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Overall:I think that in it's current state the game shows a ton of potential and has some very great features. I really like the Terraria/Starbound 2D worldcraft type gameplay and the controls/combat of this particular title does the style justice. If you're a fan of these, this game is a must-play as it is a bit more forgiving than Starbound or Terraria in some ways but also very challenging in it's own right.Positives:There is a great amount of appealing content in the game so far. The combat is a lot of fun. I like how easy it is to find and upgrade resources as well as unlocking content by simply fighting monsters and mining. Each (fighting/mining) give you exp points equally. There are also mini-dungeons you come across regularly to clear out. These in addition to deployable tower defense and other styles of mini-game dungeons adds a fun spin to the roguelike worldcraft indie style.Negative:The biggest issues I have with the game are stability issues and bugs. After initially binging on the game for several hours, I lost everything I had built due to a client crash. I still had my character and all the inventory, but the planet/area's safe file was corrupted so I had to start from a fresh new save. This made me lose all my storage and the structures/bases I had built.  Also it seems that about half the time the game has trouble deploying your character as playable into the world. Sometimes the screen is dark and everything responds, but you cannot move or take control of your avatar. It is easily fixed by a restart or two (if it happens sequentially). Neutral:This game isn't a solid world like in Terraria or Starbound. There are large open spaces inbetween land masses that you must use your jet pack to travel between while heading deeper in the map without taking damage on impact as the gravity is similar to that of earth. This I feel like has both negative and positive effects for creating elevator shafts and fast-travel between different levels. For instance, one thing I liked about terraria was creating an easily navigated mine-shaft to drop very deep very quickly, although in this you can just build a teleporter wherever you want and teleport straight to it. So it really allows you to focus on more combat if you want to.End thoughts. Worth overall. I will update my review as it is developed.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not sure yet.For an early access game it certainly shows some potential, but there are a few things that really bring it down for me.Pros:- I like the art style, characters/enemies/backgrounds all look nice.- Some character customization is nice.- Space age laser pick axe type thing with rifles to defend yourself is always promising. - Has a decent tutorial that I would have probably been 100% lost without. - I liked the quest/task system in place that was used for the tutorial. I would love to see this used a good bit in later builds of the game. Random quests/tasks/challenges while exploring the world would add a good bit of excitement for me.Cons + personal opinions/feedback:- The UI. Oh man the UI. This is the one thing that, if not updated significantly, will stop me from playing this game again. Every time I'd look for something I felt myself straining my eyes trying to discern exactly what I was looking at. Similar looking icons in inventory, small text in several places, and a very clunky and unrefined crafting menu (in a crafting game) made it so that every time I'd stop blasting things with my laser saw to go look at my loot or craft something I would grumble to myself a little bit about how I had to go back into the menus. I hope updates are coming for some of UI/menus, especially the crafting menu and/or system. Please oh please.- Also didn't care for the health/jetpack meters being on such a noisy panel up in the corner like they are. It was a hassle to try and read while running/fighting anything. I would rather just have a couple of bars or numbers above my character or some such thing so that I can see a gauge while I am looking at my character and moving about.- The [lack of] transition from day to night was so abrupt that I thought it was a bug or my game was crashing or textures had stopped drawing. Day/night is great to have, but needs to be a transition, not instant.- It seems like the way to unlock new things to craft is by collecting these little book things that give +25 or so to various crafting skills. I don't much care for that as a gating mechanic, maybe it would be better if more was available initially or if there was a better indication of how using different materials to craft the same item would make a better one. Additionally, I really didn't enjoy that I would find these little books, then have to go into my inventory, select them, equip them on my action bar, and then pull them out and use them in order to gain experience from them. Unless they are to be used for something else I am unaware of, I don't understand why they are inventory items instead of just experience type pickups that occur automatically and scroll a nice little "+25 Furniture!" or something over your head.  I should stop rambling. There's my 2 cents.I hope some of this has been helpful if anyone's read this far. I know people compare this game to Terraria, which I have not played. It may very well be that much of what I don't like is based around Terraria's success and these elements I don't like just aren't to my tastes. If that's the case then I guess it just isn't for me - ignore all that junk above. :)My conclusion - As it exists now, several different issues come together to make a disappointing experience. I hope that is just due to it being in an early stage, and that we'll see much more polish/improvement in the next few months. I think that when/if the right things are made better the whole game could come together quite nicely.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was expecting a lot of fun combat, with mining and exploration but Edge of Space dissapointed me... Maybe I didn't played long enough, but in my opinion game shouldn't need 6 hours to get to "fun stuff". Doing same boring stuff for 2h just to drop one item I needed for gun upgrade. It would be OK for late game grinding for maniac players but at the start? Getting all aluminium I needed was also pretty non-exciting. I don't mind mining, I like minecraft, terraria or Starbound and all the mining didn't get me bored there. But here there is almost nothing interesting to find underground (or anywhere else TBH) and ores are sparse.Sure it's early access - but I played many early access games that weren't that boring.+ crafting system - every material belongs to few "classes", crafiting recipes often require generic materials (for example - if recipe requires raw/metal  you can use aluminium or titanium or whatever else belongs to raw/metal),+ upgrade system - enemies drop upgrades that after use give you point in given subject (for example Armor), after gathering enough poinst you unlock new recipes,+ interesting world concept - small and large floating islands,+ base that actually is a base (different stations - like rafinary or w/e - need to be connected to main command center you build by blocks you craft - can't get away with dirt house)- your first gun is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's pretty weak, you reload more than you shoot and bullets are ugly and slow flying making shooting fast moving enemies nightmare. And you won't change it fast (after 6h of playing I managed to upgrade it to a bit less ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gun that still looks and behaves similar). I loved how guns "felt" in terraria (speed, sounds, power), here basic gun is terrible, it feels like shooting from plastic toy and you are stuck with it for long time.- I met only few types of enemies so far. Jellyfishes that suck your energy, small crabs that are freaking hard to hit with basic gun, flying brain-tentacle-thing that shoots at you and some kind of... errr... something that fires homing balls of death that get you through walls (and are hard to shoot down). And there were no "Hordes of enemies", usually just few of them at same time (and more would get you killed)- upgrades are pretty random, I still didn't managed to discover other classes of weaponry,- it's hard to tell how long will you fall after you jump (world consists of flying islands), you often die by falling down few screens because of missing island you couldn't land on beacues you didn't know its there,- islands don't vary in any way,- your pickaxe is slow (6h of play without getting a upgrade), ores are hard to find. You spend a lot of time at slow mining.- UI is bad:     - prompts you all the time (everytime you craft it shows you result in a window. it would be enough to show prompt only for weapons)     - selecting stuff to craft item and amount just takes too much time     - if you click outside inventory it will ask you if you want to throw item (again - prompt!) instead of using it. it order to use item you have to put in hotbar (annoying when building or using upgrades)+- sci-fi feel (compared to Starbound, with is kinda mix of fantasy with sci-fi)+- I don't like graphic style of game (but that's very subjective)+- no swords in space (on the other hand I was begging for some melee weapon in some situations)

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is marketed like as a clone of Tererria. This is only partially true. I really like Tererria, but I don't like this game. I understand that this game is still in early development, but based on what I have seen so far it is headed down the wrong path. 1. Everything is much bigger in this game. The character is bigger, the blocks are bigger, everything. This means you cannot fit as much of the game on the screen at a time, so you cannot see as far.2. There is no map. I use the map all the time in Tererria to find my way around and locate resources. One of the things I like about the map in Tererria is it shows open areas near you, so you can dig towards them. Since this game does not have a map it also does not have this ability. Finding resources is extremely difficult. I have spent hours digging around and ohly found very limited usable resources. Instead Edge of Space has a radar system that you have to craft, and beacons, which you also have to craft. Since it is so hard to find resources it is very difficult to find enough to make these items and so it is difficult to find your way around. Even with the radar, all you get is a little blip on a small radar screen to try and find your way around. This is so much less effective than having a map.3. So far I have not found any hidden treasures. In Tererria treasure chests and breakable containers are a great way to get resources and gear early in the game. This game does not have these so you have to manufacturer everything yourself. This results in the game moving a lot more slowly. 4. This game does not have biomes like Tererria. For example every Tererria map has desert, jungle, forest and ocean biomes. These go along way to add variety and keep the game interesting. Since this game does not have these it gets boring really quickly. In tererria you also have weather and other events, like blood moons and such. This game does not have anything like that.5. Weapons suck. The only weapon you have is a gun and it has very limited ammo and has to take time to charge. This is a big pain because if you get attacked by a mob you quickly run out of ammo and have to run away until it charges back up. This makes figinting really difficult and not fun. In addition gun are not good close range, so if the enemies get close you will not be able to hit them. Upgrading the gun is also a slow process. You first have to get enough experience to unlock the plans for a new weapon before you can build it. Since gathering experience is slow it can take a really long time before you are able to upgrade.6. This brings me to my next dislike. The experience system is completly messed up. There are 18 different categories for experience, and upgrading them depends on which items you pick up. This means you may find a lot of upgrades for furnature, but not for weapons, which has happened to me, and so you have great items to place in your base, but really crappy items to fight with. I like Tererria much better because you only have to gather the materials and you can make anything.7. You cannot use items directly from your inventory. To use an item, even things like health and other consumable items you first have to put them in your quick bar and then switch to the item and use it. Then when you have consumed all of them it stays in your quick bar with a big red X over it. I would prefer that the item was removed from the quick bar when it was used up. Your quick bar has a very limited amout of space, only 8 slots, so you will be juggling things in a out all the time.8. Detail screens are split up into 4 different screens. In Tererria if you hit the esc key you see your inventory, weapon, item, and vanity slots and everything else. In Edge of Space you have to hit I for inventory, V for crafting, C for armor and item slots, and L for Experience. The 4 different screen also cover each other up and cannot be moved. So if you try and drap something from the inventory to the armor slot you have to juggle the two screen and make sure they are not covering each other or else it is impossible.9. The bug reporting system is lousy. When you go to submit a bug you fill out what looks like a standard email form with a place for your email, a subject, and a message. However it is extremely limited in that if you make a spelling mistake or want to go back and clarify something you cannot just use your arrows or mouse and go back to previous text. The only way to go back is to use the backspace key. This means you loose all your typed text up to where you want to change.All I can say is I am glad I bought this game on sale because if I had paid more than $5 for it I would be extremely upset. Right now I am willing to wait and see if it gets better.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is probably one of the best games I've ever played. It is filled with content from start to finish, never once have I encountered a single bug. Did the developers forget to remove the early access tag? With how developed it is, it shouldn't be early access.I mean seriously one of the best well put together games, and its replayability? Unlimited.....simply unlimited. Terraria / Starbound can simply NOT compare to a masterpiece that is this game.This game makes Terraria look like an early access piece of junk. Same with Starbound.The tutorial explains everything so well, definitely the best tutorial I've ever seen in a video game before. The tutorial alone is worth playing the 13$ for, a lot of fun to be had. And it explains everything so well, with ZERO bugs.Oh also, the combat? It is simply spectacular, tremendous, this game makes GTA 5, Mad Max, Metal Gear Solid all look like pieces of junk (compared to this game), hell any does not stand to the greatness that is Edge of Space. If I could give this game to everybody, I would, everybody deserves to play this masterpiece of a game.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
Early Access Review
Not a very well-rounded GameRead past this first paragraph if you don't want to read what someone posted made up of hate comments and cranky statementsI only wish that steam would have accepted my refund request. They probably would have, if they ever played the game, and had access to the notes you can add if you say "My reason isn't here". I realize this game came out a long time ago, and I might like it more if there were actual guides on how to do stuff, rather than a little note saying what there is. Even if this game came out long ago, that just proves the developers are lazy and have no idea what else to do! Maybe post an in depth guide? Try doing something that hasnt been done many times before? Nope! They just went straight for clone of a game that is way better: Terraria. The only things I see different is that this game has some back story, and the scale of character to block is larger. And even then the developers are trying to only get good feedback by deleting every post with some negativity. I'm sorry, but this game needs some serious work to make it worth the money i'll never get back.                                                                                                               Now that that's out of the way, some things to fix: The scroll function is backwards, which gets annoying. They fact that there is an area that counters all exposure protection, completely takes away the usefulness of exposure protection, I never get any warning about exposure with Earthen Armor anyway! General Turk's (or was it Tuck? Turck?) introduction makes no sense, and I don't even know what happened after hes said to make a bunker! Was that it? Will I see him again? Or is he a useless NPC designed to make you annoyed and confused? The knowlegde tree that grants locomotion isn't all that useful, in that it take almost 200,000 experience to get to stuff that doesn't require a cloning machine, which is also near impossible to get, becasue I have no idea how to unlock the knowledge tree that grants you it! The Research knowledge tree also seems useless, what does it even do? All I see is a button to spend your EXP, and some pictures of guns. The decoration items should also be unlocked through the Base Constructor knowledge tree, because nobody wants to spend valuable EXP which can be used for much more useful things instead of a useless knowledge track that is only apealing to fashion freaks.After you play for about 4 hours, you just get stuck. What else can I do? What is there to find but a large background with clouds that never changes unless it becomes night? The game is just to empty or lacks hints as to what else you can do.Maybe reduce the amount of EXP it takes to unlock the Raptors? After seeing a screenshot of them I rapidly aquired EXP to get them only to find that i needed over 20,000 EXP to get access to them.Maybe add in a health regen system? This kind of game needs one otherwise you just get frustrated everytime you go underground and find a couple Lively Slime who are very hard to kill and reduce your health to about 1/4.Maybe add to the flying laser shark thingy (sorry I forgot his name, I feel really bad) an option that lets him explain the knowledge tracks more in-depth? Such as making an option that opens up another list of options for him to explain the knowledge tracks separately. Some of them are very confusing and seem like useless things made to confuse you (as I said before).I hope this review draws the attention of sereval developers, and for the Steam user looking for a game to check out: I wouldn't recommend this game until it's out of early access or unless you can find an in depth guide out there that tells you what you need in order to progress beyond what 5 hours can get you.Responses To Developers:LordShaggy:About Turk:He May have been triggered by me having what I think to be mid tiered weapons, such as the first Sniper Rifle available in-game, and the Assault Rifle-type weapon with a 35 round clip (both of these being researched under the weapons that require no ammo to be made)Although I would love to do internal testing for a game, I am sorry but I cannot "go out" to any streams, as I am actually only 13 and my mom or dad arent really interested in taking me anywhere. If I could still do internal testing even though I cannot meet the Edge of Space team in person I would love too!If you guys are willing to contact me through Steam or Skype (prefferably Steam, Skype takes up a lot of processing power that I would rather use for gaming, and it makes the frame rate drop majorly at random times) I can also do that! I look forward to your responses! =)(Please note that I do not have a face cam that works with my computer).

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
Early Access Review
Not a very well-rounded GameRead past this first paragraph if you don't want to read what someone posted made up of hate comments and cranky statementsI only wish that steam would have accepted my refund request. They probably would have, if they ever played the game, and had access to the notes you can add if you say "My reason isn't here". I realize this game came out a long time ago, and I might like it more if there were actual guides on how to do stuff, rather than a little note saying what there is. Even if this game came out long ago, that just proves the developers are lazy and have no idea what else to do! Maybe post an in depth guide? Try doing something that hasnt been done many times before? Nope! They just went straight for clone of a game that is way better: Terraria. The only things I see different is that this game has some back story, and the scale of character to block is larger. And even then the developers are trying to only get good feedback by deleting every post with some negativity. I'm sorry, but this game needs some serious work to make it worth the money i'll never get back.                                                                                                               Now that that's out of the way, some things to fix: The scroll function is backwards, which gets annoying. They fact that there is an area that counters all exposure protection, completely takes away the usefulness of exposure protection, I never get any warning about exposure with Earthen Armor anyway! General Turk's (or was it Tuck? Turck?) introduction makes no sense, and I don't even know what happened after hes said to make a bunker! Was that it? Will I see him again? Or is he a useless NPC designed to make you annoyed and confused? The knowlegde tree that grants locomotion isn't all that useful, in that it take almost 200,000 experience to get to stuff that doesn't require a cloning machine, which is also near impossible to get, becasue I have no idea how to unlock the knowledge tree that grants you it! The Research knowledge tree also seems useless, what does it even do? All I see is a button to spend your EXP, and some pictures of guns. The decoration items should also be unlocked through the Base Constructor knowledge tree, because nobody wants to spend valuable EXP which can be used for much more useful things instead of a useless knowledge track that is only apealing to fashion freaks.After you play for about 4 hours, you just get stuck. What else can I do? What is there to find but a large background with clouds that never changes unless it becomes night? The game is just to empty or lacks hints as to what else you can do.Maybe reduce the amount of EXP it takes to unlock the Raptors? After seeing a screenshot of them I rapidly aquired EXP to get them only to find that i needed over 20,000 EXP to get access to them.Maybe add in a health regen system? This kind of game needs one otherwise you just get frustrated everytime you go underground and find a couple Lively Slime who are very hard to kill and reduce your health to about 1/4.Maybe add to the flying laser shark thingy (sorry I forgot his name, I feel really bad) an option that lets him explain the knowledge tracks more in-depth? Such as making an option that opens up another list of options for him to explain the knowledge tracks separately. Some of them are very confusing and seem like useless things made to confuse you (as I said before).I hope this review draws the attention of sereval developers, and for the Steam user looking for a game to check out: I wouldn't recommend this game until it's out of early access or unless you can find an in depth guide out there that tells you what you need in order to progress beyond what 5 hours can get you.Responses To Developers:LordShaggy:About Turk:He May have been triggered by me having what I think to be mid tiered weapons, such as the first Sniper Rifle available in-game, and the Assault Rifle-type weapon with a 35 round clip (both of these being researched under the weapons that require no ammo to be made)Although I would love to do internal testing for a game, I am sorry but I cannot "go out" to any streams, as I am actually only 13 and my mom or dad arent really interested in taking me anywhere. If I could still do internal testing even though I cannot meet the Edge of Space team in person I would love too!If you guys are willing to contact me through Steam or Skype (prefferably Steam, Skype takes up a lot of processing power that I would rather use for gaming, and it makes the frame rate drop majorly at random times) I can also do that! I look forward to your responses! =)(Please note that I do not have a face cam that works with my computer).
