content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								First time I loaded it up I created a char. When I started loading a new world it froze at 75%.Alt+F4. Tried again. Froze at 75%Reinstalled and tried again. Froze at 75%.Verified game. Still froze. Reinstall. FINALY it worked.Start off with a tutorial covering basics on how to move around the world and open things. Also gives you some info on how to use the UI. I found it pretty difficult to use myself. Then it moves on to the crafting system and has you make a "laser pick" out of dirt.... what? Okay whatever. The crafting system is pretty off the wall, I can deal with that.  Then you move on to the combat system tutorial using a gun you made out of dirt again. Some stationary targets then some moving ones... Odd test dummy looking guys running around backwards. After the tutorial you are dropped on a cluster of floating islands with some pretty rough enemies that you'll have to grind to get items to craft higher teir weapons/armor/tools. I understand this is still in dev and a lot has to be done. With that. I'll be back when things a a bit more smooth

Early Access Review
								This game's Multiplayer is very broken. Extremely broken. Has potential, but I only bought it to play with a mate; it lags immensily every time it generates, which is every 50ft or so in game. Couldn't get past the first world after the tutorial without disconnecting and uber lag. Has alot of potential, but at this stage, it's hella broken. The UI, launcher and worlds are unpolished; rendering it quite an ugly game (looks like it's made in gamemaker pro), network issues out the wahzoo; and performance issues even on the best of machines. This game could be good in the future, but for now, it's not even worth $0.99, let alone $15.00. Very dissappointing.

number of helpful: 46 of 98 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Updated Review (10/10/16): I tried to give it a chance. The only discernible difference from when I reviewed this game until now is there is just a lot more clutter on the planets. It's just not a good game and from what I can see the dev's have largely abandoned it. RIPNot worth it in it's current state. This was my first "early access" game before I even know what EA was, I unfortunately fell for the trap of some cool trailers and the incorporation of some Terraria elements, making me hope this was a Sci-Fi terraria. While the fundamentals are the same (a 2d minecraft), the execution is just not even close and the polish of the current state of the game is going to make me wait unto 1.0 release. Upon character creation and the 10+ minute load time (I timed it once) you're forced without choice to go through a tutorial which is extremely frustrating after a character whipe. It lays out the very basics which you then shortly forget and feel very lost in the coming gameplay moments. Building and equipment progression seems confusing and not very straight forward, it's difficult figuring out where to get some of the less common materials without just randomly digging and hoping to hit a vein and what exactly you should be building next. Unless they aren't implemented yet, the distinct biomes are non existent. I walked a bit away from my spawn point and jumped down a few ledges and started taking environmental damage. I presume this is a barrier to prevent you from digging a hole straight down (a-la terraria) and gathering the best materials within minutes of starting a new game. I'll update when the retail version is released but at this time I won't be spending anymore time with this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								As someone who greatly enjoyed games like Terraria and Starbound i have to say this was a huge dissapointment, I bought this game for me and a friend to play and neither of us got as far as the multiplayer screen since there was a confusing and easily broken tutorial that was compulsary to access anything else which is just stupid. The graphics are quite laggy (Not a cause of my computer) and very jerky, the movement did not work in the slightest and i had to anticipate where my character would move to due to a 10 or so second lag in the control inputs. I had to play the tutorial itself about 4 times over to actually unlock the multiplayer and overall around 7 times as it became unplayable due to something missing or not loading.The gameplay elements seem very copied and remind me of a less playable version Starbound, the game itself just isnt worth the £9.99 and you could buy a much more worthwhile such as Terraria it self if you don't own it already. When i played it i got a certain something said by Yahtzee "Terraria? Never heard of it and also we're sci-fi and therefor different to the thing we havn't heard of" Which does describe this game perfectly. Putting the price at £9.99 for an unfinished, unplayable game such as this is stupid and £14.99 for the "finished" version (which will probably never actually come around) is even worse.Even though this game is only in "BETA" (moreso to an alpha) it won't be excused, plenty of "Early access, BETA" games are being pumped out and this is the worst of the worst and at a higher price than most. Although if you have someone on your friends list that you really hate you can gift this to them. To put it at an end, Don't buy this game, go buy something else

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I got this on a sale and my only regret was getting a 4 pack of a game I now know for sure I cannot gift with a clean conscience. The early game plays nothing like the pretty screenshots and trailers. Instead you will be hard pressed to find the necessary materials and blueprints to progress down the tech tree. Only dirt and rock as far as the eye can see. And you cannot get everywhere you can see either: radiation exposure will keep you from delving deeper unless you craft the requisite playtime-padding gear. I get the feeling this game is deliberately padding its time so as to ration the little content it seems to have.Except for the artstyle, this game is outdone by the much similar Starbound, even though this has been on Early Access for much longer. And we all know how Starbound turned out.I should have learned my lesson to not trust Early Access no more. This just buries the remaining hope I ever had for such a model.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I tried this game, i really did.I bought this game because of the crossover event it had done with terraria and terraria is one of my favourite games, and the trailers and screenshots looked cool.However, once i had bought it it took about a few minutes to install but once i had started it up it took about 15 minutes just to load the intro level. Once i had actually started my own world i almost instantly found myself falling from a floating island into a pitch-black hole with no source of light except my mining tool's laser pointer which was next to useless. I looked around for possible solutions to this on the internet (getting out of the hole, being able to see more than 5 pixels of my surroundings at a time, etc.) but i couldn't find any good sites that really gave me a good solution.If you have bought this and expect it to be as good as terraria, please just don't waste your time on this game.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not so great at this moment of time in my opinion. Feels like alot of things are unfinished and won't get finished. I know its "early access" but I still feel there is nothing new in this game that hasn't already been done in other games, which also the other games have done better. In all fairness £10 for two copies isn't nothing to lose sleep over and you won't feel robbed but in that same context it's incouraging game developers to release these "early access games", take your money for a inferior product and never finish it. Abit of a rant I know so for my end view I wouldn't recommend it, if you want 2-D space crafting sandbox game maybe try Starbound.

Early Access Review
								Terraria in space you may be thinking, except Terraria was actually a freaking amazing game. This game is a farce, and it requires so much TLC to live up to Terraria it's ♥♥♥♥ing pitiful and obnoxious. Where is the progression system that actually makes sense? Where are the melee weapons? content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would not recommend this game at this time, it is VERY dull within the first 3 hours, the first 30min-an hour you spend (if you play the tutorial) being told things that anyone who has played ANY other game like this for 10min could figure out. Needing to research the crafting recipes slows the game down a lot. The combat at the moment sucks, all weapons needing to reload and no weapons that are not guns, (that i have seen) and things to shoot that ether are to bloody small or move around so much you just kinda wag your mouse around and hope to hit them with one or two of your shots. These are just a few of my complanets but i don't want this to go on forever, i will finish this by saying I want this game to be good, but at the moment it just isent, Terraria and Starbound are just better games. 1/10 not worth the price, Its a 1-2 quid game being sold for 8 quid for the standard version or,  the bargen price for the special edition 15 smeging quid! When you can get both Terraria and Starbound for 15 quid, i would deffinitly recommend getting both of them over this game, at least fo the moment.

Early Access Review
								This game is VERY VERY unpolished, i understand that beta is beta but this is just bad. The game starts you off with a gun that does hardly any damage and isnt accurate and gives you NO information on how to get a better gun. I sat for what felt like 5 minutes shooting one enemy. Also there is a system when you die, you use cryorods. You get 10 cryorods at the start and use one upon death, when you run out your character gets a stacking debuff that makes you weaker. To remove that debuff you need to use cryorods which the game once again fails to inform you on how to get more. I felt cheated out of my money.Wait for the finished game, right now it isnt even fun.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a game that was advertised to be like Terraria and Starbound but dosent feel like either, but i like some of the concepts. I know its in beta so i cant be too critical but i would like to see some of these cons fixed in the future...Cons--Plays like 20-30 fps, needs smoother animations-There is no on screen toolbar without pulling up a window-Some of the colors are off putting and too vibrant-Enimies can be very difficult to fight-Landscape is too scattered-Needs more explorable dungeons and different landscapes to feel that real sense of exploration that  Terraria and Starbound had Pros--Interesting Enviorments-Cool Weapons and Armor-Unique and Interesting Art StyleThere is some things this game does do really good at, but more that it does not. It almost feels like it's trying to hard to be like Starbound/Terraria and it's failing to be. I think this game has potential but at the moment is just does not stack up to what i expected it to be, so i cant recomend this game :(

number of helpful: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								8 Months and a BS marketing scheme later..and I finally have an opinion of this game.1.  Its still broken beyond belief.  They've had 8 months thus far to migrate the game over to its new "format"...and they are finally getting multiplayer launched...which was promised back in July.Its still a pain in the butt to do anything in the game: the mining and gather is slow as molasis, the flow of the animations still feels like an old flash game, and they constantly have to "rework" the environment , monster spawns, etc.  Not just tweek it...but rework it.I just dread having to start over in that game, unlike in other games of the same "genre" like Terraria.   And considering how infrequent and archaic their update process is....restarting happens ...painfully often.2. Their latest marketing scheme to push dried up sales just kicks every Early Access owner in the jaw.  The people that adopted this game early...and tried their hardest to help improve the game....get called "Entitled" and  "Trying to smear the companies good name" by asking for their free copy of the game that they should get which is part of the new Early Access purchase.  No grandfathering the changes...just a solid FU tot he ones that helped make the game even possible (financially and development wise).Its not like this is a Game Lauch sale...or a 8 months from Retail Release sale; its still in Early Access...like it has been for the last 8 months....at the same exact price it was back in June/July.Yea...I can see why they dont want to give out the extra copies to the ones who already bought the game. Then they may not get any new sales imediately...because their game sales were already stagnant.  Whose the entitled one again?  This game and the comapny have been pretty "stagnent" since day one.  If they are trying a really big "last ditch" effort to generate sales before the game is even Launched .....while angering all the people who funded the game/company to get them to this point....it might speak a lot about the future of this company.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not worth it. Just feels like a cheap rip off of Terraria and Starbound... which it is?I'm aware this is an early access game and I hate to give a beta game a negative review but...this game is SO boring. It is supposed to be similiar to Terraria and Starbound but it falls VERYshort of making any attempts to surpass them. I cannot even force myself to play this game for any longer than the amount that I did. The goals in the game are in a codex you have to READ to really understand what your next stepis to continue or progress. It just seems lazy to me to force a player to read paragraph after paragraph explaining what to do. This was a huge turn off for me and I regret not doing more research beforeinvesting in this. Other comments have mentioned that there is room for improvement, but I'm goingto be brutally honest and say that this game needs a HUGE overhull to give it any actual potential.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												meh.First, this is just an opinion of mine. Second, others may feel completely different then me about this game.I bought this way back in the beginning on desura when it was just a wee pup. Did some basic exploring, fell a million feet to the hard crusty core a million times, got bored and didn't touch it for a couple years. I thought the final game would be well rounded with some good end game content and perhaps missions etc, what I see here is the same boring game from day one. I.... just... coundn't... get into it. Game progression was dismal. I haven't found any cool structures or bases or bosses or anything other than stupid space jellyfish and floating orbs of death. I dunno, perhaps if I put in an additional 100 hrs I'll find all that I'm missing in the game but ain't nobody got time for that. I say buy it on sale if you really want a go at it or else find a more polished 2d minecraft-esq game.Pros:The graphics are pretty awesomeThe creatures are very originalYou can build huge fortressesYou can craft a whole lotta sh.... stuff.Multiplayer!!Cons:Quite boring playing soloEnviroments are very much the same as far as I could tellNo actual story line or Lore to keep me intrigued in the world I was living inNo NPCs to interact with, buying selling of goods and suchNo Goals that I could findNo real point to playing.... I feel sh... bad saying it but there it is.... Sorry Devs, I really hoped it would turn out better.  I wish there was a "Not Yet" button in the recommendation field. Keep my money though, at least you finished developing the game. I'll check back next year and see what improvements you have made.PS: I thoroughly support the development of indie game such as this and while I particularly am not satisfied with EoS, I would still pay full price for this game just to see more like it come into the light and to keep 2d platforming alive.LONG LIVE METROIDVANIA GAMES!!!!!

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I've heard a lot of people express their fear that this game might become another Starbound- to those people i can say that they put out a different trick, which in the end yields the same result.You see, the game is in "1.0", it's a released game, however the amount of bugs and the complete lack of any form of polish will make you think you're playing a tech-Alpha.It's an unfinished game, and that's really all i can say.I've had people tell me the devs are actually nice guys and that they put a lot of work into the game, that they're dedicated and have been steadily developing ever since the game was announced, but i honestly can't see how someone dedicated to their work could put out something like this for the world to experience and associate with them.However if that really is the case, i'm sorry for the harsh review and i hope to see something better from them sometime soon.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												Ok......The review.......Mixed?????Before anyone else bashes this game more for being "Terrible" hear me out, this game was released September 17, 2015 which I remind you this game before hand had been worked on for a consecutive 4 years before its release.The reason I bring the release date up is that the popular game "Starbound" came out on Dec 4, 2013 and yet it has yet to have come out of early access.To remind you Edge of space yet it came out earlier got out of early access faster then "Starbound".Another important issue to point out is how people after buying The "Edge of Space Special Edition" complained about not getting the content immediately, let me remind you that a game is very difficult to program and create a whole new game from scratch,Oh yea and if you want to see how much was put into this game look at the The "Edge of Space The Journey through early access" image.I am one of the not many people on steam who will accept any game no matter what it is . In my oppinion this game is great because it has just the right amount of content.A message to everyone on steam before you rate a game think about how it took this person or team hours of their own time to create the game you are criticizing.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												So I come to find out yesterdays negative review has been deleted.  Today v1.0 came out. Ever hear the term 1 step forward, 2 steps back. Prime example here. The tutorial is no longer available. Just some message flash on the screen, too fast for me to read. and off to combat you go.You get 5 exps for every block you dig, it varies for plants and none for combat to a maximun of 5k. If you go over 5k, you don't get any more exps until you spend what you have. Techs start out at 500 exp cost and go up from there.They've removed the graphic pictures of the items in the crafting window. You can no longer match the icon with what you're crafting with what you already have. So unless you know the game well or remember everything, you'll probably end up crafting the same item twice.I took an instant dislike to this game when I found out they use "OR" "AND" "NOT" and some other gates to get your power working. Seriously!!? You shouldn't have take a electronics class to understand how to use power in a game, after all it's only a game that supposed to be fun, not a lesson in science. Some of the items have the same name. For example, the Bosom Blaster, it's in 2 different tech tables, Phased Weapons and Research 1. So apparently I have to buy it in both locations in order to build it. This part really isn't clear to me.The other thing I don't like is in the tech tree is that there are no stats for the weapons. So it's hit or miss as to what weapons you research.Frankly for me, it's too much grind and repetativesness and not engaging enough to want to come back and play this game more often.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Beware, this game is utterly broken!I tried to set up a server and play with a friend of mine.We didn't even get half way through the tutorial...My friend got stuck when the tutorial wants you to open a door by pressing a button.The problem being that neither the button is highlighted nor is anything in the room actually able to be interacted with.After randomly jumping around the room for quite some time while hammering the F-key, the door miracoulously opened for me.(It never did that for my friend)But I got stuck in the next room when the game tells you to craft a laser something, which turned out to be impossible without having the required materials...Needless to say that the game does not provide you with any materials at this point and even goes ahead telling you that everything is alright....until you continue along the tutorial (and some rather poor jokes about antibiotics) and are forced to use that laser something.(Which - you guessed it - you don't possess because the game failed to provide the needed materials)That was around the time that we decided to quit and wait for several rounds of patches and bug fixes.To be quite frank: if the game utterly fails to guide you through a 100% scripted (and hopefully tested!) environment, how on earth would it be able to accomodate all the random stuff that we would hopefully have done outside of the tutorial?!

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Do not purchase this game.Now that you've got a conclusion, let's cover the reasoning.  This game is, at best, a pre-beta.  It's not stable enough to be a beta, the mechanics are either half broken or entirely unbalanced, and the game lacks enough content to be playable.This game is unstable, and runs poorly even on a beast of a machine (3930k and 7970 GPU).  I've had numerous crashes, and the game occasionally just hangs for a minute.  During that time I've been destroyed by numerous enemies, lost progress, and lost items. The crafting system is entirely broken.  Enemies level up several orders of magnitude faster than your equipment can.  There's no invincibility mechanics, so a swarm of enemies can strip even a well equipped character in seconds.  You bounce when an enemy hits under you, so you can be air juggled to death.  Numbers mean nothing.  You start with a paltry heath and shield, but coming back with 10 times bettter stats doesn't make you live longer, because the game occasionally just spawns a dozen enemies around you.  All of this is predicated upon oyu exploring, but that's realy a joke because any upgrade past to most basic will require hours of random tunneling to get anything.  The real kicker is the crap weapons.  You have to craft ammo, but even worse the weapons requiring ammo aren't great.Content has recently been dramatically expanded.  The waiting for resources to process has been removed, and there's more to make.  Unfortunately again, this is useless.  You spend huge amounts of time now searching for resources, to synthesize into other resources, to synthesize into useable goods.  After all of that grind, you're left with gear which still allows the enemies to absolutely curb stomp you constantly.  If the point of this game is crafting, then they really need to go back and rebalance enemy strength, progression rates, and the insane cost of items.  There's no reason that you shouldn't have all research completed prior to finishing the second area, and even if you do some of the end game items require an amount of resources which literally exceeds those present on a single biome.  In a single sentence: this game is fundamentally broken and the rate of progression indicates that we'll see completed project in a few years at best.Negative comments generally warrant some thought.  In the case of a review, you should provide the people who made the prokect a way to fix it.  Let's start there.1) Stop trying to be Terraria.  You've got guns with and without ammo, crafting, and resource gathering.  That doesn't mean you are as good as Terraria, and you shouldn't invite the comparison.2) Ditch your current crafting system.  It requires too many diverse resources, it's convoluted, and there's no 1:1 comparison for item utility.  Combining that with the random nature of weapons means I can get a weapon worse than my current one, while spending much rarer resources.  That's frustrating, but what's even worse is having dozens of different armors that show no clear progression.  You've got a needlessly complex system, too many resources, and none of it is balanced.  Stop adding more, and just get the bare bones in place.3) Rebalance enemies.  They're cheap, their spawns are a giant middle finger to the player, and more often than not they have too much health.  Spending 45 minutes fending off the Head Hunter boss isn't a challenge, it's a gruelling grind.  This particular point is arguably compounded by the crap weapons choice.4) Develop the game.  I'm going to be blunt here, you aren't putting any appreciable effort in here.  It may actually be huge from your side, but I can't see it as the consumer.  In almost a year I'm still dealing with poor balance, no content, and unfulfilled promises.  Either discontinue the game, or finish it.  Right now this is looking to be an alpha we have to bay for, that will never be up to beta standards.  I can tell you that I'll never be giving another cent to anyone involved with this project unless they've got a completed game.  This extended beta is absolutely worthless, because its triumphs are drowned in a sea of failure and unfinished code.After 3 separate returns to this game, I'm done.  You don't deserve anyone's patronage, unless you can tell us when we're going to get something worth the money.  This garbage surely isn't.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is for the beta product. I intend to return to the game once it is fully developed and see if it has been improved upon, but this review is for people considering purchasing the beta version.I want to like this game the way I want to like every Terraria clone. Maybe this game will be good one day. Right now, it is not. The menu system is needlessly complicated and completely counter-intuitive. One thing I imagine will sadly not improve is the art design. Personally I play way more indie games than AAA titles - high end graphics aren't a selling point to me. But there is doing low res graphics well, and then there is this. It is terribly ugly to look at. If you want to spend money on one of these work in progress space Terraria games, Starbound is the only one worth paying actual money for currently.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the worst games I've ever played, Beta or not.  Performance is horrible given the power of the gaming pc it's being played on.  Crashes extremely frequently.  User Interface is such a hassle to work with. Audio skips constantly, deaths are far too frequent, and several items that have appeared as collected on the screen never appeared in my inventory.  Bought this on a whim since I loved starbound and terraria and the latest version is supposed to include terraria content.  Too bad I can't stand this game enough to even get that far.  Perhaps when this is past Beta, I'll try it again, but this is abysmal.*EDIT* 11/27/14As of my last attempt at playing the game, many of the above issues had been rectified.  Performance is no longer sluggish, crashes are much more rare, the audio no longer skips, and dying is harder to do unless your early game gun's stats roll poorly.  I'm glad to see a developer actually working on their early access title and improving it greatly.  Unfortunately, the interface and structures in the game are not intuitive nor simple to use like other games in this genre.  Terraria took some getting used to, but it at least had a learning curve.  I sadly have to stick by my negative recommendation on this one.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Nice intro. Nice music in intro and main menu. Too bad that here end the nice things and game begins.This game took lots of inspiration from Terraria. Developers analyzed flawlesly what is the best about Terraria - the open, proceduraly generated world, great combat system, pixeled but detailed graphics, massive crafting, home building, interesting and very different bosses, etc, and with expert precision took it all out.The combat system is bad, your greatest enemy are not the very few mobs, but aiming system, reloading and limited energy. The game is far from polished, it looks like beta+, not full release. Graphics are relatively nice and detailed, but for some reason look worse then Terraria. Crafting is on one hand better - you don't search wiki for recipes, but that is the only plus it has. World generation is strange,  on one hand looks completely unnatural, on the other is hard to navigate and the way jetpack is implemented is not helping you. There is no real need to build your home - at best you create long flat terrain to place your factories at.I could continue, but enough is enough. I Can't recommend this game. Maybe, maybe in a year, if they fix the bugs, mobs, world generation and combat, it will be interesting game. Of course, such complete overhaul is very unlikely.Edit: played mostly in offline mode, so real time playing doesn't display in Steam.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Deep down inside there might be a great, fun, crative, and expansive game here, however it doesn't present itself in an approachable manner. Games in this genera are good at letting us learn how to play the game and create things as we go along, which gives players a feeling of accomplishment. This one makes use of endless text boxes, intro videos, and gathering quests. Usually this would make me feel like I'm being patronized, but I still have no idea what I am supposed to be doing. I think it suffers from trying to do too much too quickly, which makes it exhausting approach. I'm trying not to compare it to Terraria, because clearly they were trying to go for something different, which is great, but it still has some work to do.

												I have not played this game in about a year, so I decided too re-install it, and look at it, as well as the reviews... and I see nothing has changed. It's still the confusing heap of garbage it was a year ago. The dev's seem to have abandoned this game. The game still feels like it's in an Alpha stage. It's choppy, the sprites are glitchy at times, and the amount of work you need to do to be able to get anything, it's outrageously difficult.I had been an avid Minecraft and Terraria player, having LAN parties with my friends. We had beaten Minecraft, and had beaten all the regular bosses in Terraria. Then, one of them found this game. It looked cool, so we bought the game, and ran it. 5-7 hours in, and we still have the basic tools. None of us could figure out how to upgrade them, or get new tools! All the crafting involved electrical gates the technicians use!! We ended up abandoning the game, and never spoke of it again.So, unless you're a senior technician that knows electrical gates by heart, don't waste the $15 on this game.On another note: Terraria is about 250 mb. Edge of Space of a little over 2 Gb. Terraria has hours upon hours, upon hours of gameplay, with lots of replayability, and an active online community. Edge of Space has very little content, very little to no online presence, and actually very hard to set-up a server for. Hmm, I wonder what the better choice is....If you don't know what Terraria is, and just found this game by surprise, get Terraria.---EDIT---So, another year has passed, and my friends decide to check this game out again. From what I've seen, and remember of this game, it has defintely changed, for the better. The crafting is easier to understand, the leveling up system, albeit a bit demanding and stops gameplay, is pretty interesting. The gunplay is great, the mining system could use a bit of work, and the UI is still pretty bad with my only issue being that every individual thing, such as inventory, crafting, skills, etc., requires a different button to press in order for that specific menu to come up(how hard could it have been for it to just open up with one button, and have different tabs for everything?).Me and my friends played this for about 5 hours straight, and we all said that it is definitely fun. Though there are still issues, the game is in a playable state. But... I don't think mutch will change in the future, unless these developers are secretly working on this without giving updates, as the last form of any game update was last year(April 28th 2015, if I remember correctly), while the last time a dev spoke about the game(on steam at least), was 2 months ago(April 25th). The post said that they were sorry for being silent about the game, and that logistical issues came about, and that they would get back to the playerbase and explain what was happening. Well, it's been 2 months. Where's the explanation?tl;drIn the state this game is in currently, I still wouldn't recommend this to anyone. Unless you have a group of friends to play with, know how to portforward(because Hamachi doesn't work), and have some extra money laying around, then don't buy this game. It still seems like the developers have abandon this game, or don't have a whole lot of motivation for it.I would still rather play Terraria.

content:

Early Access Review
								What can I say... I bought this with a hope of having a experience similar to Terraria, since they were in parcery with Re-logic and hadding Terraria based content.But I only got disappointement!The menu with your items is confusing! In the start, once you get in the planet It's very difficult to stay alive, mostly cause of weakass weapons, and the mining takes too much time for the same reason! Both tools and weapons are poor in perfomance!But I didn't judge like that cause in the future you would take better stuff... right?Nope! To upgrade anything, It takes amounts of various materials, not to mention:-the time to mine them (is slow)-search for them (too much time)-you have to walk FAR to find more, go into holes and a maze of caverns, making you lost from your outpost.-limited area (that radiation thing that kills you when you go too much down)-enemies stronger than you (and weak weapon)And if you fail for the first time, you will notice you actually got lives!YEAH! LIVES! Who puts lives on a game based of Terraria?!But you can make more "lives", but you will have to decide on what to do next! Spend your materials in making lives and search materials so you can upgrade your weapons, armor and tools, but you will end up lost, surrounded by enemies, and you will eventually will die. Then, you must do more "lives" so you don't lose your progress!Repeat this times and times! That was my game! A vicious cycle of losing, nerves, and boredom...I don't recommend this game...Play Terraria instead... they never disappointed (at least me) with their updates and content...

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								As I’m sure you can see I have only played about an hour of Edge of Space before I uninstalled it and asked for a refund. I cannot claim to know almost anything about the game itself in terms of if it has storyline, how good the mechanics are later on in the game or what kind of a sandbox it is. I’m simply writing about my experience with it and what I should have done to avoid this. Personally what I didn’t like about the game which is unfortunate for the developers was the introduction. The thing that really allows you to make your first impressions (excluding the tutorial of course), sum up what your experience with this game is going to be like, how everything works etc. I had no problem with the tutorial. I very much enjoyed the general mechanics of the game. I liked how it works, I also could get used to the overall ‘look’ of the game and how it varies from Terraria’s cute pixels. However as soon as I started the actual game itself it all went down-hill. When I spawned I was confused. “Where was I?”, “What was going on?” I was hoping for some kind of guide (yes, like in Terraria. *sigh) to help me however I was instead met by a distressed, flying, talking shark who after saving politely asked me to make him a toothbrush out of uranium or something. Now, I DO NOT like the addition of quests and things like that on a sandbox. (And again it’s my fault for not watching or reading any reviews) so I was annoyed that I had been restricted already so soon into the game. I like having freedom in a game however a clock timing me down to gather materials to make a toothbrush was very annoying to say the least. However this not what annoyed me, no what annoyed me was the fact that I could not find any Uranium anywhere. So I decided to screw the quest thing and do what I had bought the game for. Explore a new alien world, and have no idea what to expect. However I soon fell off a cliff and almost died. Then I fell off another cliff. And another. And another. It was only then that I realised I must have spawned on the top part of the picture in the Menu of the game where there are many floating islands. I didn’t like this at all as I felt I was restricted to the area island where my spawn was. It didn’t feel like one big map for me to explore, rather different areas I would have to go to as the game progressed. So I decided I would go as far as possible and see if I could find a dungeon or something. After mining things from pretty far away from the spawn point I was told I had a full inventory. So I moved some stuff into the bin last of which was a block of ice which after being deleted I thought nothing off. However when I looked back into my hot-bar, my mining laser had been replaced by this ice. And as there don’t seem to be any instructions beyond the simple things shown in the tutorial I had no idea how to get my mining laser back into my hotbar. The UI was extremely confusing and I was rapidly losing my patience with it. I then killed myself again and spawned back to pod only to realise random things in my inventory were now ice. On top of all of this you cannot move anywhere in the map without being constantly attacked by flying jellyfish and millions of little ‘wolf things’ on the floor that are much faster than you meaning they start to accumulate faster than you can seem to kill them. All this just seemed rather unprofessional and I still had no idea what the hell was going on and why a flying, talking shark needed uranium for his toothbrush. The gameplay was not at all what was displayed in the second trailer and the story so far involved a talking shark. Was he to be my guide??? I just wanted to get to the building, exploring and killing bosses part. I suppose it's maybe just not that sort of game.It’s not that the game was ‘bad’ as such it’s just that I believe the trailers were a bit misleading within the fact that one shows a Terraria like style of gameplay where your character is free to build and explore and the other shows a very interesting backstory that looked pretty prominent and seemed like something you would progressively learn about throughout the game through recruiting NPC’s, slaying bosses etc. None of this was in the introduction.It’s entirely my fault that I neglected to look into the game before I bought it. In all honesty I am basically one of those people who just wanted a ‘Terraria in space’ thing. I should have watched other people play it before I blindly went in and bought it. The main two reasons I bought it Edge of Space over Starbound was A) It was £5 cheaper or so, ( ͡ᵔ ͜ʖ ͡ᵔ ) :D and B) I know the lead developer is a friend of Redigit and had permission to use some Terraria bosses (which makes my Terraria in space fantasy even more realistic) and must mean it will have some Terraria qualities. I know that the game is still in Early Access so is obviously far from perfect, but I just expected better. I suppose the whole point of Early Access is so that people can post their constructive criticism and the developers take it into account. So maybe I will purchase the game again when it’s properly released. I just wish the game had a little more freedom from the start, coincidently just like Terraria does (*another sigh) and not have a random quest to make a toothbrush for a shark out of uranium. Either way, make sure you WATCH GAMEPLAY for Edge of Space before you buy it because it can be different from what it seems. (I'm no proffesional, I just wanted to get my opinions out there!)Thanks for reading!!!*Edit: Just thought I would say that Steam did promtly give me a refund for my purchase within about 2 hours.

number of helpful: 3 of 13 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Im giving this game a maybe for playing. Theirs barely any difference from this vs terraria. Oh wait their is, just a radiation exposure bar, and the game seems to be styled around metroid graphics.Onto the real review. Okay basically your use to terraria, starbound, or minecraft. You assume you have the basics of building, thats check.Now you assume you have the basics of base building, that is... barely check. You have a command center, but your given no real idea how it works, or how to use it. 0 Explanation behind it. (HINT) it supplies 2 available slots for structures that require power (Which AGAIN are not defined, nor explained) how to mine or make adjacent to a powered block (and to do that you need to mine the back, currently the mining in the background has been switched to TAB key).Anyway... now assume after base building is scrapped, most of what you seen in the pictures, or the trailer video is either not implemented yet or considered non user useable. Thats... thats just false advertising. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME based on the trailier. You will be SEVERELY disappointed if you do!Anyway, other than this review just remember... with a grain of salt.  Comparing this game to minecraft is laughable at best, as minecraft is one of the most fleshed out, well prepared games out their for survival. Just its block based graphics.With Starbound you get the perks of it having terraria gameplay with a twist, mechs, turrets, space ship home & planetary home combine with world travelining leading to finte adventures.With Terraria you get alota building functionality but... only one world, on the upside in Terraria you also get to transfer items on your character with you to other servers.With this game Edge of Space you... get working building mechanics (barely anything to craft though), good music (when its not tearing horribly or desyncing), horribly slow mining, extremely aggressive enemy npcs that fight you based on how far down you go, and how pre-occupied you are not paying attention to your surroundings, and limited idea of how to really play altogether with out continued communication through the steam forums with other players, and the developer(s)/staff of Edge of Space.If you want this game buy it, i bought 2 copies, but now im beginning to regret my investment considering how much is lacking, how much is currently missing, and what is functional, works, and what isnt combine with all the time lost to just... well... mining, searching, and trying to figure out this game altogether with searching the steam forums, and trial and error in the game itself. Anyway good luck!Oh and so far it runs for me on a Asus Transformer T100 series (1.83ghz quad core, 2gb ram) with 15minutes load time, and on low/normal graphics (on my other laptops/desktops) the game runs at normal/high. Lag doesn't seem to be existant in any gameplay on this game on any of the computers i've tested it with (all being at 1.83ghz, 4.2ghz, or 3.9ghz quad core) computing systems.*Note*Still consider this game and check back on it though! It does show promise assuming alot of the negatives i've listed, not including thousands of other negatives listed in the forums are taken care of.

number of helpful: 32 of 75 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edge of Space needs significant improvement before I would recommend that anyone purchase it. The controls are nonintuitive, the interface feels too small and crowded, and currently the game feels like a bad Terraria clone. Your money would be better spent on Starbound if you're interested in this theme.EDIT: Just went back and played through the tutorial after several months. Everything looks and feels the same. The game is as cumbersome as ever and I did not enjoy trying to get started playing. Once you leave the tutorial level, it is unclear what you're objective within the game is. I had heard mention of UI improvements, but to me, everything looks exactly the same. I don't know if I'm supposed to play this game with a wiki page open, telling me step by step how to play it all the way through or not. I will admit that Terraria and Starbound have you basically playing with the wiki open as well, but Edge of Space seems to offer very little encouragement when you actually get into the game. Upon exiting the tutorial I was beamed down to the surface of what I assume was a planet, and immediately attacked by floating jellyfish who took a frustrating amount of time to kill. I was given no actual objective, only tossed forward into this environment with very little explaination.Bottom line: I would not recommend edge of space to anyone. I bought the 4-pack when it went on sale and after playing the game informed my friends that they should not waste any bandwith or hardrive space on it. This game has EXTREMELY cumbersome controls (double tap 'x' to pick up a torch? Really?), lacks visual pop, and has poorly designed UI. Do not purchase this game. Go get Starbound. Some have said that Starbound is a glitchy, dead project. This is untrue. The game is very entertaining with a few friend and totally worth your time.I understand that this game is still in early access but it needs so much more work before anyone should play it. I've owned it for a long time and am still waiting for any significant progress to take place.

number of helpful: 12 of 33 people (36%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												I’ve delved into many sandbox games, both 2D and 3D. I’ve built castles, small huts, underground hideaways, and structures that could only be described as half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥shelter attempts. In most cases you can scrape by and learn the game yourself without needing outside help, but certain games are nearly impossible without some form of guide or wiki. Edge of Space is a 2D sci-fi action sandbox game developed by Handyman Studios and was released on Steam September 17th, 2015. If you’ve played Terraria or Starbound, you’re probably familiar with the gameplay, but don’t think you will understand the entire game based on the experience you’ve gained from other games like Edge of Space.You are an Ark corporation operative, one of many soldiers sent throughout the universe to essentially conquer and terraform other planets to make them more habitable for mankind. After awakening on your ship after a long cryosleep through the universe, you discover that your ship has gone off-course from its original destination and disabled itself near a strange alien planet. Finding few options left, you take the escape pod to the planet below to find a way to survive.When you first touch down, the game gives you a tutorial of sorts. Using a laser-wielding shark as the first quest giver, you are introduced to gathering materials which forces you to explore the surrounding areas to gain resources. The best part of Edge of Space is the use of resources. Almost all resources are useful, even dirt. Edge of Space uses a tier resource system that doesn’t always specify a resource, but rather subcategories such as organic or mineral for crafting. The more I play, the more I wish other games of the same genre would use this style of crafting!The number one issue in any sandbox building game is the unbelievable number of absolutely useless materials that do nothing but waste space, but Edge of Space finally gives the item purpose with subcategory crafting. Crafting is a huge part of the game, but when you start off you only have a handful of recipes you can craft. This is where science comes in! Almost every task you perform gives you science experience such as crafting, mining, and fighting.You start with an experience bar with a max of 5000 experience which will get you pretty far, but you’ll definitely want to do some of the terraforming events around the world to bump up that maximum amount. You can not collect more science experience while it’s maxed, so any action you perform while you have max experience is wasted.You can use science experience to purchase more recipes for any category you wish, and the endless experience you can gain in the world means you can max out each tech list if you put in enough time and effort. Science experience is a more efficient way of leveling that lets the player customize their characters unique item build. Minecraft may have started this trend with the ability to add enchantments to your weapons with experience, but Handyman Studios perfected it with science experience and tech trees.You’ll notice the three bars in the top left of the game which are Health, Shield, and Energy.  Health and Shield should be pretty obvious, with Health being the damage threshold your character can take before death, and Shield, which has a short delay before regenerating, is a secondary bar that negates damage first before Health is affected.Energy can be used for a variety of things, but they will all use the same Energy pool. Energy weapons and your Jetpack both consume energy, which regenerates much like the Shield, when not in use. Health and shield are obviously a staple in any game, but having energy that can be used to power escape and combat is a pretty interesting mechanic.Making players choose how to use a resource in real-time is a great idea, and more games need to put players in clutch situations, because it makes for hilarious results if you don’t master it properly. As you start getting more into the meaty insides of Edge of Space, you’ll learn how to handle a power grid and set up connections between hubs around the planet.Exploration is a huge part of the game, but it is also the most hazardous. Apart from the local enemies that you find around the world, you will also find bases of sorts that count as quests on the right side of your screen, and require you to clear the enemies spawners littered around the area, then either plant or disarm bombs. These bases can be used as a way to get cosmetic resources and science experience, so it’s a great way to rest up and relax after a hardcore digging session.As you travel around, you will discover NPCs that will need your help. Before you can accept their quests, you need to craft their anchor and place it in your base. Most NPCs are useful and will give you rewards or add something to your base, such as Vinny, a plant that provides light in a small radius around him.What really hooks a player onto a sandbox game is the multiplayer. Sadly, the multiplayer is a mess, with an unfathomable amount of bugs. Running a dungeon with other players is unbearable, and not even worth attempting in the current state of the game unless you like getting stuck in random dungeon loops, or getting stuck in a black void and crashing.Edge of space could be one of the best sandbox games I’ve played, but sadly it is bogged down by an enormous amount of bugs. Handyman Studios is constantly throwing out new updates and attempting to fix the bugs, but it is a bit ridiculous that a game that was in early access for so long still has so many. I feel like I would have appreciated Handyman Studios more if they either stayed in early access longer, or went back into early access until the game is functional for more than two hours.I tried hard to love this game. Handyman Studios is still putting a ton of work into so I’m hoping I can start up Edge of Space one day and play it with my friends without something terribly wrong happening. Normally, you could just wait for the Early Access tag to come off before you buy a game, but they took the training wheels off this bike too early. If Edge of Space appeals to you, either keep an eye on the updates before you consider purchasing it or take a leap of faith and roll with the updates.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is so confusingEDIT: Just to reiterate here, I'm going to give some reasoning. When I first got this game, it was in a very early alpha. Mostly everything was broken and buggy. Well, I decided to re-visit it yeterday, and while there are definatly less bugs, it still need a lot of work. First thing the game does is drops you into this very odd tutorial. They start out with the regular, walking, opening doors, etc. But then you get into crafting. The first thing they want you to make is some sort of lazer, so you go through the confusing process of crafting it (I literally cannot explain it beause it is that confusing), only to find out it takes about 6 seconds to mine 1 peice of dirt. One peice. And they make you mine through a whole tunnel of it. After you get out of this tutorial (which takes about 30-40 minutes) you're dropped into your randomly generated world. And that's it, no further instructions. Now in say, Terraria, you have the guide to help you along a bit. In this game, they give you nothing. So I spent maybe 20 (?) minutes just walking around. Going through caves, all of which were empty, falling of islands, that's about it. Once this game has some polish to it, and a reworked tutorial, I might give it a third try, but for now I wouldn't recommend this game at all.

content:

Early Access Review
								This review will only be a short one becasue I dont have much to say about it and I would only be repeating myself. Edge of Space is a Retro Sci-Fi which is about exploring and seeing diffrent things. This sounds great but it quickly gets dull. After the tutorial it seems that most of the fun is gone. There just isnt much to do. I know people are going to say its an Early Access game but that does not change everything. It improves on what it has. So far I would nit recommend this game so far. If you wanted a better game that is simular get Starbound or Terraria. The only good things I can think of are that the art style looks great and the controls are good, the music fits the world that you play in but thats about it. I am going to rate it a 4 out of 10.  here

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
Early Access Review
								Alright, so, I was urged to play the game again, in which I agreed to. Before writing this, I was reading other reviews, and I completely disagree with one of them, which said something about the game being a little hard or it being objectiveless, and even it being difficult to progress, and even when you did, you would not feel like there was even any progression at all(Review posted June 11). All of it is sorta BS because how is it hard if you literally have 3-4 minutes of night, when things start spawning?(In the caves) How can you feel objectiveless if you have a kick♥♥♥♥♥NPC right from the beginning, asking you to help it, and even making cute little sounds when you agree to help it or not be mean to it? How can there not be any progression at all if when you even mine a single block, you get 5 exp, but it then adds up? There really can't be any objective if you set one yourself, or you ask the NPC right from the beginning, yet, I believe i remember the game even saying that you can talk to said NPC.Anyways, although I did end up finding fun in the game again, like riding snails, or making pits of hell for passive crabs to jump down, it did a few things that irked me, even though it's in early access. Well, for one, the tutorial. When you spawn in, you get pretty nice videos, dont get me wrong, they were nice, but they took up the entire right bottom corner of your screen. I don't want to go and say that they're bad, but it would probably be better if a message popped up asking if you wanted to watch the videos during the tutorial. Another thing was that when it was 12:00 at night, and you were in a cave,(Especially early game) 1: The monsters that spawn hurt. 2: Why spawn in the middle of the night, only to stay during the day?Personally, I'm very mixed on this game. It really varies from person to person. If I were able to buy it again, but with the current amount of knowledge I have on the game, I would wait until it comes out  with reviews. But you know what? I enjoyed the 34 hours on this game. No regrets. Not that I'm not going to ever play the game again, since i did buy the special edition. However, there are a few aspects that can be so easily exploited, like if you're going to die, you can just exit the game, only to appear at your cryopod, aka spawn point. Even at the tutorial, there's mounds of resources you can get, with no threats, giving a very significant edge in the early game.TL:DR; The game is amazing, even though there are a few parts to it that can be questionable, but the exception is that it's early access, and it is already a game that has so much potential of being an even better game. Best to wait until it is released out of early access, but it can be even better if you choose to buy it during early access. It's always nice to see games grow.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								Update (12/30/2014):Having played a good chunk of Terraria & Starbound, Edge of Space seems like it's coming into its own at this Early Access stage. Definitely recommended alongside those others. Starbound seems to be a bit more stagnant, or moved backwards in some ways (farming/survival is even less important now). EoS has added bunches of new stuff since I last played. EoS is also more futuristic with the ranged weaponry, whereas Starbound seems more reliant on melee, if that matters to you.Original (10/13/2013):"Terraria in space"? It's not a totally fair statement, yet this is also a title that the more famous Re-Logic has endorsed. If you're looking for something like Terraria, Terraria-ish in a new set of biomes, or otherwise wanting something familiar to your Terraria experience (but IN SPACE!), then Edge of Space is a good buy, even at this earlier stage in the game's development.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								A lot like Starbound but with far less polish.  After over an hour of playing I had no idea how to add tech, progress or move forward, even with online resources.Edit for Shaggy:The training was boring but informative... As a game consumer I am looking to maximize my engagment and fun per hour. Those first 20 minutes were low on the fun per hour.  Once I got down to the planet, mining was intuitive, but the super black pixelation of the light underground was kind of a bad experience. From a beauty/comfort stand point a smoother less grainy light pixelation on my mining apparatus would make the game much more fun. Once I figured out torches and my basic gear upgrades... I didn't know where to go. I had no forumlas unlocked and had no clue where to find or make them. There were few online guides or resources that made any sense (many seemed to have been written for previous version) and I got stuck within an hour.   While I think the game has a lot of potential it's not quite playable for me yet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I bought this game late last year and have tinkered with it off and on throughout the year.  The game carries a lot of potential but needs a deal of polish imo. There are problems with crafting certain items and mining takes quite a while (even with the higher tier pick). Edge of Space is essentially a slower-paced sci-fi version of Terraria with an exposure system (which limits how far down you can go before dying) and some other aspects.  It's still a relatively barebones game a year down the road and I cannot recommend it currently.  Wait another 6 months or go try 7 days to Die in the meantime.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								After speaking with LadyAijou extensively regarding Edge of Space. I would like to update my review with some further information.The reason advancement isn't working is right before the steam summer sale most of the NPC code was gutted out for revamping, very similar to what Rust is doing. The team at Handyman Studios was not expecting to get featured in the flash sale and ended up receiving more orders during that eight hour period than they had gotten in their previous best week during the 2-1 sale.The development team consists of two people, one of which had a system failure right after the change to the NPC code was implemented, which meant that what should have been fixed either right before or right after the flash sale was unable to be fixed. The chests dropping from nests is related to this issue because the nest/event has to spawn the appropriate creatures and then track that they have been killed, which with the changes to the NPC code is not working properly, so you're "failing" every nest/event you start.This means that yes, at this particular moment it is not possible to progress past the first biome. With full aluminum armor you can make it pretty much to the end of the first biome, but beyond that is not possible. I will be leaving my review as "not recommended" for the time being due to the non-available features, but will hold my final opinion in reserve until such time as the current mess is cleaned up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								We are still in the early access, but so far it seems like the developer is improving the game. I'm hopeful this game will become worthing of being called "Terraria in space". At the moment it's closer to being Terraria's younger sibling. A bit more clumsy and less eloquent, but full of potential because of its youth.The controls are a bit fiddly and not as fluid as in Terraria. Jumping from slopes triggers the jetpack instead of a regular jump, for example. The crafting interface is more organized by categorizing everything, but having to manually assign the materials from dropdown menus is clumsy at best. Worse, if you change quantity after you selected the materials, it resets the chosen materials and you have to pick them again. It'd be handy to pre-select the cheapest (or most plentiful) resources in a configuration which could build the item, by default. Changing quantity should preserve the materials already chosen. It might even change materials if that can make a recipe work when the old materials will not make it work.The tutorial has improved. It used to be overly wordy and micro-managed you, and then it dumped you on a planet afterwards without so much of a hint as to what to do next. It's more to the point now, but after the tutorial you're still left in the middle of nowhere on a sky island without any real pointers as to what you're supposed to do.The recent big patch added research levels which you can unlock by reading the research materials dropped by monsters you defeat. Massive improvement over the old system which basically gave you access to everything, but no clue what it did or why you would pick something. Now at least you have less choices so you can get familiar with the starter items and learn more from there.

Early Access Review
								I realize this is still a beta, so consider this a "beta" review. As of now, the game has a complete dearth of content, the pacing is beyond slow, and it feels like there is no direction and very little point to even playing it yet. It needs some massive tweaking, more linear and logical crafting progression, and more things to actually do.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								We are still in the early access, but so far it seems like the developer is improving the game. I'm hopeful this game will become worthing of being called "Terraria in space". At the moment it's closer to being Terraria's younger sibling. A bit more clumsy and less eloquent, but full of potential because of its youth.The controls are a bit fiddly and not as fluid as in Terraria. Jumping from slopes triggers the jetpack instead of a regular jump, for example. The crafting interface is more organized by categorizing everything, but having to manually assign the materials from dropdown menus is clumsy at best. Worse, if you change quantity after you selected the materials, it resets the chosen materials and you have to pick them again. It'd be handy to pre-select the cheapest (or most plentiful) resources in a configuration which could build the item, by default. Changing quantity should preserve the materials already chosen. It might even change materials if that can make a recipe work when the old materials will not make it work.The tutorial has improved. It used to be overly wordy and micro-managed you, and then it dumped you on a planet afterwards without so much of a hint as to what to do next. It's more to the point now, but after the tutorial you're still left in the middle of nowhere on a sky island without any real pointers as to what you're supposed to do.The recent big patch added research levels which you can unlock by reading the research materials dropped by monsters you defeat. Massive improvement over the old system which basically gave you access to everything, but no clue what it did or why you would pick something. Now at least you have less choices so you can get familiar with the starter items and learn more from there.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDITtl;dr Was on the way to being a good game, but ran out of fuel before it got there.When I first played this game it had serious potential; there were unique and interesting gameplay ideas, regular updates, and most importantly devs who respond on the forum. I spent a fair amount of time playing the game, eagerly anticipating updates, until I felt I had got this jist of what the game was and where it was going, so decided to wait a couple of months before playing again. When I booted it up again half a year later the only obvious changes were some haloween gimmiks, as far as I could tell updates had ground to a standstill. A year (and a bit) later and no further changes, until I saw a post saying that the devs hadn't abandoned the game, however they could tell us why they weren't working on it at the moment (which was what promted me change my review). For comparison I've left my original review below, showing how excited I was for this game.ORIGINAL REVIEWThis is a really promising game, with dedicated developers who are eager to share their creation with the community. It is not a finished game at the moment, but is what a beta game should be. Updates are designed to test specific features so that they can be polished, submitting tickets is on the main menu and the developers actually respond to posts in the forums. Although it sound like these are obvious aspects for any beta game there are too many early access games that care too much about people playing them, instead of testing them to make a better game in the long run.The gameplay itself will be familiar to anybody who has played terraria, starbound etc, but with enough unique features to make it interesting. One of the best features is the crafting system that classifies materials (eg ice is a chemical, which is a raw material => raw/chemical/ice), therefore some recipes will require any chemical or any raw material etc.Overall, if you are looking for a good beta that will turn into a great game, I would recommend buying it now. If you don't want to be actively involved in improving the game, then wait until it is fully released so that you aren't disappointed and forget about it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												DONT BUY GAME IS ABANDONED AND STILL ALPHA STAGEFinally Early access done right.Regular updates, it already got two different huge biomes !Devs are posting regularly in the steam forums.This game remembers me of an insane mix of metroid and terraria.Your an astronaut and embark on a mission to reclaim and terraform a split up planet. The deeper you get the more radiation you will discover so dont forget your protection !Of course you can setup your outpost and craft all shiny furniture. You can research different armor sets and weapon types like phase and projectile weapons. It got even nice upgrade mechanics like improved health , deploying mini turrets or even a grappling hook !Now you say what ? Only 2 biomes and terraforming isnt implemented yet ? With terraform i mean turn the land into a more livable space with less radiation and hostile creatures. Base building you can do from the start!Dont fool yourself the biomes in EOS work much differently than compared to terraria. Terrarias biomes are rather small and can be traversed quickly. But on the other hand EOS's biomes really feel vast and huge. So those areas really invite you to explore and discover new lifeforms and alien buildings :)Basically the end end goal upon release is to turn the planet back into a livable space with oxygen etc. But terraforming is a future feature.I think in the past 2 months this early access title did do huge steps in the right direction. I was just on a server now and got disconnected. So i was confused, but actually they pushed an update right now ! So those devs are really crazy with the updates. For example the christmas update included 2 new dungeons , 1 new boss, 1 special event and several new items to craft.TL;DRBasically its a blend of 2d metroidvania and terraria. Ranged combat is a huge deal with many rifles and laser guns.  Each crafted weapon can get different stats and clip sizes etc.It maybe starts slow and you need to get used to the crafting and research mechanics, but im sure after 4-5 hours you feel right at home :)But take notice Win Xp is NOT supported !Mac and linux arent supported yet, but get a future implementation! Just check out the forums to get a better picture whats going on.When starting the game first time i strongly recommend doing the tutorial first.Edit2: Not recommended anymore, because its abandoneware. The website shut down and community manager got fired!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Old Review:Easily the most dull game of the year.I've been playing Edge of Space the past eight hours; with the single thought in my mind of: "This game must get better eventually, right?"  well; I've been essentially in the same spot with the same equipment for the past five hours.  Killing crabs n' jelly fish, and mining titanium, aluminum, stone, mud, clay, and dirt does get old after a while.  I found a strange white box with a blue arrow on it in a cave and tried to us eit, but that just flashed some screen for half a second and went away; and I was unable to interact with it again.  But let's put things into points for the sake of organization:Good things:*Good movement system.*Good art & music.*Online co-op.*Interesting concept.Bad Things:*Very unpolished.*Bad interface & not very user-friendly.*No explanation for the purpose of alot of things, for example the matter recombiner; the game does not tell you what it does, and the description is simply: "You can't even wager a guess as to how this crazy machine works.", normally checking a wiki would help an issue like this, but their wiki is ancient and not updated.  And then there are things like the random events that go on in the world like the crab nests, and random things such as the weird white box with blue arrow-  no idea what purpose the box served, didn't realize the crab nest was an event.*Lack of things to do; the only goal you might have in the game is simply go lower.. And there is no reason to go lower as you have all the resources you need in the top areas.*Lack of resources; it may seem like a good thing that alluminum is basically the most awesome freakin' resource in existence, but it really makes the game boring when you're not bothering to actually look for things.*Uninteresting enemies.*Uninteresting areas; why would the devs think it was a good idea to make the entire game take place on some floating rocks ?*The relaxing music and police sirens(?) doesn't lower the boring factor of this game.*Terrible enemy AI.*Poorly made tutorial levels, tutorial more interesting than the actual game.*Extremely useless chests; for this let me explain how chests work, you craft one then place it in the world; then you right click it to open it, you then have to manually drag and drop each item you wish to place in it, into it; and the chest only has three slots.*Lack of creativity; how many times has the space shark and space animals concept been done now?*Very unprofessional dev team.*Just a shoddy game in general; people like to consider it as a terraria and starbound ripoff- but in all honesty that's an insult to both Terraria and Starbound.*I'm fairly certain the preview images which show awesome things happening are all fake.*Dropped items from full inventory disappear within seconds, made 7 chests to put my items somewhere- didn't realize my inventory was full,  chests vanish.  Make a full suit of aluminum armor, don't realize inventory is full,  poof.*Glitchy items:  Made two chests, had two slots free- placed a chest, the other chest vanished into nowhere.  Used an emergency recall, had two in my inventory; the other vanished. If I had any suggestions for this game; I recommend they take a page from Windforge and add player made spaceships to fly around the edge of space.  ps:  Don't use the Omega research unless you have good equipment, it just brings you to a boss whom will murder you if you still are using low level stuff.Well,  all in all I recommend the game; but make sure you don't play it at night or else you're liable to fall asleep from the sheer boredom it causes; and if you're planning on buying the game because of the awesome screenshots you saw of like a desert and mechs and whatnot- those are definitely faked, there are four biomes; you can go to about two of them, a grassy biome and a cold biome.  There's also about 8 or so enemies currently and about six(?) different resources.Edit August 2016:So, it is now the distant future since I last reviewed the game; and honestly it's worse than before.  The game opens to a beautiful 404 page error after the Unity Logo and Splash screen.  And the game starts with you in the middle of nowhere with a shark with lasers and crap attached to it with a high pitch voice that asks you to do pointless tasks such as gathering dirt and clay for it.   Simple actions in the inventory system such as dragging an item to the trash drops the FPS immensely, nests are incredibly annoying to destroy as they infinitely respawn the enemy guards every time you shoot it; and you need to shoot one quite a lot to destroy it. AI is terrible, they wander back and forth not really trying to get to you, in part because their AI is considering the bullets you shoot as ground, so if they're jumping into the air and you shoot them, they will continue to jump as high as they want, or they'll just plain turn around when shot at with a little ? symbol.    The animations and art is weird, the physics is bad, the overall game is mayhaps more boring than it used to be.But all in all, better than No Man's Sky.  So at least there is that.
